Title: Comment Submitted by Mariette Nowak
Comment:
An access route would make it more likely to increase drilling in the Arctic, which is ill-advised for many reasons.  The Arctic is melting fast, & many areas are remote so an accident with an oil tanker would be devastating and not easily addressed in remote areas.  In addition, a spill would affect the livelihood of native peoples in the region.

Also, both the drilling itself as well as a spill would likely kill or injure native wildlife at a time when we are so many species are declining or endangered, adding to the threat of extinction  as described in the recent UN report.

Finally, additional fossil fuels use will harm the earth, dramatically increasing climate change, which has already resulted in unprecedented flooding, fires, heat waves and other problems for every person on this planet.

I oppose this route study and any further fossil fuel extraction in the Arctic.

I urge you to extend the comment period for all the above reasons, so  many other voices will be heard.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: As a taxpayer, I strongly oppose this route study and any further fossil fuel extraction in the Arctic. It is clearly an attempt to increase drilling for fossil fuels in the pristine ecosystem of the Arctic. I demand that the Coast Guard withdraw this study immediately.

Title: Comment Submitted by the Inuvialuit Regional Corporation
Comment:
Alaska and Canada are connected not only by land but by the Beaufort Sea as well. Research is ongoing in the Western Canadian Arctic to identify low impact shipping corridors and to adhere to the management and conservation objectives laid out in the Inuvialuit Final Agreement, as well as the Integrated Oceans Management Plan for the Beaufort Sea (attached below). 

Current research occurring within the western Canadian Arctic includes the Beaufort Regional Environmental Assessment (BREA) which has produced a significant amount of valuable data for the Canadian Beaufort Sea. "The primary goal for BREA was to produce relevant scientific and socio-economic data that would inform project-level environmental assessments and regulatory decision-making for oil and gas activities, while strengthening the relationship between environmental assessments and integrated management and planning in the region". The regional strategic environmental assessment is a comprehensive review which considers the relationships between the environment, social, cultural, economic, and traditional harvesting factors. Please visit https://rsea.inuvialuit.com/ for more information. 


Given the close proximity of Alaska to Canada, a review of existing and current research and management plans may aid in the Port Access Route Study.

Title: Comment Submitted by Richard Powell, Nautical Data Branch / Marine Chart Division
Comment:
Dear Mr. Detweiler,

The Marine Chart Division of NOAA's Office of Coast Survey is providing comments and related material regarding the possible establishment of shipping safety fairways along the Atlantic Coast of the United States detailed in the Federal Register (Volume 85, Number 119, pages 37034-37040) dated June 19, 2020Docket No. USCG-2019-0279. The Marine Chart Division is responsible for charting U.S. coastal waters and certain inland waterways. In keeping with that responsibility, the division depicts the locations of shipping safety fairways in navigable waterways as shown on NOAA ENCElectronic Navigational Charts.

I am a nautical cartographer with extensive experience maintaining nautical publications (United States Coast Pilot) and working with Federal regulations as they relate to NOAA's suite of nautical products. I am currently assigned to the Nautical Data Branch of the Marine Chart Division.

The nine proposed fairways were plotted in Esri ArcMap and evaluated against the Electronic Navigational Charts (ENCs) for accuracy and for noting any potential obstructions, fixed structures or administrative areas that intersect the fairways, which could possibly impact safe navigation. The results of this evaluation produced approximately 100 features intersecting the proposed fairways. It should be noted that obstruction features categorized as non-dangerous are generally omitted from this list. I created a file geodatabase of polygons that encompass the features on the intersecting ENCs. Please note that the polygons encompassing these features are a bit larger than the actual features as depicted on the ENCs. Due to the limitations on uploading certain file types to the website www.regulations.gov, this data will be provided to the U.S. Coast Guard as a file geodatabase (.gdb)  and a comma separated values file (.csv) in a separate email message to you.

In addition, I found a possible discrepancy in one of the proposed fairways. For the Delaware Bay Eastern Approach Cutoff Fairway, one corner position (3849'48"N., 07434'36"W.) appears to have been omitted from the ANPRM in the Federal Register. I believe that the western end of this fairway should coincide with the eastern end of the existing traffic lane. Please refer to the ACPARS Proposed Routing - Northern Area map as posted in the docket.

Features included in the file geodatabase were identified in a specific time frame and are subject to revision or removal from the ENCs, which are continually updated. In addition, new features may be added to the affected ENCs after you receive this comment. Therefore, you should download the most recent ENCs from the Office of Coast Survey website at https://www.charts.noaa.gov/InteractiveCatalog/nrnc.shtml. If you need assistance with downloading and or viewing ENCs, please let me know.

The purpose of the file geodatabase features is to facilitate the U.S. Coast Guard's decision-making process for positioning the fairways. I defer to the U.S. Coast Guard to make any possible adjustments to the proposed fairways. If you require any further information on any of these features, then please feel free to contact me via the information I have provided.

Sincerely,

Richard H. Powell
Nautical Data Branch / Marine Chart Division

Title: Comment Submitted by Michael, Chloe, Nick & Jack, Sustainability and Environmental Policy class, Central Michigan University
Organization Name: Sustainability and Environmental Policy class, Central Michigan University
Comment:
Alternative three, Continue to Meet with the COTP when submitting an ORA, would be the best course of action. This is because it provides for the most safety precautions to be taken when establishing new LNG facilities, while also providing more flexibility for LNG facility owners since the amount of work they would have to do to get the facility approved would be reduced. This course of action is important because it would codify industry standards and establish a national baseline for these safety standards. Doing this would ensure that any future LNG facilities would follow these safety standards, protecting facility personnel, communities near the facility, and the environment alike. 
This course of action also reduces the burden to the industry while also still requiring a meeting with the Captain of the Port. This is important because the meeting with the COTP would still allow the COTP to notice any potential safety risks or other hazards that may have gone unnoticed if not for the meeting. This could allow negative impacts to be avoided, ensuring the most safety for personnel, communities, and the environment. This meeting is important because without it, something bad might happen as a result of the LNG facility being established. This added step in the process is important to the safety and security of the potential LNG facility.

Title: Comment Submitted by Cecile T. Scofield
Comment:
CECILE T. SCOFIELD
1628 SW WATERFALL BLVD.
PALM CITY, FL   34990
774-526-4738
dawson.chris@comcast.net

November 8, 2020

Mr. Ken Smith, Project Manager
Coast Guard
Vessel and Facility Operating Standards Division
Commandant (CG-OES-2)

Submitted to:  http://www.regulations.gov


Dear Mr. Smith:  

RE:  DOCKET NUMBER USCG-2019-9444 - OPERATONAL RISK ASSESSMENTS FOR WATERFRONT FACILITIES HANDLING LIQUEFIED NATURAL GAS AS FUEL, AND UPDATES TO INDUSTRY STANDARDS

Under an Interagency Agreement (IA), Participating Agencies are responsible for exercising regulatory authority over the siting, design, construction and operation of Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) facilities, and related land and marine safety and security issues.  The IA ensures complete assessment of all facility operations and hazards and to improve the cooperation among the Participating Agencies to share information gathered, considered and relied upon by each of them, and specifically providing the necessary support for the NEPA

FERC (Lead Federal Agency):  Conducts environmental, safety, and security reviews of LNG plants and related pipeline facilities and prepares overall NEPA documentation, including tanker operation; terminal construction and operation; and environmental and cultural impacts.

RSPA:  Promulgates and enforces safety regulations and standards for the transportation and storage of LNG in or affecting interstate or foreign commerce under the pipeline safety laws. 
 
USCG:  As a Participating Agency, exercises regulatory authority over LNG facilities which affect the safety and security of port areas and navigable waterways. 
 
The role FERC plays in the LNG approval process cannot be overstated.  Unfortunately, FERC disclaimed jurisdiction over small-scale, inland LNG export facilities without a formal Rulemaking that would have required LNG facility developers to file Petitions for Declaratory Order with FERC to determine federal jurisdiction.  As a result, companies, e.g. New Fortress Energy (NFE), are siting, constructing and operating LNG export facilities on very small parcels of land in densely populated communities. e.g. NFE's LNG facility sited on an under-13-acre site in Miami, Florida, that began exporting containerized (ISO) LNG from Port of Miami on February 5, 2016, and in March of 2017, began transporting LNG by rail to Port Everglades, Florida.  This facility has exported approximately 390,000 Mcf of natural gas from Port Everglades from January 1st through August 30th of this year, and I understand that the USCG has not as yet established Exclusion Zones around ships that are transporting containerized LNG that are similar to those found in 33 CFR  165.110 - Safety and Security Zone; Liquefied Natural Gas Carrier Transits and Anchorage Operations, Boston, Massachusetts.

The proposed Rule would revise the Coast Guard's existing regulations to allow waterfront facilities handling LNG as fuel to conduct an Operational Risk Assessment (ORA) instead of a Waterway Suitability Assessment (WSA) without first obtaining Captain of the Port approval.  It appears the proposed Rule would render the terms of the referenced Interagency Agreement moot.  

In 2007, Weaver's Cove Energy performed an Operational Risk Assessment that concluded the approach to their proposed waterfront LNG terminal in Fall River, Massachusetts, was "suitable" for LNG tank traffic.  However, in an actual Waterway Suitability Assessment, the U. S. Coast Guard determined that the approach was "unsuitable" due to "navigational safety challenges."  The ruling upheld previous USCG decisions handed down in 2007 and 2008, effectively blocking the proposed LNG terminal.

If the proposed Rule is approved, LNG developers and others will have yet another opportunity to make up their own rules as they go along.  Schematics covering density and character of marine traffic, locks, bridges, or other man-made obstructions in the waterway, along with factors adjacent to the facility, e.g. water depths, tidal range, protection from high seas, natural hazards, underwater pipelines and cables and distance of berthed vessels from the channel, and other issues that affect the safety and security of the waterway, could easily be manipulated to produce the best outcomes "on paper." 

If the USCG were to approve the proposed Rule, I fear you will be giving LNG facility developers and others carte blanche to run amok, and unfortunately, potential "unintended consequences" could include immeasurable loss of life, severe damage to property and critical infrastructure, and permanent ecological damage.  


Sincerely,
Cecile T, Scofield

Title: Comment Submitted by Lori Reinhart
Comment: As a First Class Pilot the reliance on automation scares me on our waterways. As it is now i have witnessed multiple times new officers relying solely on ECDIS for piloting and its failures. I have seen automated wheelstands fail multiple times. Who would be responsible if there is an incident? The master of the vessel  or the programmer?

Title: Comment Submitted by Matt Lagarde
Comment:
Introduction of autonomous vessels is expected and inevitable from a certain standpoint but I believe it will require an intense overhaul of current regulations which may take quite some time to accomplish.

Under the Steering an Sailing Rules of The Road:
Rule 2:  At what point does an automated system make a conscious decision given all of the details of a situation to deviate from a rule in order to avoid a collision?

Rule 5: Lookout.  In certain circumstances it becomes necessary to supplement the Lookout.  On a purely autonomous vessel with no personnel onboard, how does this occur?  When does an AI on a manned vessel determine it needs help?

Rule 9: Whether or not a channel is a "Narrow Channel" is currently a judgement call.  There is not a specific definitions and TSAC reviewed the Rule and upheld the recommendation to maintain the flexibility in application because it is extremely dependent on prevailing circumstances as well as the nature and maneuverability of the two vessels.  Can an AI make this determination?

Rule 11: Applicability to steering and sailing rules of vessels within sight of one another.  All of these rules depend not only on the plotting capabilities of navigation electronics but depend on the ability to determine a contacts aspect and apparent heading in addition to the vectors determined by AIS and Radar.  The position of the navigation lights is a factor in determining right of way and actions that may need to be taken.  Will the AI be able to tell the difference between a sailboat and a seaplane and such for vessel not required to carry AIS?

In many cases with the Steering and Sailing Rules, particularly on inland rivers and in narrow channels, passing arrangements need to made well ahead of time and require agreement between the two vessels.  Disagreements occur, intentions of what will occur or what maneuvers will be made need to be understood.  The proposed location of the meeting can be very specific and often utilizes local visual landmarks and features.  Can an AI understand in a river "not to come up past the old red camp under the point and stay tucked in under the dike on the 2 whistle"?  What if that arrangement is not satisfactory?  What does the AI do if it's proposal receives a 5 whistle response?  Will these vessel be able to comply with the Bridge to Bridge Radiotelephone Act requiring verbal communications?

Another Challenge on the Western Rivers may be the shifting currents and channel conditions.  On coastal and ocean voyages, traffic lanes and sailing lines may be fairly static and set and drift can be accounted for as long as the vessel is on a particular track.  That is not always an option on rivers routes whereas from transit to transit the track line may need to change based on river conditions which are most often judged by telltale eddys and "tells" from current interaction with buoys, bridge piers and the appearance of surface currents?

46 CFR 4.05:  How is an autonomous vessel expected to provide reports to the USCG in the event of a casualty for the 4.05 as well as hazardous condition requirements.  Initial reports are verbal now. Will the Command Centers and NRC be able to communicate with these vessels?  What format will the transfer of information take place?  Any report that is given or received verbally will need to be addressed.

47 CFR Radiotelephone log entries--How will the vessel transcribe necessary information and how will it record distress signals witnessed?

EPA NPDES-VGP inspections--How is the AI expected to fulfill the inspection and recordkeeping requirements?  

The Marine Safety Manuals governing manning will need to be revised.

The main concerns in my opinion as specified above are situations which require a conversation and agreement between two vessels in less than static conditions; understanding of intended actions that have not occurred yet; decisions which require evaluation of visual clues; understanding of local terminology, landmarks and lore; and situations which require verbal communication.  These vessels may need to rank somewhere after seaplanes in the pecking order and remain clear of all other vessels.

A secondary concern is reliability of function.  Technology is fairly well distributed throughout modern society and has been employed for decades an many roles.  But I often have issues with automobile nav systems, laptops and cell phones where the do unexpected things at unexpected times and may need intervention to get back on track.  If this happens in an area where it poses a navigational risk, how will it be addressed? 

To another commenters point, who is held accountable for marine casualties involving these vessels?  The owner?  The programmer?  Mariners have a credential at stake for negligence or misdeeds.  Who will be held accountable for misbehavior by automated vessels?

Hopefully we can work through these issues in a responsible planned manner.

Title: Comment Submitted by Craig H. Allen Sr.
Comment: The attached comments and suggestions are made in my personal capacity.  Craig H. Allen Sr.

Title: Comment Submitted by VTT SenseWay
Comment:
Marine Tractor Beam (MTB) is a digitalization of the seaway, which fuses data from multiple data sources and provides shared services for different maritime users.
MTB provides shared situational awareness and navigational services for the vessels on the digital seaway and traffic monitoring, management and control services for the future remote operation centers as well as existing ports and VTS centers on the shore side.
By using MTB services, it is possible to develop various end-user interfaces and applications for different use cases and end-users. This is the most cost-efficient way to enable vessel autonomy development and take new technologies into use already today in a controlled way.
In the final phase MTB can communicate with long range deep-sea autonomous vessels and digitally escort them safely to the port. However, there are many other opportunities before that.

Title: Comment Submitted by Liro Lindborg, LBRG Holdings
Comment:
In gereal following issues are considered as current major obstacles in introduction of autonomous vessel technolgogy for commercial use: 

Definitions issues:
There is currently no international definition of what an autonomous or unmanned ship is, what the various levels of autonomy are and whether an autonomous ship is a ship under international law.

Absence of crew issues:
UNCLOS defines that all ships must be “in the charge of a master and officers who possess appropriate qualifications”. SOLAS, MARPOL, STCW and the Paris MoU as well as the EU directive 16/2009 on PSC all presume that the master will be present onboard.

Issues of navigation rules:
It is expected that all ships will be capable of executing manoeuvres and steering in accordance with the basic rules of navigation as prescribed by the COLREGS.

Issue of cyber risks & connectivity:
Autonomous ships are highly dependent on computers and other robotic equipment, which could exacerbate the consequences of a cyber attack. 
No guaranteed global connectivity.

Issue of seaworthiness and error in navigation:
“Reasonably seaworthy in all respects” warranty applies to voyage policies of marine insurance at the commencement of the voyage. Under the Hague Visby Rules, to be seaworthy, the ship must be properly manned, among others.
Issues of liability and its limitation:
Generally, civil liability in shipping is regulated nationally, and it can be said that most jurisdictions require a fault-based standard.

Further considerations and studies on topic available.

Title: Comment Submitted by Marc Deglinnocenti, International Ocean Systems Magazine
Comment:
I do recommend the development of remotely operated U.S. flagged MASS with no seafarers on board. Referencing: the International Maritime Organization (IMO),(IMO Category 3) and fully autonomous MASS with no seafarers on board (IMO category 4) for inherently dangerous vessel operations such as immersive firefighting into toxic gases and chemicals or high temperature flames that pose an extreme risk to firefighting personnel. This also holds true for scientific study of volcanic island formation by research vessels where sudden and unpredictable pyroclastic flows can instantly kill shipboard personnel. Other areas of concern would be sailors conducting minesweeping operations of other inherently dangerous military missions.

I do not recommend IMO Categories 3 and 4 for large commercial maritime vessels due to the threat of pirates seizing vessels for ransom, terrorists boarding vessels for destructive and environmental threat purposes, and lack of shipboard firefighting personnel able to attack fires as they begin.

I do recommend a drastic decrease in crew requirements though for the above mentioned categories. C white paper on MASS, Marine Technology Society Journal Vol. 53, No. 5, Sept/Oct 2019, entitled: Marine Autonomous Surface Ships on Blue Seas. I also recommend more limited crew area designs for large commercial MASS to accommodate local pilots, limited safety and security crew, maintenance personnel, USCG inspectors, and student cadets. Along with this new reduced crew structures would come a small galley facility and some retained SOLAS requirements such as fire extinguishers, SOLAS rails, ring buoys, EPIRBs, etc. This plan will also ensure the future of our merchant marine and future local pilot personnel. For further information see my award winning article published in Professional Mariner Magazine issue: July 2019, article: Maritime Jobs on the Line as Autonomous Ships Gain Steam. 

I believe that by reducing a crew size from twenty to three or four while providing pilot access is not an unreasonable compromise from those vessel owners that would see large commercial MASS IMO categories 3 and 4 if they had their way. I feel that the public safety outweighs their intended profit margin desires. My past research into the insurance requirements for these type of MASS vessels is somewhat alarming. I received feedback that states that the loss and liability is restricted by law to that of the MASS vessel's value plus its cargo, whereas the environmental and public damage can far exceed that.

My exception to drastically reducing crew personnel on large commercial vessels would have to be in the area of passenger vessels. It has been my experience that passengers pose some very unique issues that require immediate crew interdiction from both small and large numbers of crew.

To help the USCG with these proposals I suggest that the U.S. representatives to the IMO Marine Safety Committee (MSC) push for these suggested reforms to be quickly transformed into uniform international and then U.S. domestic inland laws as amendments to COLREGs after the IMO scoping study is completed.

Title: Comment Submitted by Mike Piskur, Great Lakes St. Lawrence Governors & Premiers
Organization Name: Great Lakes St. Lawrence Governors & Premiers
Comment:
The Conference of Great Lakes and St. Lawrence Governors and Premiers (GSGP) unites the chief executives from Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Ontario, Pennsylvania, Qubec, and Wisconsin. The Governors and Premiers work as equal partners to grow the regions $6 trillion economy and protect the worlds largest system of surface fresh water. In 2013, the Governors and Premiers launched a maritime initiative aimed to increase the efficiency and competitiveness of the Great Lakes St. Lawrence maritime transportation system. The Governors and Premiers Regional Maritime Strategy, released in 2016, is designed to double maritime trade, shrink the environmental footprint of the regions transportation network, and support the regions industrial core.

Smart ships represent a major leap forward in maritime technology that can help advance regional and national goals. Emerging technologies like advanced propulsion and shore-based control are revolutionizing waterborne transportation. Human error is responsible for up to 96% of maritime accidents, and smart ship technologies can leverage investments in training, pilotage, and other safety measures to reduce accidents by eliminating human exposure to hazardous or difficult tasks. Accordingly, in the near term, smart ships are particularly well-suited for research, hazardous response, and operation in dangerous conditions. The Great Lakes St. Lawrence Governors & Premiers have partnered with the maritime industry, universities, and other stakeholders to create the Smart Ships Coalition. This Coalition is working to establish this region as a global center of excellence for researching, developing, and testing smart ship technologies both on vessels and on shore. In the long term, smart ship technologies can improve the efficiency and competitiveness of the Great Lakes St. Lawrence maritime system, with the potential to create new high-paying and high-skill jobs, improve the environmental performance of regional transportation, and enhance the safety and security of shipping. To this end, the Governors and Premiers developed a Smart Ships Action Plan, which includes recommendations that the US Coast Guard (USCG) and other federal government can take to facilitate the growth of these emerging technologies. These emerging technologies present numerous opportunities for USCG to develop forward-looking policies and regulations.
	The complete comments are included as an attachment.

Title: Comment Submitted by Mika Vainio, GIM Robotics
Comment:
GIM Robotics has provided an answer to a selected question (Q9) of this RFI based on our experience on 1) localization, 2) environmental modeling and 3) obstacle detection & tracking related issues in the field of autonomous vessels. 

We are experts for example in a) fusing thermal and color camera data to enable visual vessel detection and tracking in all lighting conditions, b) fusing lidar, camera and radar data to accurately segment, classify and track any objects of interest, c) comparing sea chart and 3D sensor data to automatically extract all moving targets on the surface and d) calibrating multiple sensors into a common coordinate frame, enabling advanced sensor fusion. 

Our detailed answer can be found from the attached document.

Title: Comment Submitted by Pivi Haikkola, One Sea / DIMECC
Comment:
(2) The role of the master of the ship needs to be reviewed as well as minimum safe manning.
(3) IMOs Interim Guidelines for MASS (Maritime Autonomous Surface Ships) trials are suitable for testing. Tests can be facilitated if the Coast Guard applies the guidelines to tests within U.S. waters.
(4) The role of remote operating centers and their requirements need to be reviewed. E.g. What is to be done if there is a fire in the remote operating center? What authorities regulate remote operating centers? etc.
(5) It is important to get common vocabulary. The terms manning and unmanned must not be mixed up with levels of autonomy, which relate to technical levels of automation on board. Remote control is also another aspect, not to be mixed up with the others. 
(6) Potential operational cost savings come mainly from two sources; reduced manning and decrease in fuel consumption. Savings in CAPEX come at high levels of autonomy where human related systems can be excluded from the ship. The savings are dependent of the ship type, route and level of autonomy, therefore a general answer cannot be given. Since the ships spend large amounts of their time and fuel in ports, the entire logistics chain should be autonomized to gain the benefits.  According to a study that One Sea has commissioned from an independent third party, in the three cases studied, the OPEX savings between current designs and the highest level of autonomy studied, ranged between 4 and 11 %. The CO2 emissions of the vessels can also be reduced, according to the study in some cases upto 20 %. The cost of accidents is also high, and it is not only included in the insurance prices.
(7) Autopilot is used extensively already globally and Dynamic Positioning utilized in current automized navigational solutions, has been used for over 20 years. Regarding machinery has remote diagnostics been utilized again for more than 20 years, although not in the whole fleet, as its cost has been rather high.
(8) U.S. has a lot of ferries that could be automated with current autodocking and autosteering technologies. Electrical propulsion makes taking in use of autonomous propulsion technologies much easier. These technologies can also be utilized with tugs and coastal feeders in the first stages of adapting the technologies.
(9) All onboard systems can be augmented through increased automation.
(10) Regarding port facilities, there are various fastenings that do not need ropes available for vessels nowadays. Also the port operations should be automatized to ensure the benefits and make port turn-around times shorter.
(11) The insurance companies calculate risks based on the occurrences in the past. It is not clear if insurance prices for these vessels would not be more costly initially.
(12) The work will change so that more of it will be done on land from the office. At the same time the safety of those still at sea is expected to increase.
(13) People working in the maritime field will need to have better computer and IT skills. They will also need better communicational skills in order to communicate with the experts in various fields.
(14) Infrastructure needs are for example increased bandwidth through satellite communication (more satellites).
(16) Increased automation will improve safety by decreasing human errors, but at the same time it will bring with it potential new threats relating to the new technologies on board.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Comment on Question #3 (Q3) from the RFI: To improve safety through improved tracking, monitoring and potential remote control, USCG should require all autonomous vessels maintain connectivity to a manned control station via an RF device while within 12 miles of shore. To promote innovation and competition in this area, ability to create and use RF links should be made reasonable and easy for a wide set of potential users (individuals and commercial or government entities).  To this end, the FCC should dedicate spectrum for this use. Further, Temporary and Experimental Licenses should be made available, with as low an administrative cost (time and/or money) as reasonable to assure safety.

Q5: As stated in the comment on question 3 regarding policy changes: To improve safety through improved tracking, monitoring, and potential remote control, USCG should require all autonomous vessels maintain connectivity to a manned control station via an RF device while within 12 miles of shore. To promote innovation and competition in this area, ability to create and use RF links should be made reasonable and easy for a wide set of potential users (individuals and commercial or government entities). To this end, the FCC should dedicate spectrum for this use. Further, Temporary and Experimental Licenses should be made available, with as low an administrative cost (time and/or money) as reasonable to assure safety.

Q6: The Government already seems to consider there is benefit in the use of automated and autonomous commercial vessels, including the efficient use of labor, etc. This response focuses on the potential benefits of standardizing persistent connectivity to said vessels.
The most important benefit of the policies recommended above is safety. Persistent broadband connectivity allows unmanned vessels to continually report their location and additional sensor information (images, telemetry, etc.), which allows better tracking of those vessels as a part of overall traffic management, which in turn allows automated and autonomous vessels to avoid dangerous interactions with other manned and unmanned vessels.
A connected vessel could also report system health and potential maintenance needs. Finally, a connected vessel could be remote controlled in emergency situations, allowing manual avoidance of dangerous situations.

Q8: Wireless RF links are the most commercially feasible technology to allow automated and autonomous vessels to maintain persistent connectivity with shore-based safety and/or control centers. However, many RF capabilities lack sufficient range, data throughput, or ability to maintain connectivity in a dynamic, moving (high sea state) environment.  
There are two widely discussed technologies that could work in a mobile environment, SATCOM and 5G, but they are not economically or technologically viable. SATCOM requires expensive hardware on each vessel, a high recurring cost for necessary bandwidth, and injects too much latency for the application. Alternatively, 5G shows promise in providing low latency and high bandwidth persistent connectivity, but is only suitable for limited terrestrial locations where significant and expensive infrastructure can be installed at relatively short distances from the subscriber devices. 5G does not have the range for this application.
The best current capability to provide necessary coverage is deployment of a technology called Mobile Ad-hoc Networking (MANET), which is already commercially available, and has the ability to create a wide area coverage, creating connectivity to moving objects at ranges beyond the 12-mile inclusion zone and with 10s to 100s of Mbps of throughput such that there is enough capacity to carry command and control data, potentially to include video, radar and other sensor data.  

Q9: RF connectivity may require an RF device be added to the vessel.

Q10: Port facilities may desire to install equipment to allow persistent RF connectivity to automated and autonomous commercial vessels.

Q11: Beyond the cost of equipment to be installed on automated and autonomous vessels to allow persistent connectivity, there is administrative overhead and potential licensing fees to acquire available frequency bandwidth. The Government should strive to standardize frequencies and make usable frequency allocations easy and low cost for vessel operators.

Q14: The Government will need to assure there is a terrestrial RF infrastructure. Each vessel will need a device to connect to the infrastructure.

Q15: An open RF link may expose private data; therefore, the standard should include NSA approved encryption to the network and devices.

Q16: Unmanned vessels pose a security risk (they can be more easily commandeered by criminals) and safety risk (without permanent observation they could drift into conflict with other vessels).  Standardization on a persistent RF link to monitor and potentially remote control the vessels will help to mitigate these risks.

Title: Comment Submitted by Christopher Kuester, Milwaukee Harbor Yacht Club
Comment:
To whom it may concern:

I am commenting on behalf of the Milwaukee Harbor Yacht Club and its members.

The expansion of time that Milwaukee bridges will not open to maritime traffic has caused multiple unsafe conditions to boaters of all kinds navigating the Milwaukee River. Larger boats are being held up and being forced to hold in place while smaller watercraft and paddle operated vessels are trying to navigate around the stopped larger boat traffic. 

The two hour advance notice has also caused disruption to maritime traffic, as witnessed by many boats trying to navigate upriver and being turned around if two hour advance notice was not given. There has also been a noticeable decrease of patrons to riverside businesses due to these expanded hours of non-opening.

In addition, more boats are violating the slow no wake rules on the Milwaukee River system in order to get through bridge openings before the clock strikes 4pm. 

Please  return to the 8:30a-9:30a and 4:30p-5:30p non-opening hours.

This trial has also caused problems with smaller commercial traffic navigating the Milwaukee River, forcing them to alter schedules and loss of business.

Respectfully submitted,

Christopher Kuester
Milwaukee Harbor Yacht Club- Commodore
5304 S. 8th Street
Milwaukee, WI 53221

Title: Comment Submitted by Marine Industries Association of South Florida
Comment:
Comments of the Marine Industries Association of South Florida on Docket Number USCG-2019-0955 

The Association offers the following comments on the revision to paragraph (c) of 117.313, 33 CFR, promulgated in the July 13, 2020 Federal Register (2020-14578) Notice of Proposed Rulemaking for the Drawbridge Operation Regulation; New River, Fort Lauderdale, FL:

1.	The Background, Purpose and Legal Basis discussion in this Notice refers to an abbreviated vessel traffic study conducted during the month of March 2020 and made observations about average queue time for vessels.  This study was conducted just after the public was advised to remain at home due to the coronavirus epidemic and the resultant cancellation of the commuter train operations.  While this included a two-week collection of data and two-day field observation, this period of time and observed effects may not be representative of the impact on waterway users due to the disruption in train service caused by the coronavirus epidemic.  
2.	In subparagraph (3)(i) and (ii) we interpret the proposed rule to mean that the requirement for an additional 10-min. period for each hour from 12:00 p.m. and 2:59 p.m. will be required to be published by the drawbridge owner when the quarterly schedule is published and reflected on the owner's website and mobile application in addition to the fixed periods prescribed by this paragraph.
3.	In subparagraph (5), a notification of operational failure or other emergency circumstances impacting normal drawbridge operations is only conveyed to the Coast Guard Captain of the Port Miami.  We interpret the rule to mean that, once notified, the COTP will take prompt and appropriate measures to communicate these emergency circumstances to the waterway community so that appropriate measures can be taken by vessel operators. 
4.	In subparagraphs (6) and (7), a drawbridge log and a website and mobile application are required to be maintained.  To clarify who is to maintain these we recommend inserting "by the drawbridge owner" after "maintained" each time that the word appears.
5.	In subparagraph (7)(ii), timely notices to the waterway community regarding the impacts of emergency circumstances is important in addition.  We recommend adding at the end after "schedules" the phrase "and impacts of emergency circumstances".
6.	In subparagraph (8)(iii), the drawbridge is required to be opened after rail traffic has cleared the drawbridge.  We interpret the rule to mean that this will be done as soon after rail traffic has cleared to be in compliance with the requirement in subparagraph (1) that the drawbridge will be maintained in the fully open-to-navigation position for vessels at all times, except when permitted under the rule for rail traffic or inspections and minor repairs.  The following is offered as a draft replacement of paragraph (8)(iii) as a clarification (with changes underlined):
"(iii) After the rail traffic has cleared the drawbridge, the drawbridge shall promptly open and the lights shall return to green.".

Title: Comment Submitted by Sam Bidwell
Comment:
We see these proposed changes to the Alfred A Cunningham Bridge opening times as having both good and unnecessarily poor implications for boaters:
	The removal of the odd summer Sunday afternoon opening hours is good as this unnecessarily limits weekend boat traffic during optimum boating hours.  In discussions a couple of years ago with the NCDOT Bridge Department, the City of New Bern Director of Public Works, and City Manager's office, no one could justify nor would take responsibility for recommending these hours, thus it is good that they are being removed with these proposed changes.
	The general change from on demand openings to openings on the half-hour and on the hour between 0600 and 2200 we believe to be unnecessary. The number of boaters transiting this bridge requiring an opening has decreased dramatically in the last two years with the loss of the Bridgepoint Marina to Hurricane Florence, and thus there should be no need to increase opening restrictions at this time. We recommend maintaining the "on-demand" practice for bridge openings of past years.
	The further limitation of "rush hour" openings to 90 minutes in the evening is unnecessarily burdensome to boaters.  We were informed by the City of New Bern Director of Public Works that he was pushed for this change because senior city employees kept catching the bridge opening when they left their office at 5:00 pm.  If this is the driver of this change, then shifting the evening "rush hour" opening restriction to 1630 to 1730 should be sufficient for the city workers to leave their office promptly at 5:00 pm and cross the bridge unimpeded.  This is similar to the new proposal for restricted hours during the morning rush hour. 
	It is important to keep in mind that the Cunningham Bridge is only one of a number of routes that can be taken to enter and exit New Bern and is not the primary road for emergency vehicles going to any portion of the city or county.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jay Reed
Comment:
The Coast Guard Station at Silver Eel Pond, Fishers Island, NY should remain open and active. As a recreational fisherman, I have observed extreme boating conditions at the Race due to the rapid current. It is not hard to imagine a Man Overboard situation in which a rapid response would be crucial. Especially in the spring and fall seasons when the water temperatures are low. The southern shore of Fishers Island is another popular fishing ground. The Silver Eel Pond Station is ideally located to provide emergency assistance.

Also, please consider, the Race has a high level of commercial and military traffic. There is a fair number of ferry, barge and freighter movements through the constricted waters of the Race. These ships are providing service to all of the large ports of Long Island Sound. In addition, there are a fair number of surfaced submarines transiting to and from Naval Submarine Base New London. Again, the Silver Eel Pond Station is ideally located to provide security support and emergency assistance.

Thank you for considering these remarks. Please keep the Silver Eel Pond Station open.

Title: Comment Submitted by the Commissioners of Oxford
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by Jan Greer
Comment:
I heard only today, 4/9/2020, about the initiative to close the Oxford, Maryland USCG station. This news is deeply shocking. Proposing the USCG Station Annapolis as an alternative for mariners in distress on the Eastern Bay, of which there are many thousands every day during the boating season, and virtually year-round for our watermen, is tantamount to having no Coast Guard assistence within reach at all in anything resembling adequate timeliness. As a member of Tred Avon Yacht Club, I hope to speak for the entirety of our membership when I mention the many hundreds of yachtsmen who are routinely involved in the regattas we host annually. I mention, as one example, the Star World Championship Regatta hosted by our club in October 2018, when we drew 72 boats and crews from all over the United States, many teams from South America, and more than quite a few from Europe. The conditions during several days of this championship regatta were less than favorable (read, "pretty nasty"), and the assistance in maintaining an orderly spectator presence, not to mention the availability of safety rescue from boats that capsized notwitstanding the efforts of their world-class sailors, by USCG Oxford Station personnel were to say the least invaluable. We are dependent upon these fine service mambers for our safety. I and my fellow townspeople sincerely hope you will appreciate the number of Eastern Shore citizens, far, far beyond th0se of us who live here in Oxford, who agree with this sentiment, and will seriously reconsider the closure of this valuable, lifesaving resource.

Jan Greer
Captain, USMC, 1962-1966

Title: Comment Submitted by Alexis Kramer
Comment:
Please do not close the Coast Guard Station in Oxford, MD.
It is instrumental in maintaining safety on the waters on the Eastern Shore of Maryland.
If you close the Oxford Station, this would make the Annapolis Station on the  other side of the Bay the
closest station to provide aid in the Eastern Bay, Tred Avon and Choptank Rivers.  
I maintain a small motor boat at Ferry Point Marina in Trappe, MD.  My family (including four children) use it regularly.  It would be 
greatly concern me every time my children get underway, if the closest C.G. station is on the Western Shore.

Title: Comment Submitted by Susan Campbell
Comment: AS a marina/boatyard owner in Oxford, Maryland, the US Coast Guard station in Oxford is important.  Having them shut down would not be good for the community.   The Coast Guard assists in many endeavors throughout the community.

Title: Comment Submitted by Ian Fleming, The Oxford Business Association
Comment: The Oxford Business Association vigorously supports the retention of the Oxford Coastguard Station on the grounds of safety of recreational and commercial boaters.

Title: Comment Submitted by The Robert Morris Inn
Comment: The Robert Morris Inn vigorously supports the retention of the Oxford Coastguard Station on the grounds of safety of recreational and commercial boaters.

Title: Comment Submitted by Karen Livingston
Comment: Please do not take our Oxford Coasties from us.

Title: Comment Submitted by WIlliam Marquess
Comment: Closing the Oxford Station may be the same thing as pealing dollars from public health funds under the guise of we don't need it only to find out later that you do need it and the results of your earlier actions leads to the people you are sworn to protect dying from your neglect.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: The Thomson family and extended families are avid boaters living near and boating frequently in the Tred Avon, Choptank, and many numerous creeks.  We strongly oppose the closure of the USCG station in Oxford for obvious reasons

Title: Comment Submitted by Rita Hill
Comment: Please reconsider keeping the US Coast Guard Station at Oxford, Maryland active. This is pertinent for the safety of many boaters in and around the Tred Avon River, Choptank River and the Lower Chesapeake Bay.

Title: Comment Submitted by Richard Leggett
Comment:
I am writing in strong opposition to USCG-2020-0042, Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations, proposing the consolidation of U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford located in Oxford, Maryland ("Station Oxford").  As I will explain below, the closing of Station Oxford would have a great impact on the Eastern Shore.  I appreciate the opportunity to submit comment in opposition to USCG-2020-0042 and hope that you recognize the impact that consolidating Station Oxford would have on the Town of Oxford and the Eastern Shore. 

I strongly oppose USCG-2020-0042 as I believe the closing of Station Oxford would be detrimental to the safety of boaters on the Eastern Shore.  Station Oxford plays a pivotal role in the safety of boaters along the waterways from northern Tilghman Island to the Little Choptank River on the eastern side of the Chesapeake Bay, and also over to Chesapeake Beach and south to Calvert Cliffs on the western side.  Many jurisdictions within this area do not have fire or police departments with boats capable of responding to an emergency on the water, leaving Station Oxford and the Department of Natural Resources, which is oftentimes otherwise occupied with enforcement activities.  The fire departments that have boats capable of responding to emergencies lack the manpower to operate the boats 24 hours a day and the qualified personnel to make water rescues.  

  Station Oxford provides timely response to any emergency on the water.  If Station Oxford is closed, the next closest station to most of the areas Station Oxford serves is Station Annapolis.  This is a major concern.  Station Annapolis is 32 nautical miles from Oxford, 25 nautical miles from St. Michaels, 45 nautical miles from Solomons, 80 nautical miles from Crisfield, and 48 nautical miles from Cambridge.  In addition to the distance, Station Annapolis requires the responding crew to travel across the entire Chesapeake Bay, which can be treacherous at times and require slower boat speeds, resulting in an increased response time. 

A nearly two-hour response time is concerning.  It is even more concerning when you consider that hypothermia can set in within 45 minutes and the fact that the Eastern Shore is known for waterfowl hunting during the winter months.  Hunters routinely take out large groups on guided boat hunts during the winter.  If a guided tour experienced an emergency on the water, the response time would be crucial to the group's survival.  Relying on a boat from Annapolis, in poor winter weather, could easily result in tragedy.  

	The distance from Station Annapolis to areas that Station Oxford serves is a huge concern for boater safety.   Station Oxford plays a significant role in educating the public on boater safety.  Without the education aspect that Station Oxford offers, the risk to our marine community will greatly increase.  The crew at Station Oxford focuses on maritime safety and protecting the local communities.  The crew spends a lot of time during prime boating season educating boaters by boarding their boat to accomplish that mission.  I am doubtful that the Eastern Shore could expect the same level of presence by Station Annapolis.  If the consolidation occurred, Station Annapolis would be responsible for a much larger area causing their time spent educating boaters to decrease.  It is not realistic to think that a crew from Station Annapolis could be as present on the Eastern Shore as the Station Oxford crew. 

Station Oxford is pivotal in providing the necessary boater education on the water.  The Department of Natural Resources does not have the time to board boats to provide boater safety education.  Without boater education, the number of accidents and emergencies on the water is certain to rise and there will not be a local Coast Guard to respond.  Ultimately, the closure of Station Oxford will cause an increase of emergencies and decreased response time, which is detrimental to the public health and safety. 

	Therefore, I believe Station Oxford is necessary for the protection of the health and safety of boaters in the area it serves.  A replacement of Station Oxford by Station Annapolis will not adequately protect our boaters and I am concerned it will result in an increase of accidents with more detrimental results due to the prolonged response time.  Station Oxford is necessary to provide security of the public health and safety and emergency assistance.
	Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Comment Submitted by Chris Mckelvy
Comment:
Chris McKelvy
Oxford Market
203 S. Morris St
Oxford Md 21654

April 10, 2020
Re: [Docket Number USCG-2020-0042]

Rear Admiral Sibley
USCG
c/o regulations.gov

Dear Admiral Sibley

         In regards to the closing of the Oxford USCG Station I think it would be a mistake to close the station.
The waters around the station are very heavily used by commercial and recreational boaters alike. With the closing
of the oxford station the response times may have devastating consequences as the closest station would be
25 miles away in Annapolis. .
         I have lived in Oxford and surrounding area for most of my life and have boating recreationally since the early
1970's.I ask that you reconsider the closing of the Oxford Station for the safety of boaters in the area.


         Thank you
          Chris Mckelvy
          Owner: Oxford Market

Title: Comment Submitted by Todd Taylor
Comment:
April 10, 2020
Re: USCG Oxford Station Closure; Docket Number USCG-2020-0042


Dear Admiral Sibley,

I am a professional mariner and writing to comment on the USCG consideration of closure / consolidation of the Oxford, MD boat station.  While it is certainly true that modern navigation, communication and the performance (speed) of USCG assets has greatly reduced response time, and that general vessel reliability and increased safety standards has reduced incoming calls, it also remains true that accidents and emergencies happen.  No degree of consolidation of boating stations can replace the fast response of a NEARBY and prepared USCG crew.
The mid bay region of the Chesapeake is an expansive body of water.  As you know, the nearest USCG boat stations to Oxford are Crisfield and Annapolis.   Emergencies on the water do not always happen during benign conditions.  No matter how fast and capable a USCG vessel is, it is only as fast as conditions allow.    Responding to an emergency in the mid bay from Annapolis or Crisfield during challenging conditions would be slowed and potentially put lives at risk.
Although Oxford station may not receive as many calls as other regions, they are prepared and standing by....as they should be.  As a professional mariner I am opposed to the closure of the Oxford boat station.

Title: Comment Submitted by Millicent Pitts
Comment: We are residents and recreational boaters out of Cambridge,MD on the Choptank River and associated waterways like the Tred Avon River.   A shut down of the Oxford MD USCG Station puts our boating community in a position of significant hardship if we have to rely on the Annapolis Station on the other side of the Chesapeake Bay.  Our lives and safety will be at greater risk when time is critical.  We live in an area with significant recreational and commercial boats and a long history of living our lives in our waterways.   DO NOT close the Oxford MD Station which is part of the fabric of the Middle Eastern Shore community.

Title: Comment Submitted by Frederick Miller
Comment: I am opposed to the closing of the Oxford,MD U. S. Coast Guard Station. There is too much traffic on the Middle Eastern Bay and it's tributaries and too distant to be serviced by the Annapolis station. With the volume of commercial fishing, crabbing and oystering and the recreational boating on the bay, rivers and creeks, the response time from the Annapolis station will not be adequate and could cost lives of those on the water. The recent canoeing accident involving Bobby Kennedy's granddaughter is an example of the type of dangers the people on the water face. The USCG needs to have the resources to respond to these emergencies in a timely fashion.

Title: Comment Submitted by Dale Branch
Comment:
As a recreational boater on the Easernshore of MD, I strongly objectify the closure of the Oxford MD USCG station.
If it closes, the nearest station is in Annapolis MD,  nearly 2 hour boat ride away with a searchable territory of unmanageable amounts of water and shorelines.  
Oxford USCG is a close and reliable source of help and rescue in times of need to Eastern Shore boaters and watermen.

Title: Comment Submitted by Ronald Ensminger
Comment:
I am a 26-year retired Navy Captain and a recreational boater my entire life. We live on Trippe Creek in Easton, Maryland just off the Tred Avon River.

If you close the USCG station at Oxford, Maryland, the nearest USCG station to provide aid for the Eastern Bay, the Choptank and Tred Avon and their tributary waters will be in Annapolis. 

This closure will be a serious mistake and pose a life-threatening situation for all boaters in these waters. As you may well know, the Bay and its rivers and tributaries can become a quite serious threat to mariners in very short notice. 

Therefore, my strong recommendation is to reconsider and maintain a USCG station in Oxford, Maryland. 

Ron Ensminger

Title: Comment Submitted by David Bourdon
Comment:
Having served some 39 years and 6 months in the US Coast Guard Auxiliary, after serving 20 years as an US Air Force Officer
 and 21 years in Civil Service in Washington, DC, I must advise against closing USCG Station Oxford, MD. This station is
vital to the service of the American Boating Public on the Maryland Eastern Shore, Eastern Bay, Tred Avon and Choptank 
Rivers. Considering it would take Station Annapolis, the closest CG Station, some 2 hours to arrive at an emergency site, lose 
of life could occure. Station Oxford is strategically located to respond in a boating emergency in their Area of Operstion. The loss
of this vital asset jeprodizes the mission of the US Coast Guard and the lives of countless boaters on the Chesapeake Bay of
Maryland.

David A. Bourdon ( Capt. USAF Ret.) and USCGA Ret.

Title: Comment Submitted by Andy McConnell
Comment: Station Oxford is essential on the shore and should remain operational

Title: Comment Submitted by Ray Stevens
Comment: See attached file(s)
