Without the education aspect that Station Oxford offers, the risk to our marine community will greatly increase.  The crew at Station Oxford focuses on maritime safety and protecting the local communities.  The crew spends a lot of time during prime boating season educating boaters by boarding their boat to accomplish that mission.  I am doubtful that the Eastern Shore could expect the same level of presence by Station Annapolis.  If the consolidation occurred, Station Annapolis would be responsible for a much larger area causing their time spent educating boaters to decrease.  It is not realistic to think that a crew from Station Annapolis could be as present on the Eastern Shore as the Station Oxford crew. 

Station Oxford is pivotal in providing the necessary boater education on the water.  The Department of Natural Resources does not have the time to board boats to provide boater safety education.  Without boater education, the number of accidents and emergencies on the water is certain to rise and there will not be a local Coast Guard to respond.  Ultimately, the closure of Station Oxford will cause an increase of emergencies and decreased response time, which is detrimental to the public health and safety. 

	Therefore, I believe Station Oxford is necessary for the protection of the health and safety of boaters in the area it serves.  A replacement of Station Oxford by Station Annapolis will not adequately protect our boaters and I am concerned it will result in an increase of accidents with more detrimental results due to the prolonged response time.  Station Oxford is necessary to provide security of the public health and safety and emergency assistance.
	Thank you for your consideration.  


         James L. Robfogel,
         Boat Owner

Title: Comment Submitted by James B. Deerin
Comment:
Matthew W. Sibley, Rear Admiral
U.S. Coast Guard
Assistant Commandant for Capability

Re: OPPOSE - USCG-2020-0042

Admiral Sibley,

I am writing in strong opposition to USCG-2020-0042, Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations, proposing the consolidation of U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford located in Oxford, Maryland ("Station Oxford").  As I will explain below, the closing of Station Oxford would have a great impact on the Eastern Shore.  I appreciate the opportunity to submit comment in opposition to USCG-2020-0042 and hope that you recognize the impact that consolidating Station Oxford would have on the Town of Oxford and the Eastern Shore. 

I have called Oxford my full time home since 2006. However, my father purchased the home that I now own in 1963, and my wife, three sons and I have been coming to Oxford for over 50 years. During those years I have owned a number of boats and have enjoyed boating on the Tred Avon and Choptank Rivers and the Chesapeake Bay. Having the Oxford Coast Guard Station has been a source of comfort knowing that help was nearby.

I strongly oppose USCG-2020-0042 as I believe the closing of Station Oxford would be detrimental to the safety of boaters on the Eastern Shore.  Station Oxford plays a pivotal role in the safety of boaters along the waterways from northern Tilghman Island to the Little Choptank River on the eastern side of the Chesapeake Bay, and also over to Chesapeake Beach and south to Calvert Cliffs on the western side.  Many jurisdictions within this area do not have fire or police departments with boats capable of responding to an emergency on the water, leaving Station Oxford and the Department of Natural Resources, which is oftentimes otherwise occupied with enforcement activities.  The fire departments that have boats capable of responding to emergencies lack the manpower to operate the boats 24 hours a day and the qualified personnel to make water rescues.  

  Station Oxford provides timely response to any emergency on the water.  If Station Oxford is closed, the next closest station to most of the areas Station Oxford serves is Station Annapolis.  This is a major concern.  Station Annapolis is 32 nautical miles from Oxford, 25 nautical miles from St. Michaels, 45 nautical miles from Solomons, 80 nautical miles from Crisfield, and 48 nautical miles from Cambridge.  In addition to the distance, Station Annapolis requires the responding crew to travel across the entire Chesapeake Bay, which can be treacherous at times and require slower boat speeds, resulting in an increased response time. 

A nearly two-hour response time is concerning.  It is even more concerning when you consider that hypothermia can set in within 45 minutes and the fact that the Eastern Shore is known for waterfowl hunting during the winter months.  Hunters routinely take out large groups on guided boat hunts during the winter.  If a guided tour experienced an emergency on the water, the response time would be crucial to the group's survival.  Relying on a boat from Annapolis, in poor winter weather, could easily result in tragedy.  

	The distance from Station Annapolis to areas that Station Oxford serves is a huge concern for boater safety.   Station Oxford plays a significant role in educating the public on boater safety.  Without the education aspect that Station Oxford offers, the risk to our marine community will greatly increase.  The crew at Station Oxford focuses on maritime safety and protecting the local communities.  The crew spends a lot of time during prime boating season educating boaters by boarding their boat to accomplish that mission.  I am doubtful that the Eastern Shore could expect the same level of presence by Station Annapolis.  If the consolidation occurred, Station Annapolis would be responsible for a much larger area causing their time spent educating boaters to decrease.  It is not realistic to think that a crew from Station Annapolis could be as present on the Eastern Shore as the Station Oxford crew. 

Station Oxford is pivotal in providing the necessary boater education on the water.  The Department of Natural Resources does not have the time to board boats to provide boater safety education.  Without boater education, the number of accidents and emergencies on the water is certain to rise and there will not be a local Coast Guard to respond.

	Therefore, I believe Station Oxford is necessary for the protection of the health and safety of boaters in the area it serves.  A replacement of Station Oxford by Station Annapolis will not adequately protect our boaters and I am concerned it will result in an increase of accidents with more detrimental results due to the prolonged response time.  Station Oxford is necessary to provide security of the public health and safety and emergency assistance.

	Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Comment Submitted by Sewell "Toby" Frey
Comment:
SEWELL "TOBY"  FREY                  103 THIRD ST.                OXFORD, MD 21654                  410-725-1781


Matthew W. Sibley,
Rear Admiral, U.S. Coast Guard,
Assistant Commandant for Capability.
[FR Doc. 2020-03079 Filed: 2/13/2020 8:45 am; Publication Date: 2/14/2020]								

Ref: DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY
Coast Guard
[Docket Number USCG-2020-0042]
Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations
AGENCY: Coast Guard, DHS.
ACTION: Request for comments.

Admiral Sibley,                            				4/10/2020

I am writing to oppose the closing of Coast Guard Station Oxford in 2021 or any time in the future.  

Some Chesapeake Bay/Choptank River figures:

Choptank River:
       Largest River Solely in Maryland on the Chesapeake Bay
       Cambridge,  Maryland's Second Deep Water Port
       Choptank River is one of the major areas for Oyster Harvest in the                                      
             Winter months (emergency requires short response times)       

Coast Guard:  Desired Response time 30-45 minutes
Choptank Light located approx 1 mile West from Coast Guard Sta Oxford

Two Closet CG stations to Choptank River:

CG STA Solomon's:  
       Approx 37 miles to Choptank Light  
        (1.5 miles is in a wake restricted zone)
        Estimated Response times to Choptank Light
               Winds <10kts.....1.5 hrs
                Winds >10k-15 kts.....3-4 Hrs 

CG STA Annapolis:
        Approx 31 Miles to Choptank Light
         (1.3 Miles,  cannot determine if no wake zone)
         Estimated Response times to Choptank Light 
                Winds <10kts.....1- 1.5 hrs
                Winds >10k-15 kts.....2-3 Hrs  

Coast Guard Boats can operate at speeds into the 40 knot range, usually run at 30 knots...I used 30kts calm and less in high wind conditions, thinking that most emergencies happen in bad WX conditions.

My research shows that closing Oxford Station, Oxford Maryland is not a viable option!

If cost cutting is the point, I suggest first addressing the excess stations in a 15km radius in the Norfolk Area.

Any questions, Please call ....410-725-1781

Sincerely,
 

Sewell L. Frey
Major USAF (ret)
Active Boater, Choptank River 65+ yrs

Title: Comment Submitted by William S. Dudley
Comment:
As a life-long sailor and a veteran of 35 years of boating on Chesapeake Bay, I am convinced that closing the USCG station at Oxford, MD, is an unwise proposal. The number of boaters on the Bay has increased significantly over time. In 1990, there was a total 190,436 registered and documented boats on Maryland waters, including trailered power boats, in-water power boats, and sailboats.By 2004, there were 209,706 boats of all types. Of the latter, 90% were power boats, including personal water craft (jet skis). Not all of these boats were in use on the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries; some were on our few large lakes. But probably 80 % are bay boats. 

When you consider the number of possible boating accidents, collisions, capsizings, and engine fires that can occur anytime, anywhere, on the bay, a reduction of our USCG stations and cutters that play such a large role in life-saving rescues and policing maritime boating activity seems an ill-advised policy. The two USCG boat stations in the Mid-Bay area are located near Thomas Point and Oxford, but they have a huge area two cover when you consider the number of rivers flowing into the bay from opposite shores from Baltimore south to Solomons on the Patuxent . Another consideration must be the virtually uncountable number of canoe and kayak enthusiasts who often venture out into unsafe waters from anywhere along the shoreline, you have to factor-in the dangerous situations that can occur on almost daily basis during our long boating season.  

It is essential to retain and maintain the USCG stations that we do have. Their personnel do a wonderful job responding to maritime emergencies of all types that occur on Chesapeake Bay. To reduce the number of stations only increases the area and number of emergency calls for which they will be responsible and may cost additional boaters' lives because of longer response times. Do the right thing and reject the proposal to reduce and consolidate USCG Boat Stations.   William S. Dudley, Easton, MD.

Title: Comment Submitted by Clay Stamp
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by Jeanne Collinson
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by John Gallagher
Comment:
I am strongly against the closure of USCG Station Oxford, the area this station covers includes a vibrant winter time commercial fishery, including: oystering, clamming and fin fish netting. The response time from the neighboring USCG Stations during strong winter weather will be over two hours away, and many local rescue resources do maintain presence in the winter.
Also, it should be noted that there is a Nuclear Power Plant, and LNG Dock which Oxford is the closest location by water.

If you are not firing the crew, getting rid of the boats, then the money that is being saved, by shutting a owned building on a federal property is minuscule. 

In light of the recent Covid-19, it seems to me that keeping  USCG Stations spread apart, especially to the Eastern Shore with a
rural population makes sense to be able to protect our forces.

This plan puts lives in danger, does not save money, and decreases homeland security.

Title: Comment Submitted by C. A. Boyd
Comment:
April 14, 2020

Matthew W. Sibley, Rear Admiral
U.S. Coast Guard
Assistant Commandant for Capability

	Re: Oppose-USCG-2020-0042

Dear Admiral Sibley,

	It is understandable that when confronted with limited resources, as we recognize that the Coast Guard is making efforts to cut costs wherever possible to ensure that the Coast Guard continues to meet its mission in the best manner possible.  But certain cuts, including the elimination of the Oxford Coast Guard station, do harm to the ability of the Guard to protect the lives of the people you serve.

	As we are learning from the Covid-19 pandemic, the costs in lives and to our economy are magnified greatly because we failed to properly maintain a government infrastructure designed to mitigate a relatively small but highly impactful number of threats.

The rationale for closing Oxford station is based, in part, on the assumption that there are other options available that can meet the needs of the Chesapeake boating community from recreational to the variety of commercial operations from fishing to ocean going traffic. 

 I do not believe that rationale is valid.

	Given that the nearest CG station is more than 30 miles away as well as across the bay, the closure of the Oxford Station will mean that there are no viable options for a reasonable response time to vessels and people in distress.   As you know, there are significant distances between Annapolis and St. Michaels (25 nm) Solomons (45nm), Crisfield (80nm) and Cambridge (48nm).    Consequently, there will be extended wait times for response that will sooner or later cause harm.  

	It also is now a reality that there are scenarios in which the Coast Guard could be forced to prioritize responses and proximity to an event will certainly be a factor in who gets needed assistance quickly and who may get none at all.  

	Perhaps the reduced ability of the Coast Guard to respond to those in need would be more tenable if there were other mechanisms in place that could step up to support the hundreds of vessels that cruise along the Eastern Shore.  But local communities have even more limited resources and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources has neither the appropriate vessels nor mission to provide the level of support that is so needed by the communities of the Chesapeake.

	In my more than 30 years of boating on the Eastern Seaboard from New York Harbor to the Florida Keys, I have needed assistance from the Coast Guard twice.  Once I happened to be one mile from Governor's Island in New York Harbor so the assistance was quite rapid and welcomed because it saved my vessel. The second time, 20 years later, was a fire in the Florida Keys and I happened to be almost equidistant between two stations creating a unique understanding of the importance of proximity.  Perhaps 10 miles one way or another would have made the difference between being able to salvage the boat or at it turned out having it become a total loss.   
	Fortunately, no lives were at stake during this emergency and while I did lose my boat in the fire, the education and support from the Coast Guard over the years helped me make sure that after I had done all I could do to combat the fire, I had the proper equipment and knowledge to safely get my wife and myself off of the boat. 

	I appreciate you taking the time to read my  opposition letter and I hope that you will remove Oxford from the list of stations to be closed because such a closure presents a significant opportunity for harm to the  property and people  who have been and should continue to be served by its presence.


Sincerely,



C. A. Boyd
700 S. Morris St. 
Oxford MD, 21654

Title: Comment Submitted by Russell Woolford
Comment:
To whom it may concern,
When I was notified of this consideration that was on the table, about the closing of the Oxford station I immediately felt
 concern for the safety of my family and other boaters who frequently boat in the area that would be affected by this closer.
Obviously the response time  for a boating emergence would be greatly lengthened by this change. As I'm sure you know that
 in a real boating emergence time is of the essence. Please consider the safety of all Marylanders who enjoy boating on the 
Choptank River.

Title: Comment Submitted by Sarah Harris
Comment:
The oxford md coastguard station is very important for the eastern shore of maryland. They are close for water emergencies and without it we would have to rely on a station on the other side of the bay.
 Please keep the oxford md coastguard station open.

Title: Comment Submitted by David Williams
Comment: This letter is regarding the proposed closing of the Coast Guard Station in Oxford Maryland.  My name is David Williams, I am a Captain on the Nathan of Dorchester, a Skipjack sailing out of Cambridge Md. Our location is twelve miles from Oxford and much further from Annapolis.  Although we do everything possible to have a safe experience for our passengers, if we have an issue in the future, we would not get a timely response from the Coast Guard Station in Annapolis due to the additional distance and the need to cross the Chesapeake Bay before even getting into the Choptank River.  I therefore do not support closing the Coast Guard Station in Oxford Md.  Thank you

Title: Comment Submitted by Susan Delean- Botkin
Comment:
The Oxford Station of the USCG is not redundant!  It is an important station in a waterfront community.  The USCG in Oxford is able to provide service to The Tred Avon, Choptank, Little Choptank, Chesapeake Bay and all smaller rivers and tributaries in the area.
Small pleasure boats, large tankers, sailing vessels and ocean going freighters are all plying the waters of the Oxford station's responsibility.  It is imperative that our area have a viable, present USCG station for the well being of our citizens.
You don't realize how much you need the Coast Guard until it's not there in an emergency.  We have too much traffic to risk losing the station.  We have too many boats on the water to risk losing the station.  We have too many lives at risk to lose the station.
Susan Delean-Botkin
Oxford, Md.

Title: Comment Submitted by Captain Ryan Leo, MM, AFNI
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by Sherrie Schuman
Comment:
As not only a recreational boater on the Easernshore of MD but also the mother of a waterman based out of Oxford MD, I am very concerned about the closure of the Oxford MD USCG station.  He is out in very rough water year round, often times not within close proximity to land or other boats.

If it closes, the nearest station is in Annapolis MD, nearly 2 hour boat ride away with a searchable territory of unmanageable amounts of water and shorelines.  Given those timelines with cold water, the results of slower response times could be deadly.   

Not to mention........Dorchester and Talbot Co have enormous amounts of shorelines.  As long as I can remember, we have heard boats running at night, suspicious boats in the area, and oddly,  drug dealers from the DC/Baltimore/Philly area seem to find their ways here.  Rumors have always abounded of drugs coming in via water through our area.  Regular patrols by the Coast Guard have probably limited that activity to some degree.  Eliminating these patrols and only offering limited police presence by DNR may open up more opportunity for illegal drugs to come through here and flow to the cities.

Oxford USCG is a close and reliable source of help and rescue in times of need to Eastern Shore boaters and watermen.  Please do not close this safety net for us.

Title: Comment Submitted by Leonard Gomella, MD
Comment: I am writing concerning the planned closure of the Oxford Coast Guard Station. As a boat owner on the Choptank River I and my entire family and our boating neighbors are very concerned about this decision. Leaving a major portion of the Eastern Shore commercial and recreational boating community without this safety resource is concerning. With this closure, emergency coverage would only leave Annapolis and Crisfield that are a significant distance away form our region. Please reconsider this decision for the safety of the boating community from a significant portion of the eastern Shore of Maryland.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I am favor of closing redundant bases.

Title: Comment Submitted by William Tyndall
Comment: As a USCG credentialed Master and commercial operator in the mid bay area including the Choptank River Area I oppose the closing of Oxford USCG station.  The fast response from a close station can save lives and vessels. The continued patrol of the local station vessels add safety for recreational boaters as well as commercial.  Please allow this station to remain operational.

Title: Comment Submitted by Robert F. Kelly, Ph.D
Comment: OPPOSE - USCG-2020-0042

Title: Comment Submitted by John Fairhall and Elaine Eff
Comment:
My wife and I are Oxford residents STRONGLY opposed to the closing of Station Oxford, which would result from USCG-2020--0042, consolidation of redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations. This station is not redundant, as it plays a key role in assuring the safety of boaters from northern Tilghman Island to the Little Choptank River on the eastern side of the Chesapeake Bay, and over to Chesapeake Beach and south to Calvert Cliffs on the western side. Closing this station would put us under the jurisdiction of Station Annapolis -- a whopping 32 nautical miles from Oxford and 25 miles from St. Michaels, for example. A nearly two-hour response time would endanger the lives of people whose boats sink or are or disabled, particularly in colder seasons when hypothermia would set in long before a rescue craft could arrive. Of course, the Oxford Station provides other services as well, notably boater education.
I could go on, but you get the point.
Thank you for considering our comments.
John Fairhall and Elaine Eff
108 W. Pier St.
Oxford, MD 21654
202-446-7219

Title: Comment Submitted by Jennifer Williams
Comment: Maryland's Eastern Shore needs the USCG station in Oxford. Just a little over a year ago there was a fatal drowning during the Oxford sailboat races. Keep the Oxford station.

Title: Comment Submitted by Kathy Laughlin
Comment:
I urgently request that the Coast Guard strongly reconsider closing Coast Guard Station Oxford.  This station is essential to commercial & recreational mariners on the Eastern Shore.  With our many commercial fisherman & Oxford Ferry the need for a rapid response station in the area is essential to the lives & livelihood of the mariners in the area.  This is not a redundant service it is the sole station on the mid eastern shore of Maryland.  Thank you for your time & attention.  

Kathy Laughlin
USCG Master Mariner

Title: Comment Submitted by Lee Walker
Comment: Closing the Oxford, MD Coast Guard station would seriously impact the thousands of people from many states who keep their boats here for pleasure and local livelihoods that provide food for the East Coast and farther into the United States.  It would seem that saving lives and helping people needs prompt action, not from 20+ miles away.  The waterways here are vast and complex and knowledge of this is essential.

Title: Comment Submitted by Donna Hasslinger
Comment:
Closure of the USCG station in Oxford, MD will negatively impact those of us who live off the Tred Avon River,  Choptank River and surrounding waterways. 
We certainly would not want to wait for assistance from the Coast Guard in Annapolis.  It is too far away. 

The USCG station in Oxford must remain open. 

Donna Hasslinger
Easton, MD

Title: Comment Submitted by Eva Smorzaniuk
Comment: I am writing to advocate for the continued operation of the USCG station at Oxford, MD.  This is the only station on the bay side of the Eastern Shore of Maryland, ensuring safety for both recreational and commercial boaters on the Choptank, Trend Avon, and Eastern Bay.  Closing it would imply significant delay in responding to emergencies, therefore, potentially endangering lives.  The station has become a valued part of the community in Oxford as well.  Perhaps thought should be given to enlarging the station and scope of responsibility, given its more  central location in the Bay

Title: Comment Submitted by Richard Merrill
Comment: I'd really like to respectfully object to the closing of the Oxford Station.  I've never had a problem that required the CG, but I was always happy to see them out on the water with me.  I have had the privliege of meeting the Oxford personnel on the water (safety inspection) and in Oxford during Oxford Days parade.  A fine group of young people doing a great job.  On the serious subject of safety, I can't imagine having the nearest crew all the way over in Annapolis.   Please reconsider.

Title: Comment Submitted by Richard Wagner
Comment: I oppose closing the USCG Oxford Station, at Oxford, MD. There would be serious reductions in boating safety with such a closure. Annapolis Station is too far away for sufficiently rapid emergency response, and is on the other side of Chesapeake Bay, which can sometimes be treacherous enough to further slow response time.  These concerns apply not only to Oxford but to the entire boating area in and near the Choptank River.

Title: Comment Submitted by Barbara Denton
Comment:
We live in Talbot County on the Eastern Shore of Maryland.  We have more coastline than any other County in Maryland.  While this is excellent for boaters it presents a problem for law enforcement.  It is very easy to smuggle drugs and other contraband to piers in our County.  Removing the Coast Guard station currently in Oxford, MD endangers the boaters on the Eastern Shore as well as removes law enforcement to deal with contraband and illegal drug distribution.

There are many amateur boaters who end up requiring the services of the Coast Guard due to their inexperience.  Depending on the Annapolis station to deal with this will endanger their lives as time is a factor in many cases.  The Coast Guard Station at Oxford is not redundant and should be kept open.

Title: Comment Submitted by William Pugh
Comment: We feel the Oxford Coast Guard Station is essential. Please keep it open.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jim and Danuta Schuessler
Comment:
I'd like to comment on the possible closing of Station Oxford. As stated in other comments Station Annapolis is a ways away.  The response time to our area waters could be hours, especially in bad weather on the Bay. During the boating season the Station Oxford crew has a significant presence on the water being involved in safety checks. That in itself I feel is a very important duty in keeping our area boaters safe along with simply their presence on the water. As boaters my wife and I are out on most weekends if weather permits. We greatly appreciate the crew of Station Oxford!
Sincerely,
Jim and Danuta Schuessler

The crew spends a lot of time during prime boating season educating boaters by boarding their boat to accomplish that mission.  I am doubtful that the Eastern Shore could expect the same level of presence by Station Annapolis.  If the consolidation occurred, Station Annapolis would be responsible for a much larger area causing their time spent educating boaters to decrease.  It is not realistic to think that a crew from Station Annapolis could be as present on the Eastern Shore as the Station Oxford crew.
	
	Therefore, I believe Station Oxford is necessary for the protection of the health and safety of boaters in the area it serves.  A replacement of Station Oxford by Station Annapolis will not adequately protect all boaters and I am concerned it will result in an increase of accidents with more detrimental results due to the prolonged response time.  Station Oxford is necessary to provide security of the public health and safety and emergency assistance.
	Thank you for your consideration. 

Sincerely,

John S. Tochko

Title: Comment Submitted by Brooke Myers
Comment:
My husband responded to the first call for comments some weeks ago.  He stated that we, as legal residents of the Town of Oxford, strongly oppose the closing of the USCG facility at Oxford.  Among the reasons stated included 1) the Tred Avon area is a congested boating thoroughfare needing constant patrolling, especially due to the large and growing number of rental boats and jet skis; 2) growing heavy 24-hour commercial traffic to and from Easton Point, 3) the cove (Terrapin Cove) surrounding the Marine Lab and USCG facility is a long-time Federally designated federal sanctuary requiring ultimate federal protection; 4) the aforsaid Terrapin Cove is both the only Maryland Terrapin nesting site on the fringes of Oxford; 5) the aforesaid Terrapin Cove is also the location of an ongoing oyster restoration program by Maryland, the USG, and private partnership, such as the CBM, 6) and the area is subject to expensive crabbing in season that requires helping DNR's meager resources to allow lawful harvesting.  There is also the fact that the USCG budget helps to defray the costs of maintaining the dock and other facilities also used by NOAA for federal purposes.  Removing the USCG activities would jeopardize the NOAA Lab and its many marine protection and conservation programs.

Our family owns a home directly on the center of Terrapin Cove.  For 20 years we have observed the activities of the USGG on the Tread Avon River, and beyond.  We know firsthand how constructive a role the USCG plays in the policing and environmental protection of that watershed.  Myself and our two sons, one of whom interned in the NOAA marine mammals protection program some years ago, strongly support maintaining the USCG presence at the Oxford Marine Laboratory.

Sincerely,

Brooke Myers
Elliott Myers
Chris Myers

The removal of the USCG presence at the Oxford marine Lab would be penny-wise and pound foolish.

Title: Comment Submitted by Brad Hill
Comment:
Please leave the Oxford coast guard station open. We rely on their proximity and support here in the Tred Avon area. We had virtually no opportunity to speak to this either

Annapolis is a long way from this area and, therefore, would be very hard to be responsive from.

Title: Comment Submitted by Douglas Abbott, Tred Avon Yacht Club
Comment: See attachment

Title: Comment Submitted by Sarah Lawrence
Comment: Station Oxford is not redundant. The assets protect the lives of boaters on the Chesapeake Bay, focusing on the Eastern Shore. Closing the Oxford station leaves the eastern shore of Maryland exposed with no USCG coverage on the Choptank and other important rivers and tributaries that are so important to our local watermen and boaters. Please let us remember that even though there is a temporary mandate restricting recreational boating, there are still many people fishing, crabbing and making their life on the water.  Essential businesses are also still working on the Bay, in and around the Eastern Shore and all of the waterways that Station Oxford services. For our local men, women and children, keep Oxford open!

Title: Comment Submitted by Sarah Ramsey
Comment:
See attached file(s)
I have attached a letter in opposition to the possible closure of Coast Guard Station Oxford , Oxford MD

Title: Comment Submitted by Elizabeth Fisher
Comment: I am writing to support the Coast Guard station in Oxford, MD. From information that has been posted, I understand that our area will be in a precarious position in the event of a boating accident in inclement weather, as boats stationed on the Western Shore will not be able to make the crossing quickly enough. As a recreational boater and fishing enthusiast, it is comforting to know that the Coast Guard is close by. Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Comment Submitted by Mitch & Janel Parke
Comment: We object to the closing of the USCG station in Oxford, MD for all the reasons already stated. We live in Cambridge...the Choptank and it's tributaries encompass a vast area. Annapolis is a long way in an emergency! We have interacted with the USCG station in Oxford in several non-emergency situations. They were highly professional, skilled and are necessary to the local boating communities, whether commercial or recreational.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I respectfully request that Coast Guard Station Oxford not be consolidated with Annapolis.  With the nearest Coast Guard station in Annapolis response time in urgent and emergent situations becomes far too long.  Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jack Batty
Comment:
As former boaters and residents of Easton, we strongly protest any decision to close the Oxford Coast Guard Station. The Eastern Shore ia a prime boating destination for recreational boaters from the Western side of the Bay. Eliminating this station in the mid-shore area is a huge threat to safety of all mariners-- commercial as well aw recreational. The remaining station in Annapolis is 32 nautical miles from Oxford and even further from the Choptank and Dorchester County. Please say "no" to this unwise, pound foolish proposal. Thank you.

Carolyn and Jack Batty
28836 Jasper Lane
Easton, MD 21601

Title: Comment Submitted by Trevor Hammon
Comment: This comment is regarding the potential vlosure of the USCG Oxford station. Im a lic. capt./ waterman that has spent close to 40 yrs working the mid bay area. I also run a Towboatus boat in the area n have for many years. This closing of the Oxford station would be ridiculous. This station is not redundant at all. It covers a huge area from Hoppers Is northward to Kent Island and from Choptank river to Chesapeake Beach n South towards Breezy Point. If closed, USCG response time to these areas either from Annapolis or Solomon's Is would be....well most likely a recovery by the time they get there! A large percentage of calls are in adverse conditions and at night. The Oxford station is a great central point to have a great response time in a large portion of the mid Chesapeake Bay! A grave mistake to close this station!!

Title: Comment Submitted by Maureen Smith
Comment:
As a recreational boater, I oppose the closing of the US Coast Guard Station Oxford, Oxford, MD.  I believe the Oxford Station is not redundant.  The station is in a central location for the safety of recreational and commercial boaters, hunters  along the middle eastern Bay, Choptank and Little Choptank Rivers and the many smaller rivers, creeks and tributaries. It is our safety net as the Annapolis USCG station is far enough way to not be effective in an emergency. 
     I am a crew member and involved in training new crew on the Nathan of Dorchester.  A US Coast Guard regulated educational skipjack vessel that takes hundreds of passengers each season for educational sails on the Choptank River.  It is very reassuring knowing the Oxford Station is nearby in the event of an emergency. 
     In addition, it is my understanding that In the town of Oxford, MD the station sits alongside the NOAA and DNR offices where it provided support of there services during the three month government shut down in 2018.

Title: Comment Submitted by Frank Wiese
Comment: I object to the closing of the USCG station in Oxford, MD. Oxford and the towns around it which are all served by this station are generating significant boating traffic which should be supported by a local station. The response time from Annapolis exceeds reasonable response time in cases of emergency. Thank you.

Title: Comment Submitted by William Boos, Commissioners of St. Michaels
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by Patrick Firth
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern:

I am a citizen of Talbot County, Maryland and I strongly object to the closing of the U.S. Coast Guard station in Oxford, MD. This is a very unwise, unsafe, and potentially disastrous policy decision that will undoubtedly and unnecessarily put lives at risk.

Station Oxford plays a pivotal role in the safety of boaters along the waterways from northern Tilghman Island to the Little Choptank River on the eastern side of the Chesapeake Bay, and also over to Chesapeake Beach and south to Calvert Cliffs on the western side. If Station Oxford is closed, the next closest station is Station Annapolis. Not only is Station Annapolis 32 nautical miles from Oxford, it also requires the travel across the entire Chesapeake Bay, which can be treacherous at times and require slower boat speeds, increasing the response time. In fact, some locations Station Oxford protects are over two hours away from Station Annapolis. We should not have to explain to the U.S. Coast Guard that every second counts in maritime rescues.

Many jurisdictions within this area do not have fire or police departments with boats capable of responding to an emergency on the water, leaving Station Oxford and the Department of Natural Resources, which is oftentimes otherwise occupied with enforcement activities. The jurisdictions with fire departments that do have boats capable of responding to emergencies lack the manpower to operate the boats 24 hours a day and also lack the qualified personnel to make water rescues.

I echo the concerns of the Town of Oxford in this concerning matter. Although emergency response is the largest benefit Station Oxford brings to the community, it contributes much more. Station Oxford plays a significant role in educating the public on boater safety. We strongly feel that without the education aspect that Station Oxford offers, the risk to our marine community will greatly increase. The crew at Station Oxford focuses on maritime safety and protecting the local communities. The crew spends a lot of time during prime boating season educating boaters by boarding their boat to accomplish that mission.

As an example, over Memorial Day weekend in 2019, Station Oxford conducted 44 recreational boater safety boardings to promote the message of boating safety. The Coast Guard is the only agency that provides the necessary boater education. The Department of Natural Resources does not have the time to board boats for the sole purpose of providing boater safety education. We believe that the education Station Oxford provides directly correlates to the limited number of emergencies on the water. Without the education, the number of accidents and emergencies on the water will likely increase and there will not be a local Coast Guard to respond.

Ultimately, the closure of Station Oxford will cause an increase of emergencies and decreased response time, which is detrimental to the public health and safety.

Aside from the safety Station Oxford provides on the water, it also provides security to the area where it is located. Station Oxford shares a campus with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration ("NOAA") and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources ("DNR") at the end of South Morris Street called the "Cooperative Oxford Laboratory." Unlike NOAA and DNR, Station Oxford is manned 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. During major weather events and similar emergencies, Station Oxford monitors the NOAA lab and DNR site and provides updates to the employees that work at both locations so that they may respond to the location if an emergency arises.

A reckless decision here puts lives at risk. Station Oxford is a critical piece of Oxford's, and the entire Eastern Shore of Maryland's, infrastructure and I implore you to look elsewhere for additional funding resources. Thank you for your consideration of my opposition to the shuttering of Station Oxford.

Title: Comment Submitted by David Bruce
Comment: I support USCG Station Oxford Maryland. Please do not consolidate. For safety and security Choptank River needs CG presence.

Title: Comment Submitted by Heath Schuman
Comment: I have been boating/fishing on the choptank river with my family for 30 years and now my son is a commercial waterman running his own boat out of Oxford.   Having the coast guard in Oxford in case of a emergency is comforting especially in winter months.  I respectfully do not agree with closing this station.

Title: Comment Submitted by Elizabeth K. Dawkins
Comment: Please do not do this !  We need more not fewer Coast Guard Stations !  Look at their Record ! Saving Lives ,Stopping Human Traffic sellers, Stopping Drugs from entering our Country , Cyber Security intervention ? , and So much More that we never hear about .

Title: Comment Submitted by Roger Bollman
Comment: I would like to protest the possible closing of the Oxford Maryland station. It is vital to the marine safety of the Choptank River and the mid bay.

Title: Comment Submitted by Ed Sullivan, Eastern Shore Council of the US Navy League
Organization Name: Eastern Shore Council of the US Navy League
Comment:
I recognize that this request for comment is based on a budget decision that looms for the future of many USCG Stations, but it is so much more about safety and the perception of safety. It is a well known and appropriate allegory that perception is reality, and safety is paramount. The Chesapeake Bay has long been recognized as a unique environment with its own sub-climate, geography, and inherent marine challenges. The Port of Baltimore is now recognized as the busiest port on the East Coast, the Bay Bridge brings interesting and challenging dynamics to the mid bay almost every day, and just a bit further south is the NATC Patuxent River complex that uses the airspace over the bay as well as surface and subsurface areas for naval aviation flight and weapons testing with those associated perils. Distance measuring between USCG stations to approximate a area of SAR coverage does not appear to be reasonable given the intricate geography of the bay and its tributaries. Annapolis is a well known mecca for sailing and boating, but the eastern shore is just as popular but more spread out with more diverse and obscure niches of maritime recreation and commerce. USCG STA OXFORD is intrinsically familiar with its area of operation and provides education, oversight, and safety to the citizens of the eastern shore of Maryland that has become reality! 

Ed Sullivan
President Eastern Shore Council of the US Navy League

Title: Comment Submitted by Kristen L. Greenaway, President, Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum
Comment:
On behalf of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, St. Michaels, MD, I submit in opposition to USCG-2020-0042 titled "Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations," which proposes to consolidate and shut down U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford, located in Oxford, MD ("Station Oxford"). CBMM appreciates the opportunity to submit comment in opposition to USCG-2020-0042, and implores that you consider the impact that USCG-2020-0042 would have on the Eastern Shore.

CBMM believes the closure decision would be detrimental to all Eastern Shore residents, and the safety of CBMM's own on-the-water programming. A nearby Coast Guard station means greater safety on the water. Since CBMM operates vessels with thousands of museum guests and K-12 school children on field trips on waters near this Coast Guard station, safety is diminished if Oxford Station is closed, and the next nearest station has a longer run to reach us.

Currently, the next closest station is Annapolis. When CBMM operates on the Miles River, the Annapolis and Oxford stations are roughly equidistant. But response times from Annapolis are much slower if the Bay crossing is dangerous. 

When CBMM is operating on the Choptank, such as during the Oxford log canoe races or the Cambridge skipjack race, the Coast Guard in Annapolis will have a much longer response time. We have often seen Station Oxford visibly present for the Oxford regatta, and we appreciate them--and we have repeatedly said so to the young Coasties. Their visible presence tempers the behavior of other boaters.

CBMM appreciates your consideration of this opposition to the consolidation of Station Oxford. CBMM hopes that the very serious issue of boater safety--for people of all ages--will cause you to reconsider the the consolidation of Oxford Station. Closure of Oxford Station would be extremely detrimental to the health and safety of the entire marine community on the Eastern Shore, and particularly the public programming offered by CBMM, which is essential to CBMM's mission.

Kristen L. Greenaway
President
Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum

Title: Comment Submitted by Johnny Mautz, Maryland House of Delegates
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by Allen Prettyman
Comment: I would like to register my objection to closing Station Oxford. The safety of the people on the water would be greatly reduced in the area.

I had a medical energy and if the USCG in Oxford got to me and saved my life , If the station had been in Annapolis  I would have died. There are A LOt of traffic on the Tred Avon river as well as the Choptank. . There are a lot of seniors that boat in this area  . PLEASE reconsider your decision

Title: Comment Submitted by Wayne Winokur
Comment:
I am commenting on the potential closing of the Coast Guard Station in Oxford, MD.  I am a sailor and keep my boat at a marina in Oxford.  I use the boat often for various purposes, including racing and day sails in the Oxford area, and cruising on the bay.  I appreciate the fact that the Coast Guard has my back in the event of an emergency.  The potential plan is to close the Coast Guard station in my home area, and use Coast Guard Station - Annapolis in the event of an emergency.  It could potentially take a boat from Annapolis two hours or more to reach me; by then I might well be dead.

I completely agree with the statements by the Town of Oxford in its letter objecting to this closure.  It does not make sense to me.

Title: Comment Submitted by M Guerrieri
Comment: I am writing in strong opposition to USCG-2020-0042, Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations, proposing the consolidation of U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford located in Oxford, Maryland ("Station Oxford"). Station Oxford is integral to the safety of boaters, residents and businesses on the Eastern Shore. They are an important and cherished part of this historic seaport.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jeannie Haddaway- Riccio, Maryland Department of Natural Resources
Comment: See attached letter from the Secretary of the Maryland Department of Natural Resources.

Title: Comment Submitted by U.S. Senator Benjamin Cardin, Untied States Senate
Government Agency: United States Senate and House of Representatives
Comment:
We write in opposition to UCG-2020-0042, titled, "Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations," which proposes to close U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford, located in the city of Oxford, Maryland.  Station Oxford is the only U.S. Coast Guard site in the Eastern Shore of Maryland, a region that consists of nine counties and makes up more than a third of the total land area of the State.  We fear that the loss of the facility in Oxford would drastically increase emergency response times with the effect of undermining the region's safety and security.

The Eastern Shore is a vast geographic region that includes the waterways of the Chesapeake Bay, Choptank River, and Little Choptank River.  Economically, the area and its waterways form one of the most critical seafood harvesting grounds in the state.  In its large geographic jurisdiction are the active Calvert Cliffs Nuclear Power Plant as well as the Cove Point Liquefied Natural Gas export facility, two key national security assets.  Moreover, these waters are part of the Intracoastal Waterway that vessels use for transit along the length of the East Coast of the continental United States.  Thousands of watermen work and travel along the waterways, even in cold water and inclement weather.  The individuals who work in this and other industries on the water will at times require assistance in a time of emergency.

Station Oxford is all the more essential for meeting the unique security and safety needs of the Eastern Shore given that it is the only U.S. Coast Guard facility in this extensive region.  Manned by approximately 20 U.S. Coast Guard personnel, Station Oxford provides critical emergency response in a timely manner that is not likely to be maintained if it were to close.  Indeed, many of the public safety agencies in the area simply do not have the boats and other resources necessary for responding to emergencies on the waterways.  There is no alternative facility that can meet the needs of the Eastern Shore.  Station Annapolis, which in the case of Station Oxford closing, would become the closest facility.  Occupying a more northerly geographic position, that facility would not be able to respond to more southerly areas in the same amount of time.

Two other government agencies share the site with the U.S. Coast Guard: (1) the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) National Centers for Coastal Ocean Service's (NCCOS) Cooperative Oxford Laboratory and (2) Maryland's Department of Natural Resources (DNR).  This cohabitation of three agencies on one site has created longstanding partnerships while also allowing for greater utilization of the unique resources of the U.S. Coast Guard by state and local entities.  Yet while both NOAA and DNR also provide important functions, they cannot be a substitute for Station Oxford, whose public servants stand ready to respond to emergencies 24/7 all year round.  Their commitment to serving the needs of the Eastern Shore was only underscored when, during the 35-day federal government shutdown of 2018-2019, the men and women of Station Oxford continued to work even as they went unpaid and the NOAA and DNR facilities were vacant.

We thank you for taking the time to consider our public comment and hope that you can recognize the merits of our argument.  Station Oxford is a critical resource that can help save lives in the Eastern Shore.  It should remain in operation.

Title: Comment Submitted by Mary Gilmer
Comment:
Station Oxford is very much needed on the Eastern Shore. I have run the local marine towing and salvage company in the area for the past 30 years and work with the CG and other agencies closely. The ETA  from Annapolis to respond to an emergency in the Oxford, Cambridge or the Denton area would be far too long.  Their absence would put more pressure on our local volunteer fire departments and DNR assets. If CG Annapolis were to send a boat by land and launch in one of these areas, they would have to contend with the bridge traffic.  Is it more cost-effective for a helo to cover the area? There are many local events where CG Oxford is there to control boating traffic and assist with other issues.
We are a community that works together with all of our assets, closing Station Oxford would be removing one of our greatest assets in the safety of our boating community.

Title: Comment Submitted by Timothy Kearns, Oxford Volunteer Fire Company, Inc.
Comment:
On behalf of the Oxford Volunteer Fire Company, Inc. I am writing in opposition to USCG-2020-0042, Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations, that is proposing the consolidation and closure of U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford located in Oxford, Maryland ("Station Oxford").

I believe the closing of Station Oxford would be detrimental to the safety of our citizens and the boaters in our response area and on the Eastern Shore.

Station Oxford provides timely response to significant emergencies on the water.  If Station Oxford is closed, the next closest station to most of the areas Station Oxford serves is Station Annapolis and we would be hindered with a significant response time.
Although Station Oxford does not respond to our routine local marine emergencies, knowing that they are available to back us up is a significant factor in our safety strategy and our citizens knowing they are nearby is a contributing factor influencing our economy.
Their Federal presence deters the potential for drug trafficking within our many small waterways.
Station Oxford is pivotal in providing necessary boater education and oversight on our waters and reinforces our local Department of Natural Resources operations. 

Closing Station Oxford will place additional pressure on our limited local emergency services and resources to protect our region during a significant marine emergency.
If anything, OVFC would like to develop a much more routine working relationship with Station Oxford as we are struggling with minimal personnel and outdated marine resources.

Especially in light of our ongoing pandemic we ask that you maintain the existing Federal presence, manning, emergency assistance, and protections offered to the public health and safety on the Eastern Shore by USCG Station Oxford. 

Thank you for your consideration.



Timothy B. Kearns
President
Oxford Volunteer Fire Company, Inc.
300 Oxford Road
Oxford, Maryland 21654

Title: Comment Submitted by Zak Krebeck
Comment:
I am a resident of Talbot County and I am opposed to the elimination of the Coast Guard Station at Oxford at this time.  I believe the closure should be reconsidered based on the following:

1. The Mid-shore region has many more miles of shoreline to patrol than other the regions of the Bay.  

2. In addition to an active Recreational boating industry, the region is home to a large commercial fishing fleet including the Skipjack fleets that fish during the winter months.

I am a fair weather boater that can stay off the water when the conditions are a little iffy, but I am concerned about the commercial fisherman that don't always have that luxury.

Thank you for consideration.

Title: Comment Submitted by Corey Pack, Talbot County Council
Comment: Letter from Talbot County Council in opposition to USCG-2020-0042, Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations, proposing the consolidation of U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford located in Oxford, Maryland ("Station Oxford").

Title: Comment Submitted by Patricia Johnson, Dorchester Skipjack Committee
Comment:
The Dorchester Skipjack Committee, as owner and operator of the Nathan of Dorchester, a USCG certified passenger carrying vessel, strongly opposes the closure of the Oxford station.  A critical service for ensuring boating safety on the Tred Avon, Choptank River, Oxford provides an ability for rapid response to commercial fishing, pleasure and passenger carrying vessels.

The Nathan of Dorchester carries over 1200 passengers per year with over 100 trips per season.  We host and participate in the annual skipjack race which brings 10 historic boats to Cambridge.  We work with American Cruise Line, who carries many passengers on the eastern side of the Bay.  Along with seasonal recreational craft activity, the Choptank River hosts several powerboat races, log canoe and sail regattas.  These venues have potential need for USCG assistance and a station 32 nautical miles away could delay essential services and have devastating results.  

Please strongly reconsider the allocation of USCG services by maintaining the Oxford station: to valued service to this very large, varied and active boating community.

Title: Comment Submitted by Lawrence Rudner
Comment: As a boater on the Choptank River and the Chesapeake Bay by the Choptank, I am very concerned about the proposed closure of the Oxford Coast Guard station. Its elimination would put thousands of lives in danger.  In our area, the Coast Guard is most needed during unexpected horrendous weather conditions. The Chesapeake Bay is known for sudden squalls, tornados, and waterspouts. In those horrible conditions, it is unlikely the Annapolis office would be able to render timely assistance.

Title: Comment Submitted by Rep. Christopher H. Smith, U.S. House of Representatives
Comment:
See attached file(s)

Dear Admiral Schultz and Rear Admiral Sibley,

I am writing to urge you to withdraw the proposal to close the U.S. Coast Guard Station (small) Shark River located in Avon-by-the-Sea in my congressional district (NJ-04). Given the history and safety implications of this station, I am also requesting a meeting with you and your appropriate designees, as well as informed local stakeholders, to discuss this ill-conceived plan which has been proposed and rejected, with good reason, in the past.

As you are aware, in October of 2017 the Government Accountability Office (GAO) issued report GAO-18-9, titled Actions Needed to Close Stations Identified as Overlapping and Unnecessarily Duplicative. Within this report, the GAO recommended 18 boat stations be identified for consolidation and anticipated the consolidation of five stations--including Shark River station--be "notionally" implemented for fiscal year 2021. 

Each station has different circumstances.  Yet, there is little doubt that closing the Shark River station poses a serious threat to the safety of all who are on the water in-and-around Shark River, including commercial and recreational boaters, fishermen, athletes, and tourists.  The station is strategically located--and has been for over a century--300 yards inside the mouth of the Shark River Inlet in Avon.  The station covers a 25-mile stretch along the Monmouth County shore and is pivotal to the mission of preventing the loss of life, injury, and property, especially since time, in these matters, is always essential.   

The Shark River station is an optimal location for successful implementation of the U.S. Coast Guard's search and rescue (SAR) mission  in this very busy waterway.  The high volume of maritime activity in-and-out of the Shark River Inlet in the busy summer months and the crowds at the many perennially popular public beaches warrant a station closer than Manasquan Inlet and Sandy Hook to safeguard citizens from the constant danger of boating accidents and rip currents at the Jersey Shore. According to page 51 of the GAO report , between Fiscal Year 2010-2016, there were 47 SAR cases involving Shark River station, alone.  Those who live, work and recreate on the Shark River, underscore the importance of time in each of these cases and point out that closing the Shark River Station would jeopardize the mission of the U.S. Coast guard, and risk the safety of all who live and visit the northern Jersey Shore. 

I am aware that in 2007 and approximately 1997, U.S. Coast Guard attempted to seasonalize the station, closing it during the winter months.  Each time, the plan was ultimately withdrawn, underscoring the shortsightedness then, and even more so now.  Today, just as in 1997 and 2007, angler, boaters and water enthusiasts continue to require the protection offered by Station Shark River. It is imperative for the U.S. Coast Guard Shark River Station to be fully operationally with SAR mission capabilities 24 hours a day, seven days a week, 365 days a year. 

To ensure the safety of my constituents and all who visit the beautiful waters of the Jersey Shore--especially the Shark River area--I strongly encourage you to reconsider, and reject, this unnecessary and dangerous proposal. Additionally, I respectfully request that no final decision be made while the our Nation is observing stay-at-home orders due to the coronavirus pandemic and until leaders in and around the Shark River have had a chance to meet with you and your staff to discuss this critical matter.  

I appreciate your time and consideration. To identify a mutually convenient time for us to meet, please have your appropriate staff contact me or my legislative assistant Christopher Hansell at 202-225-3765 (Christopher.hansell@mail.house.gov).

Sincerely,
 
CHRISTOPHER H. SMITH
Member of Congress

Title: Comment Submitted by Pamela Getson, PhD

Title: Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Anne and  Mickey
Comment:
We are submitting these comments in opposition to USCG-2020-0042 titled "Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations," which proposes to consolidate and shut down U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford, located in Oxford, Md. ("Station Oxford").  We live on Tar Creek in Royal Oak, Maryland.  The town of Oxford can be seen from our dock.  We engage in recreational boating on the Tred Avon and Choptank Rivers.  Occasionally, we also venture into the Chesapeake Bay to go to the western shore or to the Miles River.  We ask that you consider the adverse impact that USCG-2020-0042 would have on boaters like us.

	Any decision to close the Oxford station would be detrimental to boaters in the Easton, Oxford, Cambridge, St. Michaels and Tilghman Island areas.  A nearby Coast Guard station means greater safety on the water.  In addition to coming to the aid of boaters, we have often seen the Oxford Station pull over boaters engaging in unsafe practices (e.g., kids on the bow while underway, following too closely, too many people on the boat) and in some cases, boating "under the influence."  Many of these activities by the Oxford Station are preventative.  Safety is diminished if Oxford Station is closed, and the next nearest station has a longer run to reach us and only comes once an accident has occurred.  Moreover, the visible presence of the Oxford Station tempers the behavior of other boaters.

	Currently, the next closest station is Annapolis.  When boating on the Tred Avon or on the Choptank, the Coast Guard in Annapolis will have a much longer response time.  The preventative activities now undertaken by the Oxford Station will be basically nonexistent.  The response times from Annapolis will be even longer if the Bay crossing is dangerous.

	We appreciate your consideration of this opposition to the consolidation of Station Oxford.  We hope that the very serious issue of boater safety--for people of all ages--will cause you to reconsider the consolidation of Oxford Station.  Closure of Oxford Station would be extremely detrimental to the health and safety of the entire marine community on the Eastern Shore, and particularly those on the Tred Avon and Choptank Rivers.
See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by David L. White
Comment:
Dear Sir:  I write as Commodore of the Chester River Yacht & Country Club (CRYCC) to oppose USCG 2020-0042, "Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations", particularly opposing the closing of the Coast Guard Boat Station in Oxford, Maryland.  While CRYCC is located in the northern part of the eastern shore of Maryland our members frequently sail through Kent Narrows into the Eastern Bay and further south.  Thus we sail in waters where coverage by the Coast Guard station at Oxford affords greater security than the station at Annapolis.  In addition, CRYCC sponsors one of the Log Canoe races usually held in Langford Bay which may be more easily accessible in an emergency than from the station in Annapolis.  Consequently we oppose closing of the station in Oxford as it is detrimental to eastern shore residents and the safety of CRYCC activities.

Sincerely,
David L. White
Commodore CRYCC

Title: Comment Submitted by Deborah Lawrence on behalf of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum
Comment:
Gentlemen, On behalf of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, St. Michaels, MD, on whose Board I serve, I submit in opposition to USCG-2020-0042 titled "Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations," which proposes to consolidate and shut down U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford, located in Oxford, MD ("Station Oxford"). CBMM appreciates the opportunity to submit comments in opposition to USCG-2020-0042, and implores that you consider the impact that USCG-2020-0042 would have on the Eastern Shore.

CBMM believes the closure decision would be detrimental to all Eastern Shore residents, and the safety of CBMM's own on-the-water programming. A nearby Coast Guard station means greater safety on the water. Since CBMM operates vessels with thousands of museum guests and K-12 school children on field trips on waters near this Coast Guard station, safety is diminished if Oxford Station is closed, and the next nearest station has a longer run to reach us.

Currently, the next closest station is Annapolis. When CBMM operates on the Miles River, the Annapolis and Oxford stations are roughly equidistant. But response times from Annapolis are much slower if the Bay crossing is dangerous.

When CBMM is operating on the Choptank, such as during the Oxford log canoe races or the Cambridge skipjack race, the Coast Guard in Annapolis will have a much longer response time. We have often seen Station Oxford visibly present for the Oxford regatta, and we appreciate them--and we have repeatedly said so to the young Coasties. Their visible presence tempers the behavior of other boaters.

CBMM appreciates your consideration of this opposition to the consolidation of Station Oxford. CBMM hopes that the very serious issue of boater safety--for people of all ages--will cause you to reconsider the consolidation of Oxford Station. Closure of Oxford Station would be extremely detrimental to the health and safety of the entire marine community on the Eastern Shore, and particularly the public programming offered by CBMM, which is essential to CBMM's mission.

Title: Comment Submitted by Elizabeth Moose, SOS Sink or Swim
Comment:
We are in  opposition to USCG-2020-0042 titled "Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations," which proposes to consolidate and shut down U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford, located in Oxford, MD ("Station Oxford"). SOS Sink or Swim appreciates the opportunity to submit comments in opposition to USCG-2020-0042, and implores that you consider the impact that USCG-2020-0042 would have on the Eastern Shore.

Talbot County has more miles of waterfront than any other county in Maryland.  Being safe in our waters in a paramount concern.  The Coast Guard helps to prevent drownings by being immediately available to respond to commercial fishing and recreational boating accidents.

Thank you for your consideration,
Libby Moose
President, SOS Sink or Swim

Title: Comment Submitted by James Boicourt, Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum
Comment:
On behalf of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, St. Michaels, MD, I submit in opposition to USCG-2020-0042 titled "Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations," which proposes to consolidate and shut down U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford, located in Oxford, MD ("Station Oxford"). CBMM appreciates the opportunity to submit comments in opposition to USCG-2020-0042, and implores that you consider the impact that USCG-2020-0042 would have on the Eastern Shore.

As someone who was born on the Eastern Shore of Maryland, grew up commercial crabbing for my first job, and a regular boater on the waters of the bay, Oxford Station is of the utmost importance for responding to the very popular waters of the Tred Avon, Choptank, and the rest of the Eastern Shore. This area is one of the most popular destinations on the Bay for recreational boating, is home to thousands of working watermen, many of whom don't know how to swim, and is a place where people live and breath life on the water. Schools regularly have field trips to Poplar island and on boats down in this area, and I can't imagine anyone but the USCG responding with adequate resources. 

Keeping people living and breathing is important, and the response capabilities of local municipalities are not up to the task of adequately responding to calls for help. Only the USCG has the full level of training, experience, coordination abilities, etc to deal with the amount of need in this area, and response time is critical when dealing with marine accidents.

I regularly spend time sailing and fishing in these waters, and cannot imagine not having the presence of Oxford Station.

Title: Comment Submitted by Howard Freedlander
Comment:
I'm writing to oppose the proposed closing of the USCG station in Oxford, MD. While I understand the USCG made this difficult decision for business reasons and the increased capability of SAR assets to respond to maritime incidents, I question the ability of the Coast Guard station in Annapolis to respond quickly and efficiently to the large geographic are of the Eastern Shore of Maryland.

As a member of the Board of Governors of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum (CBMM) in St. Michaels, MD, I'm aware of the needs simply related to CBMM activities, not to speak of the requirements for emergency support of the thousands of commercial and recreational boaters throughout the water-dominated Eastern Shore.

I hope that the decision-makers at the USCG will reverse its decision concerning the proposed closing of the Oxford station. I hope that consideration is given to the impact of closing this facility on a region accustomed to a rapid response by the Coast Guard's skilled professionals.

Thank you.

Title: Comment Submitted by Elizabeth Moose, SOS Sink or Swim (2nd Comment)
Comment:
SOS Sink or Swim, a Talbot County, MD non-profit organization whose fiscal sponsor is the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum in St. Michaels, MD, respectfully submits its opposition to USCG-2020-0042 titled "Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations," which proposes to consolidate and shut down U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford, located in Oxford, MD ("Station Oxford"). SOS Sink or Swim appreciates the opportunity to submit comments in opposition to USCG-2020-0042, and implores that you consider the impact that USCG-2020-0042 would have on the Eastern Shore.

Since 2014, SOS Sink or Swim has provided over 5,000 "free to all, no questions asked" swimming lessons to children and adults at the Talbot County public pools each summer.  Our goal is not only to teach swimming lessons but also to help children and their caregivers feel safe in and around the water,

Preventing drowning is a goal we share with the Coast Guard.  Talbot County has over 600 miles of shoreline, more than any other County in the US.  Talbot County also has limited public access to its waters so children often seek unsafe places to jump in the water.  We need Coast Guard Station Oxford more than ever as more and more people of all ages and races will be eager to enjoy the water following the COVID-19 crisis.

Please continue to help us save lives by keeping the Oxford, MD station open.

Thank you very much,

Libby Moose
President, SOS Sink or Swim Council

Title: Comment Submitted by Jennifer Kuhn, Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum
Comment:
On behalf my role as Shipyard Programs Manager at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, St. Michael's, MD, and as a resident of the Eastern Shore of Md,  I submit in opposition to USCG-2020-0042 titled "Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations," which proposes to consolidate and shut down U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford, located in Oxford, MD ("Station Oxford"). I greatly appreciate the opportunity to submit comments in opposition to USCG-2020-0042, and request that you consider the impact that USCG-2020-0042 would have on the Eastern Shore.

I believe this closure would harmful to all of our Eastern Shore residents, and the safety of CBMM's own on-the-water programming. If the Oxford station is closed the next station is in Annapolis which means a longer run to reach us and even longer if the Bay crossing is dangerous due to the weather. 

I am a log canoe sailor and an ACA certified kayak instructor who participates in activities with the public on the Miles, Choptank, Chester and Tred Avon Rivers. I've often seen Station Oxford visibly present during these events.  This presences is welcomed and a deterant for bad behaviors from other boaters.


I appreciate your consideration of this opposition and hope you will reconsider the consolidation of the Oxford Station.   Closure of the Oxford Station would be extremely detrimental to the health and safety of the entire marine community on the Eastern Shore, and particularly the public programming offered by CBMM, which is essential to CBMM's mission.

Thank you,

Jennifer Kuhn

Comment:

Title: Comment Submitted by Jillian Ferris
Comment:
Please accept my comments in opposition to USCG-2020-0042 titled "Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations," which proposes to consolidate and shut down U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford, located in Oxford, MD ("Station Oxford"). I appreciate the opportunity to submit comments in opposition to USCG-2020-0042, and implore that you consider the impact that USCG-2020-0042 would have on the Eastern Shore.

As the Director of Education at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum in St. MIchaels, MD, I oversee programming that puts PK-12 school children, families, and adult museum guests on the water. While safety is a top priority for our programming and in the operation of our vessels, one of my greatest fears is the need to call in advanced support. A nearby Coast Guard station means greater safety on the water. The closure of the Oxford Station directly impacts the safety of our rivers and local boating communities, as in the event of an incident, the next nearest station has a longer run to reach us.

Further, as an active member in the Chesapeake Bay sailboat racing community, I have personally experienced the impact of the Coast Guard presence on the Eastern Shore. Our traditional boats are very tender and susceptible to wake from other boats; despite an abundance of safety precautions on the part of our skippers and fleet, we have little ability to control other recreational boaters who can--and have--put other boaters on the river at risk. The presence of the Coast Guard has a dramatically positive impact on protecting our fleet.

Currently, the next closest station is Annapolis. When CBMM operates on the Miles River, the Annapolis and Oxford stations are roughly equidistant. But response times from Annapolis are much slower if the Bay crossing is dangerous. When CBMM is operating on the Choptank, such as during the Oxford log canoe races or the Cambridge skipjack race, the Coast Guard in Annapolis will have a much longer response time. We have often seen Station Oxford visibly present for the Oxford regatta, and we appreciate them--and we have repeatedly said so to the young Coasties. Their visible presence tempers the behavior of other boaters.

I appreciates your consideration of this opposition to the consolidation of Station Oxford, and hope that the very serious issue of boater safety--for people of all ages--will cause you to reconsider the consolidation of Oxford Station. Closure of Oxford Station would be extremely detrimental to the health and safety of the entire marine community on the Eastern Shore, and particularly the public programming offered by CBMM, which is essential to CBMM's mission.

Title: Comment Submitted by Nancy Appleby
Comment: As a longtime boat owner and home homeowner in Bozman, MD, I submit in opposition to USCG-2020-0042 titled "Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations," which proposes to consolidate and shut down U.S. Coast Guard Station Oxford, located in Oxford, MD ("Station Oxford"). I  implore you consider the negative  impact that USCG-2020-0042 would have on the Eastern Shore.

Title: Comment Submitted by Bruce Grimm
Comment:
RE: Docket USCG-2020-0042 FRN 2020-03079 

The Coast Guard, within the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), is charged with preventing loss of life, injury and property damage in the maritime environment through its search and rescue mission.  The operations and maintenance of a vast network of boat stations with various assets, along the United States coasts and inland waterways are a testament to carrying out this mission and those of maritime security. 

Although each station is deemed important by various groups of citizens and local officials, resource limitations and changes to operations require the Coast Guard to periodically reexamine the need for these stations.  That is what was done in this case that identified five stations for future closure or modification. 

The need for stations at particular locations has generally decreased over the years with changes in boating activity, boating equipment, and the capabilities of other search and rescue providers such as local police, sheriff, fire departments or other first responders.  However, these entities may not match the many physical responsibilities and duties of the members of the Coast Guard. 

Today and in the past, action at Coast Guard stations has availed the services of adjacent stations when called upon to proceed to render assistance or at least keep in readiness to respond promptly to any subsequent call or be a lookout in the immediate area under distress.   Changes to Coast Guard operations, such as additional mission requirements to address emerging security issues, capabilities and resource limitations allows for the Coast Guard to periodically review the allocation of these resources, including those directed toward boat stations to ensure that they are positioned to meet the Coast Guard's current missions while not unnecessarily duplicating efforts.  This has been done through audit and inspection which identified boat stations for closure. 

This appears to be a sound process for analyzing the need for the Coast Guard boat stations and action should be taken to implement the process results.  The established evaluation design practices and internal control standards can also be used to determine reopening such boat stations, if needed, in the future.
