Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: As a frequent visitor to Lake of the Ozarks and one who has experience the business of firework season, find Safety Zone; Lake of the Ozarks, Mile Marker .5 on the Main Channel of the Lake of the Ozarks Near Bagnel Dam, Lake Ozark, MO. A well-needed necessity. The main channel and the Bagnel Dam are popular spots. While the language in the provision thus far covers a wide range of what, when, and who, in the sentences, "The zone is intended to ensure the safety of persons, vessels, and these navigable waters before, during, and after the scheduled 9:30 p.m. to 10:00 p.m. fireworks display. No vessel or person would be permitted to enter the safety zone without obtaining permission from the COTP or a designated representative," could be reviewed. Is "vessels" only in relation to boats, or vessels meant for floating atop the water? Does the "navigable waters" only apply that of the main channel and water in the surround area of the damn, or also the water that flows through the damn and to the other side? Would the safety zone extend past and through the Bagnel dam? People tend to also gather on or around the Bagnel Dam due to the tourist attraction of shopping strip located just before the damn and could potentially be considered a safety zone. It is appropriate and necessary to discuss first amendment rights as many people will be affected by this provision and getting permission to cross as an average person may pose hardships. All things considered, safety in a very dangerous area during a busy season is not a bad idea. The proposed Informational broadcasts that will inform the public of the enforcement date and times for this safety zone, as well as any emergent safety concerns that may delay the enforcement of the zone through Local Notices to Mariners (LNM) will help the transition of this safety provision into the lives of those who live in the area, boaters, and vacationers.

Title: Comment Submitted by Selena E.
Comment:
After reading this Proposed Rule, I would be in support for this Safety Zone. If the Safety Zone does not hinder small businesses, as the Rule said, I do not see a reason for the Zone to be instated. I feel there would be far more benefits in instating a Zone, versus not instating a Zone. If the Zone were not instated, the fireworks could potentially harm those who are too close to the area where they are being set off. Additionally, I feel that a Safety Zone would cut down on the amount of people that would attempt to be too close to the firework site. 
This Zone might aid in water security and the safety of everyone involved in the fireworks. Additionally, I feel that this Zone would protect the individuals who are in charge of the fireworks. They would not have to worry about anyone becoming too close to their display, as the Zone would be in place. The Zone makes sense in this instance.

Title: Comment Submitted by Joseph Hanes
Comment: This is a good idea. I think that it will help keep people safe. Just ensure that it does not slow down traffic or conflict more than it needs to with people who are using their boats on the lake.

Title: Unrelated Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I'm concerned that USCG has completely misinterpreted Executive Order 13771 Reducing Regulation and Controlling Regulatory Costs. It's a mistake to read the text of this EO literally. In fact it was written (in the words of President Trump) "sarcastically... just to see what would happen."

Title: Comment Submitted by Ednalyn Kishida
Comment:
Ednalyn Kishida, 3161 Ala Ilima Street #209, 3/27/20


Dear Planners:

I am writing a comment regarding the proposed rule to issue a Special Local Regulation for the Sail Grand Prix 2020 Race Event; San Francisco, CA (USCG-2020-0078-0001). Due to the current situation of the COVID-19 virus  pandemic that takes place in the United States, I would like to know if this will affect the promulgation of these regulations. California is on lock down situation as well as the entire nation and most of the world. Therefore, it is highly unlikely this event will occur. The World Health Organization declared it as a pandemic and the people to social distance themselves and to self-quarantine at home until the virus threat has passed. However, if the Sail Grand Prix 2020 Race Event Regatta is held the main concern for writing this comment is the safety for the public in the event. The other concerns would be how they will minimize the control issue of terrorism or violent attempts, such as will there be any security check points so people with weapons would be minimized and where would 20,000 people park and who would be providing the food and beverages, is alcohol going to be served for the event? because it could lead to physical alterations. There will need to have to have a clear access to police, fire, and medical assistance and ambulance in the event of an incident. The accountability and logistics for distribution and security of the funds the collecting of the ticket fee to watch the event as well as selling food and alcohol, they would need to have permits for the alcohol and food. Lastly is the issue of the residents who dispute this event and wants access to the water which is a health and safety concern. In addition, may concerns are with the supporting documents on file which I have listed below.
 
	Regarding the document on file: DHS National Environmental Policy Act Record of Environmental Consideration for Categorically Excluded Actions an issue was raised by BCDC during the 2019 event regarding an incidental impact to waterfront users , I agree with this document in closing off all access from the waterfront area directly to everyone in front of Yacht Road through-traffic is possible prevent citizens the same mistakes and individuals from getting injuries. Also, I agree with this change making this area a no loitering zones along the San Francisco Waterfront to the east and west of Yacht Road in San Francisco, CA. 

	Regarding the document on file: DHS National Environmental Policy Act Record of Environmental Consideration for Categorically Excluded Actions: I would recommend  all recreational owners of water vehicles hanging around period should be banned from the event. Therefore, I disagree with this "This closure will not affect vessel entry to or exit from marinas, piers, or parks located east or west of Yacht Road in San Francisco, CA, so recreational boaters will still be able to launch their watercraft to enjoy the Bay. Commercial vessels will be notified of the closure to through-traffic in advance, so they'll be able to plan to transit around the northern edge of the regulated area".  Please consider blocking the access to the public in this area until the event is concluded.  

	Regarding the document on file Chart Graphic_SailGP20_NPRM is it possible to block access Zone C1 West- Spectator Area and have the public access only C! East

	 My main concern is that In the past two years, the hours for the previous Regattas start was earlier from 10-3pm and this time allowed was adequate. Perhaps if this event starts earlier it could have a conclusion earlier at 3pm instead of 5:30 pm making the local residents happier and they would stay away from the event until the conclusion. There were nine local residents who also commented about the time ending by 3pm so I wanted to suggest a recommendation for the Regatta ending at 3pm. my recommendation is if this event started earlier and the warm up time is reduced to 30- 45 min perhaps the event can conclude earlier by 3pm. 
	Another recommendation is if this event finished even earlier with an earlier start time such as 10-1pm than food, beverages and alcohol at the event would be moot. There would not be the need for food to be served.



Thank you for your time and effort in reading my letter, I hope that my recommendations would be considered. Thank you the opportunity to comment. Please add my name to your mailing list so that, I can be active of this project.




Sincerely,


Ednalyn Kishida

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
On behalf of Fordham Law students, we are submitting this comment in response to the United States Coast Guard's Notice of Proposed Rulemaking on Special Local Regulations and Safety Zones; Recurring Marine Events and Fireworks Displays and Swim Events Held in the Coast Guard Sector Long Island Sound Zone published in the Federal Register on April 20, 2020. We'd like to express our support for the proposed changes aimed at expediting public notification of recurring maritime events and ensuring the protection of the public and event participants from potential safety hazards.

Our group appreciates the Coast Guard's effort to reduce administrative costs and bureaucracy. Given our group's support for this proposed regulation, we want to make sure the Coast Guard has the required legal authority to enact the proposed change. Specifically, we are concerned about whether the Coast Guard's proposed changes adhere to the "hard look" standard the Supreme Court set forth in Citizens to Preserve Overton Park v. Volpe. 

The Coast Guard stated that it derives its authority to enact this proposed rule from 46 U.S.C. 70034. Under the statute, the "Secretary shall consult with, and receive and consider the views of all interested persons..." While the effects of these proposed changes appear positive, we want to ensure that the interests of the parties who will be affected have been adequately considered, including the organizers of the events around the Long Island Sound. 

Additionally, under "Section IV(B): Impact on Small Entities," the Coast Guard certifies under 5 U.S.C. 605(b) that the proposed rule would not have a significant economic impact on a substantial number of small entities. The statute states that an agency can avoid the extensive analysis required by section 602, 603, or 604 of the same statute if "the head of the agency certifies that the rule will not...have a significant economic impact on a substantial number of small entities."

The Coast Guard is likely operating under the appropriate authority, but our group's main concern is to ensure that the Coast Guard is operating within the rules of the APA and has fully considered the relevant outside interests and impacts on small businesses before invoking 5 U.S.C 605(b). As stated in Overton Park, a court "must consider whether the decision was based on a consideration of the relevant factors and whether there has been a clear error of judgment. Thus, a court may require a more in-depth analysis than just the agency's proclamation that there will be no significant economic impact on small entities.  While the plain language of the statute may not seem to require any additional analysis, we are concerned that the rule will not pass a court's review under the APA's "arbitrary and capricious" standard. 

Our group wants to ensure that the agency will be able to competently address the factors considered for the agency's proclamation. We are therefore requesting a formal publication of the factors considered.

For example Trump's side could display FILTHY MOUTHED... and then Teigen's side responds. I would definitely watch this.

Thanks for the consideration and stay safe.

Comment:
docket number [USCG-2020-0094]
Ms. Megan Johns Henry, Alternate Designated Federal Officer of the Merchant Marine Personnel Advisory Committee, 2703 Martin Luther King Jr. Ave. SE, Stop 7509, Washington, DC 20593-7509, telephone 202-372-1255, fax 202-372-4908 ormegan.c.johns@uscg.mil
Dear Megan,

1. The meeting should consider a Model Course in Vessel Quarantine and Dock/Port Quarantine.
2. Also, pursuant to the Compact of Free Association and the extension of the economic aid package, the meeting should consider requesting the USCG Inspector General, and the GAO or Comptroller General to report on implementation of:"Section 342"The Government of the United States shall have enrolled, at any one time, at least one qualified student from Palau as may be nominated by the Government of Palau, in each of:"(a) The United States Coast Guard Academy pursuant to14 U.S.C. 195[now14 U.S.C. 1923]; and"(b) The United States Merchant Marine Academy pursuant to [former] 46 U.S.C. [App.] 1295b(b)(6) [see46 U.S.C. 51304], provided that the provisions of 46 U.S.C. [App.] 1295b(b)(6)(C) [now46 U.S.C. 51304(b)(2)] shall not apply to the enrollment of students pursuant to Section 342(b) of this Compact.3. Also, the Meeting should invite participation of Palau, Tuvalu and Kiribati in respect of fulfilling the theirnational requirements under Presidential Determination No. 2002-09 of March 12, 2002Eligibility of Palau, Kiribati, and Tuvalu to Receive DefenseArticles and Services Under the Foreign Assistance Act andthe Arms Export Control ActMemorandum for the Secretary of State
Pursuant to the authority vested in me by section 503(a) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, as amended, and section 3(a)(1) of the Arms ExportControl Act, I hereby find that the furnishing of defense articles and services to the Governments of Palau, Kiribati, and Tuvalu will strengthen thesecurity of the United States and promote world peace.You are authorized and directed to report this finding to the Congress andto publish this memorandum in the Federal Register.GEORGE W. BUSHTHE WHITE HOUSE,Washington, March 12, 2002.4. And the meeting should ensure compliance with the LEP rules and the spirit of 25 USC 2902 and 2904, providing for conference interpretation in appropriate First Languages.5. We would like to request two minutes to address the meeting pursuant to the Public Notice (During the April 8, 2020 teleconference, a public comment period will be held from approximately 2-2:15 p.m.). We will provide simultaneous interpretation as may be needed.6. We hope the meeting will consider the status of Formosa and the Pescadores and the Spratley and Paracels. Previously the Secretary of State noted that the US have residual responsibilities under the Peace Treaty with Japan and perhaps the SEATO Treaty:https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1955-57v03/d186.During the discussion, the Secretary pointed out that we might consider acting under the Japanese Treaty since the U.S. has residual responsibility over all former Japanese territories. He also expressed the tentative view that we could act unilaterally under Article VIII of theSEATOtreaty.3Various other possibilities were discussed, including[Page 379]the suggestion that we might get the Philippines to act jointly with us. The Secretary rejected the suggestion of consultation with otherSEATOpowers on the ground that quick action was needed and the only way to get it was for the United States to act and take the responsibility for acting.He agreed, however, that nothing could be done until the facts has been ascertained from the reconnaissance aircraft from the Seventh Fleet and that meanwhile various possibilities for prompt and effective action should be explored.7. Since the Treaty is the supreme Law of the Land, we hope the meeting will consider those aspects of our merchant marine human capital development in light of 22 CFR 120.13: "any territory or possession over which the United States exercises any powers of administration, legislation, and jurisdiction", 22 USC 619, 18 USC 3185, and the various statutes and CFRs defining waters of the United States.Respectfully,
Dr. Paul Maas RisenhooverRobin Hood International Human Rights Legal Defense FundTainan, FORMOSA, island of Taiwan

Title: Unrelated Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
We all know the drill. First President Trump comes up with some crackpot theory, e.g. that a hurricane will hit Alabama. When questioned Trump doubles down, lashing out at the media and cherry picking evidence -- or in this case clumsily marking up a weather map with a Sharpie. Then his staff twists themselves into knots coming up with any possible rationale. And anyone that doesn't get on board is bullied and punished.

So now it's the Covid-19 pandemic, and Trump's crackpot theory is: "HYDROXYCHLOROQUINE & AZITHROMYCIN, taken together, have a real chance to be one of the biggest game changers in the history of medicine!" Federal agencies like HHS and the FDA were told to get on board, despite the lack of supporting evidence. And those who didn't? C'mon, you know that. When Dr. Rick Bright argued for focusing on "vetted solutions" rather than unproven drugs, he was removed from his position as director of the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority.

On the plus side Trump seems to be slowly figuring out that CoronaVIRUS is a virus, not a bacteria.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: The premise of this proposed rule makes sense; lessening the number of entities involved in a process can make it more efficient. Less time and money will need to be spent to reach the end result. However, this is a deregulatory statement which returns responsibility back to the manufacturers to certify that the survival craft equipment they produce meets the appropriate criteria. This can be a dangerous game since without the Coast Guard spot checking the equipment the manufacturers produce, the quality of survival craft equipment has the potential to decrease as the tolerances for mistakes will likely widen. If it is highly likely that manufacturers will regulate themselves accordingly then this rule could work, but as we look at precedents set throughout history that is rarely the case. Based on that I would not withdrawal the Coast Guard type approval requirements in order to air on the side of caution.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I fully support the recommended update to First Aid Kits. The first aid kit requirements were in need of updates and burdened companies will purchasing very specific items that were limited in choices. Allowing companies to purchase first aid kits that have been approved by the manufacturer will save companies the headache of having to assemble kits on their own.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Regarding the first aid kit contents for life rafts/boats, on page 62919  it is stated "medicinal products must be approved by the US Food and Drug Administration."  The US FDA does not routinely approve OTC products; the overwhelming majority are sold without FDA approval.  The FDA reviews the active ingredients of OTCs. [1]  Oral analgesics sold OTC consist of products which have received FDA approval by an NDA, as well as products containing FDA reviewed active ingredients.   If the intent is to include all OTC oral analgesics, rather than limit the analgesics to only those which have received FDA approval by an NDA, then the statement on page 62919 needs to be revised to be inclusive.

(1)  https://www.fda.gov/drugs/types-applications/drug-applications-over-counter-otc-drugs

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: The proposed First Aid Kit contents list (page 62892) does not specify the FDA regulatory status, product form, or type of delivery for the two topical preparations in the ISO 18813 requirements.  For potential first aid kit manufacturers, it would be helpful to know if these two products are supposed to be FDA over-the-counter drug products or cosmetic products, as well as the product form and delivery.

Title: Comment Submitted by Acme United Corporation (3rd Comment)
Comment: Removing all Coast Guard oversight for first aid kits in the proposed rule changes for Survival Craft Equipment may result in substandard first aid kits (Table 1, First-Aid Kit; removal of approval of First Aid Kits Subpart 160.054).  The new proposed rules fail to provide a guarantee first-aid kits will meet or exceed the proposed first-aid kit standards.  Although manufacturer self-certifying a kit (page 62854) is indicated, there is no proposal as to how this is achieved, or who will ascertain this certification is accurate.  With no confirmation the self-certification is accurate, this may lead to omission of required first-aid kit items, alternate interpretations of required kit components, and/or sub-standard kits.  If the current system of USCG First Aid kit approval is eliminated, how does the USCG intend to ensure the first aid kits are compliant with the regulations?

Title: Comment Submitted by Acme United Corporation (2nd Comment)
Comment:
The proposed use of ISO 18813:2006 (E) 4.12, as the First Aid Kit standard (Table 30) should be reconsidered and replaced with clearly defined kit component specifications.  The ISO requirements proposed for the first aid kits are ambiguous.  Other countries, such as Canada, Australia, United Kingdom (UK), and New Zealand  precisely define the contents of their lifeboat/raft first aid kit. (See Attachment 1 for comparison of lifeboat/life raft kits from these jurisdictions, as well as current USCG, and ISO.)  This includes the number of each component and the size or dosage.  Without clear specifications, the proposed US lifeboat/life raft first aid kit contents will likely vary from manufacturer to manufacturer.   For example, consider “bandage in assorted sizes”.   This nomenclature can lead to the inclusion of mostly bandages which are the least expensive, with one or two of another size. Not only should the dimensions be specified, but the type of bandage and material.    Similar ambiguities are presented for every first aid supply in the ISO requirements.  Specifics need to be provided for the ingested drug, topical products, and length and width of bandages, compression bandage, gauze compress, and triangular bandage so the kits will be standardized.
 
With the need for clearly defined kit contents, we are proposing the components in Table 1 be considered for the US lifeboat/life raft first aid kit contents.    The contents were based on a comparison of other kits (Attachment 1) and our knowledge of marine and USCG first aid kits. 

The integrity of the first aid kit contents is important.  Contents should be kept dry and protected until they are needed.   The primary means of protecting the kit contents is the case.  The kit’s case should withstand the expected conditions it may encounter.  Currently, all approved USCG life rafts use the same soft pliable plastic first aid kit pouch.  The pouch was approved by the USCG.    Use of rigid cases is a concern.  The use of polypropylene cases is unacceptable due to their propensity to crack and shatter. The ability of other types of plastic cases, such as high impact polystyrene (HIPS) and acrylonitrile butadiene styrene (ABS), may also pose a broken plastic risk, as well as potentially damaging a life raft.   ISO 18813:2006 (E) 4.1 states “The use of rigid plastic cases which can shatter and create sharp or pointed edges shall be avoided."

We propose the use of the currently USCG approved watertight soft plastic pouch for all life vessel first aid kits, not just the life rafts.  In addition to being flexible for easy storage on a vessel, the pouch is proven to be watertight (46 USC 160.054-5b ), resist salt spray damage (46 USC 160.054-5a), tolerate temperature extremes (LSA Code 5.17.3), and pass drop testing (46 USC 160.051-5(e)(2).  The testing conducted ensures first aid kit contents will be protected for those situations the pouch may encounter.  All pouches intended for lifeboat/ life raft first aid kit use should meet the same testing requirements for being watertight, salt spray tolerant, and pass drop testing and be able to withstand temperature extremes.

Using the pouch to hold the kit contents can offer the flexibility of having more pouches on larger lifeboats/ life rafts to accommodate the potential first aid needs of more people.   A single pouch contents (as shown in TABLE 1) is sufficient for 25 people.  For larger survival craft, a pouch needs to be added for every 25 people.  Example:  Lifeboat for 26 – 50 people, 2 pouches.  This helps keep costs lower for smaller life rafts yet provides sufficient supplies for larger survival craft.
In addition to the outer first aid pouch providing protection, the components within the kit must be further protected, by being individually wrapped and sealed in plastic.  This allows the kit to be opened during wet conditions and the contents remain protected from water as specified in ISO 18813:2006(E) A.2.7.1.

Title: Comment Submitted by Acme United Corporation
Comment: The proposed use of ISO 18813:2006 (E) as the standard for lifeboat/life raft equipment and first aid kits is not an optimal choice for a standard.  It is not widely accepted; we were unable to identify any country using it as a basis for their first aid lifeboat/life raft kits.   Furthermore, the 14-year old ISO 18813:2006 (E) standard is currently under review by the International Organization for Standardization.   If changes are made to the life raft equipment and first aid kit contents as part of their review, the United States Coast Guard’s (USCG) Proposed Rule will become outdated.  It would be better for the USCG to establish their own standards, rather rely on another organization’s standards which may be about to change.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
I am the general manager of a 10-boat passenger boat (whale watching) operation in Alaska. We have been in marine tour operations for over 15 years now and have a well organized - 'tried and true' - method for documenting our captain & crew policies, training policies and USCG compliance. The proposed rule, to me, is very vague: it "could include" a lot of things and, with no tangible examples provided of what new documentation could look like, it's hard for me to understand how that would impact my business and how much annual work it would add to the already incredibly detailed-oriented process that is annual and 5-year inspections. 

My suggestion to you is this: ask your local inspectors for real life tangible examples. Put another way, can they provide you with case studies, real on the ground examples, of companies they feel are doing it right, e.g. have clearly stated safety procedures, staff policies, etc. Our local inspector in USCG sector Juneau deals with every single tourism company (and there are MANY), and I know he could rattle off for you who is organized and who isn't. Organization says a lot right off the bat about who has true safety follow-through and follow-up. I also expect many companies would be willing to provide proprietary examples of their procedures (be it required training hours or accident report procedures & formatting, or paperwork organization - whatever), should he ask for them.

Title: Comment Submitted by Steven Welch, American & Canadian Lock Tours, Inc.
Comment:
V. Information Requested (Responses from American & Canadian Lock Tours, Inc. in operation since 1934.

1.  All vessel operators should have some type of SMS, Crew Training Manual, and be actively involved in training their crews in safety and security.  The local Sector Marine Inspection Offices nationwide know which operators are Maritime Professionals and which operations are trying to skate by under the radar.  The resident Inspectors really know the vessel operators in their zones.  They do get stretched to thin at times though.  That's your problem to fix.  Beef up the staff in Marine Inspection at every Sector.  They do a fabulous job.

2.  We always are looking at how to become better at what we do.  These improvements are implemented when we see them, and all crew all trained in new and improved procedures.  Our local inspectors see us annually and know the strides we take to be professional.  There is always a benefit to becoming better at what you do.

3.  There is no silo-ing in our Company.  We have multiple vessels and internal control measures in place.  The best thing is to have all crew on all vessels share experiences with management present taking notes  I remember when the PTP Program was put into place.  The answer was simple Prevention Through People.  The key to success though relies on the People segment.  "The People involved must be Professional" and They must truly care about what they are doing.  The local Marine Inspection Teams know those operators that care and those that are just trying the skate by under the radar.  The local Marine Inspection Teams can easily rate every operator in their zone. A, B, C, D, and Absolute Failure.

4.   Communication

5.  Don't bog something done that is best handled by the Operators themselves.

6.  Once again, don't bog something down with regulations.  Get back to the roots of PTP and increase you staffing in Marine Inspection Offices.  They know better than anyone, what's going on in the real world of the Passenger Vessel Industry.

7.  Why complicate the world.  Allow your USCG Inspectors to rate the operators and then see exactly where the problem is. It is not with the Professional Operators.

8.  Use a tiered approach.  Analyze where Risk of Life is in each operation.  What factors would create Risk of Life.  Each operator should be able to mitigate that risk.  Serious Injury is the next tier.  Steps should be made by the operator to mitigate this tier.  The USCG Marine Inspecion Teams are already engaging with Operators to provide information on mitigation measures.  If anything, the Marine Inspection Teams are understaffed.

9.  One size does not fit all.  They are good references.  Each operation is unique.

10. Guidance is always great.  Engagement with the Local Marine Inspectors is also helpful.  We are partners in this.

11. N/A Have own plans and training.

12. You always have additional costs with a SMS.  When you focus on safety and security you will incur time training your crews and discussing best practices.

13. N/A

14. I drafted the original work after a USCG Seminar on the PTP.  All of your professional operators did this when the USCG reached out to us.  Over time this original work has been added to.  It has also been bullet pointed into key important areas of focus.  Your crew must first learn fundamentals.  After this, they can move into becoming true professionals.  We have a fleet of 3 vessels.

15.  You have the system already.  USCG Marine Inspectors.  They are understaffed.  

16.  ABSOLUTELY NOT.  USCG Marine Inspectors only.

17.  We have a fundamentals class, and then build on that foundation.

18.  We already are engaged with training.

19.  Regulations do not help.

20.  Non-USCG Third Party Audits would be a complete waste of my time.  I do internal audits myself.

21.  Get more Marine Inspectors in your Sectors.  Allow them to reach out to the Operators.  Provide a basic bullet point fundamental framework to start with and check up with these operators.

22.  Ask your Marine Inspectors.  They are true professionals and on the front line.  Many of these individuals are truly outstanding......Ask them!

Title: Comment Submitted by Brent Bitterman
Comment:
Good Day, 

This email is in reference to potential Safety Management Systems being required for all domestic passenger vessels.  As a captain, boat and tour company owner I am in favor of protecting the public but this proposal goes too far.  Public safety should be a priority but reacting to a few specific incidents seems to me as overkill.  Generalizing across the entire US fleet of passenger vessels will create a complicated spiderweb of undue regulations and oversight.  There will be an alarming number of vessel owners that will drop their vessels from the voluntary inspected status to un-inspected in order to circumvent the system.  Please reconsider this requirement and apply to specific types of vessels or operating conditions that the USCG deems necessary. Thank you for your time.

Title: Comment Submitted by Alma Villasenor
Comment: Requiring a Safety Management System for vessel of all sizes, capacity, etc., will provide a standardized approach to safety management. A consistent approach will not only improve safety performance, but can also reduce the number of human errors, level of risks, costs associated with accidents, and will help companies comply with legislation. However, implementing a Safety Management System will also need to be followed up with mandatory training and regular inspections to verify compliance. Steady and consistent auditing procedures will also be necessary to ensure compliance is met.

Title: Comment Submitted by Henry Garcia
Comment:
My name is Henry Garcia.  My son Daniel Garcia perished on the dive boat Conception on Labor Day, 2019.  I am a retired emergency management professional with 50 years experience in the petroleum and petrochemical industries and have lived the benefits of Safety Management Systems in those industries.  It is my sincere belief that implementing such systems in passenger vessels will save lives and improve the safety of crew and passengers.  My comments follow (referencing the questions in the ANPRM).

1.	The requirement for an SMS should include but not be limited to vessels that have overnight accommodations for 10 or more people as well as an onboard mess for feeding those passengers and crew.  It should be noted that in the petroleum and petrochemical industries, Safety Management Systems have dramatically reduced reportable incident rates, reportable environmental releases, and other key measures of safety and environmental management performance.
2.	A scalable and structured SMS would provide passenger vessel owners, managers, and operators many benefits.  A primary benefit is that an SMS would encourage and facilitate the interchange of lessons learned - both in the identification risk and the approaches to mitigating those risks.  The development of common solutions to identified risks and deficiencies will reduce the cost of those responses. 
3.	The wide use of Safety Management Systems in the petroleum and petrochemical industries has demonstrated the value of sharing lessons learned.  Sharing lessons can extend between fleet owners as well and also provide support for single-vessel owners.
4.	Several SMS templates should be developed for different types of fleets, e.g., dive boats, ferries, tour boats, etc.  This would be a great help for small companies that might not have experienced safety management professionals on staff.  The templates would include procedures for launching the systems, training personnel in auditing and documentation processes, communications to upper management/ownership as well as vessel management teams, etc.  
5.	Unable to comment.
6.	No.  The use of Safety Management Systems across the various sectors of passenger vessels will be a more proactive approach and will also facilitate USCG monitoring of system implementation and performance.
7.	Unable to comment.
8.	Unable to comment.
9.	Industry standards, e.g., fire codes, should be incorporated by reference, especially in regard to the increasing load demands on vessel electrical systems for charging electronic devices, etc.
10.	Several SMS templates should be developed for different types of fleets, e.g., dive boats, ferries, tour boats, etc.  This would be a great help for small companies that might not have experienced safety management professionals on staff.  The templates would include procedures for launching the systems, training personnel in auditing and documentation processes, communications to upper management/ownership as well as vessel management teams, etc.  The USCG should make personnel available to conduct online seminars to assist owners in implementation.  Such seminars as well as specific training modules could be available for streaming to other owners.
11.	Unable to comment.
12.	Companies with many vessels may need to establish a full-time position to oversee implementation and steward progress towards implementation and measures of performance.  Smaller companies may need to rely on consulting firms to assist in modification of SMS templates for their organizations and implementing those systems.
13.	Not an operator; unable to comment.
14.	If templates are available, a realistic timeline for adapting and implementing an SMS would be 12-18 months.
15.	The USCG should require a certification process and an ongoing audit process.  Both could be conducted by approved third-party companies with experience in SMS.
16.	The USCG should conduct some audits, especially in the early stages of the program.  Candidates for future audits by the Coast Guard could be determined by reviewing the results of third-party audits.  Audits should be conducted after the first full year of implementation and then every 36 months.
17.	Beyond any position-specific training that they already receive, some crew members would require a general overview of their company/vessel SMS and how to conduct and report self-audits and measures of performance.
18.	Not an operator; unable to comment.
19.	Not an operator; unable to comment.
20.	Unable to comment.
21.	The carrot-and-stick approach would be appropriate.  There should be realistic timelines and deadlines for implementation with penalties for noncompliance.  A well-publicized certification by the Coast Guard or recognized third-party entity can offer branding and marketing benefits for operators.
22.	The focus above all should be on improving the safety of crew and passengers.  An additional benefit would be areas of environmental performance.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: My comment is related to number 4 of the information requested section, I believe that an SMS can be effectively implemented into a multi-vessel fleet. It could be done by breaking down the SMS into 2 parts, the first part is an SMS for the entire fleet that deals with emergences and operations for the fleet as a whole as well as communication between ships to prevent siloing and then another part that pertains to each individual ship. The SMS for each ship could account for differences between ships, if applicable, and operations in the event of a problem occurring in just one ship. This type of system could help in preventing people from receiving injury because of lack of communication and lack of knowledge in case of an accident or problem.

Title: Comment Submitted by Calysta Bartlett
Comment: Hello, my name is Calysta Bartlett and I am reviewing this proposal from a passengers point of view. I do think that this increase in SMS procedures is something that can help the safety of passengers. By taking the events such as the tourist boat explosion in the Bahamas in 2018 which resulted in lives lost, it can be easy to asses the situation and wonder if the horrible accident could have been avoided if there were more procedures or percussions taken. I believe that enforcing these new SMS procedures creates two different sides, people who want safety but do not understand the technical impact of these changes, and the side of people who deal with the already heavy workload of different percussions and what not. Although I can understand that these changes may result in added work to the already plentiful loads that boat owners have, it should be worth anything to save any passenger on a vessel from potentially loosing their life.

Title: Comment Submitted by Victoria Moore
Comment:
Dear United States Coast Guard,
Question #1:
I believe the Coast Guard should require a Safety Management System for a wide range if passenger vessels including:
- any passenger vessel that has overnight accommodations
- any passenger vessel carrying 12 or more passengers (should be at least as strict as the current international traveling vessels)
- any passenger vessel traveling more than a half hour's reach for emergency response (medical, fire, explosion, etc)
- passenger vehicles that are stand alone or part of a fleet.  The number of vessels is not important compared to having a SMS in place.
2.  A scalable SMS for fleets makes sense, but SMS should be required per above regardless of whether it can be scaled or apply to a fleet.  It is not necessarily less likely that individual passenger vessels would face an emergency situation.  In the case of the Conception, that vessel was one of only three vessels operated by Truth Aquatics, but it could have just as easily been the only vessel operated by Truth Aquatics.
3. A SMS should absolutely be shared with all vessels in a fleet and there must be explicit requirements for doing so, including evidence that it has been done.   It makes no sense to do anything less than this. 
In their Marine Accident Report “Fire aboard Small Passenger Vessel Conception” (NTSB/MAR-20/03 PB2020-0101011) the National Transportation Safety Board documented an interview with a passenger from a trip on October 8, 2018 on the Vision, another vessel owned and operated by Truth Aquatics.  In this interview, this passenger Mr. Savage recounted being asleep in the bunkroom of the Vision when a battery charging fire started in the aft salon.  He recalled being told that his charging batteries had exploded and caught fire around 4:30-5:00 in the morning.  The following morning the Captain indicated that all battery charging at nighttime was to cease.
Had this incident been shared with the sistership Conception and an investigation and response been performed through a robust fleetwide SMS System in October of 2018 it is entirely possible that 33 passengers and one crew member may not have perished onboard the Conception on September 2, 2019.
So, have I encountered situations in which information about safety risks or best practices were know to one vessel but not shared with others that might use it to prevent incidents?  I absolutely have and this lack of sharing resulted in the loss of my Husband and Daughter.  I truly believe that an SMS System in practice during the 2018 incident would have saved the lives of 34 people.
4. A SMS should be implemented across a fleet the same way that any business with branches or operations in multiple locations -- through clear communications and requirements for compliance.  All crew responsible for the safety of each vessel must be required to be trained in SMS and have required "refresher" trainings for both the captain as well as all other crew members.  The reason that all crew members should be trained is because you simply won't know which crew member(s) will be in the position to implement SMS procedures.  For example, the captain may be injured in a fire or explosion and thus another crew member may have to carry out the SMS procedures.  This is not a difficult thing to implement.  The Coast Guard should have a process to verify that the training and equipment is in place at least on a yearly basis.  
6. The important thing is that the SMS or whatever the process for achieving safety requirements include all recommendations from The NTSB Marine Accident Report (NTSB/MAR-20/03 PB2020-0101011).
7. No.  In addition to SMS, additional regulations are also necessary to incorporate the requirements contained in the Regulations for Covered Small Passenger Vessels passed in the National Defense Authorization Act of 2021.  The regulations required by this Act ensure compliance with overnight roving patrols.  These regulations are critical as the failure to provide the overnight roving patrol was determined to be the probable cause of the Conception tragedy which took the life of my husband and daughter.  In addition, the Act provides for additional regulations for the safe handling, storage, and operation of lithium-ion batteries, improved fire and safety training protocols, increased fire detection and suppression systems, interconnected fire detection equipment including audible and visual alarms, two independent avenues of escape and a protocol and monitoring devices to ensure a roving patrol is awake and on active duty.  Having a robust fleetwide SMS will help ensure that these important regulatory requirements are adhered to.

8.  A SMS is justified, period. A maintenance plan or emergency plan doesn’t take the place of full SMS.

Please see attached file for the complete comments.  The complete comments did not fit on this form.

Title: Comment Submitted by Rhonda Farrar
Comment: Losing so many people in  such a senseless fashion in the the MV Conception was devastating.  Particularly, the loss of Scott and Kendra Chan, who were dear friends.  The fact that this could have been prevented by simple safety rules makes the loss even more painful.  Please take action to regulate and enforce SMS procedures.

Title: MM1 Comment Submitted by Drew Jensen
Comment:
Comments re: Document USCG-2020-0123-0001:

22. Are there any additional factors that we should consider? We lost two of our best in Scott and Kendra Chan from this senseless tragedy. Let us act now to prevent it from ever happening again. 

1: For which types of passenger vessels should the Coast Guard require an SMS? A Safety Management System (SMS) should be required for as wide a range of passenger vessels as possible to assure greatest potential to save lives. One criteria could be vessels that travel more than a half-hours distance from emergency help in the case of a disaster.

3: To what extent would an SMS encourage sharing and prevent the "siloing" of information in which information about safety risks or best practices was known to one vessel not not sure with others? A SMS should absolutely be shared with all vessels in a fleet and there must be explicit requirements for doing so, including evidence that it has been done.

7: If a comprehensive SMS is required, are there more prescriptive USCG regulations currently in the CFR that could be removed because the SMS would serve a similar function in promoting safety? No.  In addition to SMS, additional regulations are also necessary to incorporate the requirements contained in the Regulations for Covered Small Passenger Vessels passed in the National Defense Authorization Act of 2021. These regulations ensure compliance with overnight roving patrols. The failure to provide the overnight roving patrol was determined to be the probable cause of the Conception tragedy. In addition the Act provides for additional regulations for the safe handling, storage, and operation of lithium ion batteries, improved fire and safety training protocols, increased fire detection and suppression systems, interconnected fire detection equipment including audible and visual alarms, two independent routes of escape and a protocol and monitoring devices to ensure a roving patrol is awake and on active duty. 

8. If a comprehensive SMS is not necessary or justified, what aspects of an SMS would be appropriate to include in this regulatory framework? A SMS is justified, period. A maintenance plan or emergency plan doesn’t take the place of full SMS. 

15. Should the Coast Guard require a certification process, an audit process or both? Yes. I firmly believe in certifications and audits; meaning review, approval, and oversight by the Coast Guard. If you don’t have such a program, including auditing, then how do we know if operators are meeting the standards?

16. Should the Coast Guard-required SMS be subject solely to independent third-party audits? Yes. An industry-run audits run the risk of overlooking deficiencies and pose internal conflicts of interest. A third party audit by a body with no financial or other conflict of interest should be required. It should be done at least annually and without prior notice.

17. What training or knowledge requirements are appropriate for crewmembers on passenger vessels with an SMS? Crewmembers need to be tested frequently (quarterly) through drills to assure that they are trained and fully knowledgeable to respond to potential hazards and accidents. 

19. How would the costs and benefits of expanding other existing regulations differ from the costs and benefits of requiring SMSs for all passenger vessels? The SMS should be required, period.  The SMS should have been required a decade ago and the consequences of the failure to implement and enforce can be measured by the loss of lives.

Title: MM1 Comment Submitted by Taylor Dignam
Comment:
22. Are there any additional factors that we should consider? The loss of my Dad, Justin Dignam, has impacted me every moment of everyday. He was my best friend, boss, business owner, fearless leader and happy, kind, generous man. He was our world. There are not enough words to articulate the saddness and loss this has been on our family and friends. He will not be able to walk me down the aisle at my wedding. He will not be there when I have my first child. He will not be here for any big events to come. Let's work together on this to ensure this never ever happens to anyone else.

    1: For which types of passenger vessels should the Coast Guard require an SMS? A Safety Management System (SMS) should be required for as wide a range of passenger vessels as possible to assure greatest potential to save lives. One criteria could be vessels that travel more than a half-hours distance from emergency help in the case of a disaster.

    3: To what extent would an SMS encourage sharing and prevent the "siloing" of information in which information about safety risks or best practices was known to one vessel not not sure with others? A SMS should absolutely be shared with all vessels in a fleet and there must be explicit requirements for doing so, including evidence that it has been done.

    7: If a comprehensive SMS is required, are there more prescriptive USCG regulations currently in the CFR that could be removed because the SMS would serve a similar function in promoting safety? No.  In addition to SMS, additional regulations are also necessary to incorporate the requirements contained in the Regulations for Covered Small Passenger Vessels passed in the National Defense Authorization Act of 2021. These regulations ensure compliance with overnight roving patrols. The failure to provide the overnight roving patrol was determined to be the probable cause of the Conception tragedy. In addition the Act provides for additional regulations for the safe handling, storage, and operation of lithium ion batteries, improved fire and safety training protocols, increased fire detection and suppression systems, interconnected fire detection equipment including audible and visual alarms, two independent routes of escape and a protocol and monitoring devices to ensure a roving patrol is awake and on active duty. 

    8. If a comprehensive SMS is not necessary or justified, what aspects of an SMS would be appropriate to include in this regulatory framework? A SMS is justified, period. A maintenance plan or emergency plan doesn’t take the place of full SMS. 

    15. Should the Coast Guard require a certification process, an audit process or both? Yes. I firmly believe in certifications and audits; meaning review, approval, and oversight by the Coast Guard. If you don’t have such a program, including auditing, then how do we know if operators are meeting the standards?

    16. Should the Coast Guard-required SMS be subject solely to independent third-party audits? Yes. An industry-run audits run the risk of overlooking deficiencies and pose internal conflicts of interest. A third party audit by a body with no financial or other conflict of interest should be required. It should be done at least annually and without prior notice.

    17. What training or knowledge requirements are appropriate for crewmembers on passenger vessels with an SMS? Crewmembers need to be tested frequently (quarterly) through drills to assure that they are trained and fully knowledgeable to respond to potential hazards and accidents. 

    19. How would the costs and benefits of expanding other existing regulations differ from the costs and benefits of requiring SMSs for all passenger vessels? The SMS should be required, period.  The SMS should have been required a decade ago and the consequences of the failure to implement and enforce can be measured by the loss of lives.

    21.What incentives could the Coast Guard provide passenger vessel companies to adopt an SMS? And what is the most appropriate means or method for the Coast Guard to incentivize these companies to adopt an SMS?  The incentives that the Coast Guard could provide to passenger vessel companies to adopt a SMS would be to assure the companies that they will not likely have crew or company members go to prison for gross negligence and involuntary manslaughter and be sued in civil court for wrongful death.  Companies don't need any other incentives.  We're talking about saving lives.   Why should there be other incentives, such as financial incentives, when the paramount issue to protect lives?

Title: MM1 Comment Submitted by Daniel Burns
Comment:
22. Are there any additional factors that we should consider? Scott Chan had dedicated his life to the next generation by becoming a high school physics teacher after a highly successful career as an engineer. Scott was highly regarded by his students and peers. He also shared his expertise frequently with other teachers, helping their students as well. The pain felt by Scott's students because of this preventable and heart-breaking loss is unfathomable. Studies show that a teacher as effective at teaching physics as Scott adds hundreds of thousands of dollars to the lifetime income of their students. This tragedy was a large economic loss, the costs associated with preventing another by these rules are negligible. Kendra Chan was at the start of a career that would have resulted in large positive impacts to the environmental health of our planet. Her loss hurts everyone on Earth.

    1: For which types of passenger vessels should the Coast Guard require an SMS? A Safety Management System (SMS) should be required for as wide a range of passenger vessels as possible to assure greatest potential to save lives. A maintenance plan or emergency plan doesn’t take the place of full SMS.     15. Should the Coast Guard require a certification process, an audit process or both? Yes. I firmly believe in certifications and audits; meaning review, approval, and oversight by the Coast Guard. Title: Comment Submitted by Paul Risenhoover
Comment:
Chief Petty Officer Robert Davis, Sector Guam, U.S. Coast Guard, by telephone at (671) 355-4866, or email at WWMGuam@uscg.mil.  

re docket USCG-2020-0144-0001
Cocos Crossing swim event in the waters of Cocos Lagoon, Merizo, Guam 

Dear Chief Petty Officer Davis,

We believe that the traditional waters of the Chamorro Nation belong to the traditional chiefs of the Chamorro Peoples to determine whether and if so how, to permit, use and events under DHS USCG
sponsorship such as the Cocos Crossing swim event. Swimming is a traditional Chamorro sport. 

In the 1940s the Chief of Naval Operations and the US State Department opined that Micronesians were not citizens of their own islands even, but mere  "residents of the islands."

Recently Judge Waddoups in Fitisemanu v US, held that American Samoa, quit claimed by her matai chiefs to the US, was within the US for purposes of birthright citizenship, nunc pro tunc, dating back to the Deeds of Cession in 1899, even though Congress did not accept the Deeds until act in 1925. https://casetext.com/case/fitisemanu-v-united-states
By the same logic, Guam is also in the US since 1898, and citizens since then, too. But 8 USC 1401(b) says that aboriginal Americans are entitled to maintain their tribal property and rights, even if deemed American citizens. 

25 USC 2902 and 2904 require the rulemaking be promulgated in the Federal Register and on Guahan, in Chamorro, not only in English. A Carolinian version may also be required, and indeed Palauan too, as the FAS and COFA state residents in Guam also qualify for 25 USC 2902 and 2904 rights, see Meyer v Nebraska, 
and see Farrington v. Tokushige, 273 U.S. 284 (1927).
Chamorros, like Formosans, remain wards of the military government of the US, https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1944v05/d1218
Non-Japanese Inhabitants of Formosa
 tribal aborigines as wards of the military government (PWC-19463).

https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1944v05/d1208 
 tribal aborigines, who are akin to the non-Christian peoples of Northern Luzon, are neither Japanese nor Chinese, but more properly to be considered as wards of whatever government has control of the island.
Section 302.
Any person who becomes a citizen of the United States ... become a national but not a citizen of the United States by making a declaration under oath before any court established by the Constitution or laws of the United States or any court of record in the Commonwealth in the form as follows:

"I ______________ being duly sworn, hereby declare my intention to be a national but not a citizen of the United States."
Even though most Chamorros are US citizens, some who resided in the CNMI, could elect to remain wards, but not citizens, of the US, as DHS has ruled:

https://www.uscis.gov/i-9-central/complete-correct-form-i-9/who-needs-form-i-9/federated-states-micronesia-republic-marshall-islands-and-palau  

The instructions for Form I-9, Employment Eligibility Verification, state that the term "noncitizen national of the United States" includes "certain former citizens of the former Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands." This refers to a very small group of people living in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in 1986 who chose voluntarily to give up their new U.S. citizenship. This does not apply to citizens of the FSM, RMI, or Palau, although many of them are also citizens of the former Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands (TTPI).  

https://www.gao.gov/products/473806#mt=e-report 

The Comptroller General noted Guamanians are not aliens to the US even before "granted" "citizenship", unless the act of 1917 does not include Chamorros because deemed not even "citizens" of their own islands!:

SECTION 1 OF THE ACT OF FEBRUARY 5, 1917, 39 STAT. 874, REGULATING THE IMMIGRATION OF ALIENS TO THE UNITED STATES, PROVIDES:

THAT THE WORD "ALIEN" WHEREVER USED IN THIS ACT SHALL INCLUDE ANY PERSON NOT A NATIVE-BORN OR NATURALIZED CITIZEN OF THE UNITED STATES; BUT THIS DEFINITION SHALL NOT BE HELD TO INCLUDE INDIANS OF THE UNITED STATES NOT TAXED OR CITIZENS OF THE ISLANDS UNDER THE JURISDICTION OF THE UNITED STATES. THAT THE TERM "UNITED STATES" AS USED IN THE TITLE AS WELL AS IN THE VARIOUS SECTIONS OF THIS ACT SHALL BE CONSTRUED TO MEAN THE UNITED STATES, AND ANY WATERS, TERRITORY, OR OTHER PLACE SUBJECT TO THE JURISDICTION THEREOF, 

And note that even if Chamorros are citizens, that does not mean they are no longer wards of the nation, or that their traditional lands and seas somehow become American.

The Comptroller General has ruled:

IT MAY BE STATED AS A GENERAL RULE THAT THE GRANTING OF CITIZENSHIP TO INDIANS DOES NOT ALTER THE RELATIONSHIP OF GUARDIAN AND WARD BETWEEN SUCH INDIANS AND THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT 

https://www.gao.gov/products/436727#mt=e-report 
 
Respectfully,

Dr. Paul Maas Risenhoover
Executive Director
Robin Hood International Human Rights Legal Defense Fund
Tainan, FORMOSA

Title: Comment Submitted by The Associated Branch Pilots (Bar Pilots)
Comment:
The Associated Branch Pilots (Bar Pilots) support the adjustments and additions to the referenced deep-draft anchorage spaces within the filing made under the header of USCG-2020-0154: Anchorage Regulations; Multiple Anchorages on the Mississippi River From
MM 12 AHP to MM 85 AHP.

Title: Comment Submitted by Matthew Lagarde
Comment:
i would like to express my support for the creation of additional anchorage spaces in the Mississippi River pursuant to the Federal Notice.

The addition of these anchorage spots increases the safety of navigation on the Mississippi River by allowing ships to cross the bar into the river during periods ideal conditions and stage for berths and inspections inside of the protected waters of the river.  In most of these cases the anchorages already exist in these areas, the public comment only addresses additional length of the anchorages to accommodate and additional ship or two .  Collectively the expansions of these existing anchorages add several spots.  Additionally these anchorage spots are utilized for emergency mooring during periods of reduced visibility, mechanical issues, quarantine issues, etc.

There are comments attached that the additional anchorage spots would interfere with costal restoration borrow sites.  These comments are not true.  Traditionally projects requiring dredged material work in a symbiotic relationship with the anchorages whereas the anchorages benefit from removal sediment deposits which in turn deepens the anchorage area and the coastal restoration projects get the needed material.  

If the projects truly had conflicts with one another then it would be impossible for the restoration projects to acquire fill materials from anchorages, but this has not been the case.

I currently serve as the President of the Maritime Navigation Safety Association which reviews USACE permits and provides feedback on any potential safety concerns.  To date the group has worked closely with the USCG, USACE and various entities to manages safety concerns and maximize use of the river for all interests.

Sharing of space and resources does require some cooperation and communication and perhaps this is the true concern.  The MNSA Board has requested inclusion of communications plans, estimated timelines and details on any required channel/anchorage closures and outer limits of anchoring equipment for the purposes of ensuring that the equipment used to remove the sediment does not pose an unknown risk to not only anchoring ships but also passing traffic.

The industry has a long history of working with coastal restoration projects and choosing not to use anchorage positions to facilitate dredging.  Coastal restoration is important to MNSA as a whole because we live and work in Louisiana and integrity of the Louisiana Coastal Marsh helps preserve navigation channel integrity.  The MNSA group has facilitated studies to study impact on outflow channels, particularly in the Wills Point and Ironton (Myrtle Grove) areas.  

These additional spots dedicated to anchorages also set these areas aside from other development such as terminals and barge fleets.  It is much easier to move a could of ships around in an anchorage or choose not to use a couple of spots than it is to work around infrastructure that is permanently affixed in place.  

In short, these anchorages are greatly needed for safety reasons, facilitation of commerce and to preserve these borrow sites for coastal restoration project coordination.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Title: Comment Submitted by Scot Mackey, Garden State Seafood Association (GSSA)
Comment:
July 6, 2020

Mr. Jerry Barnes & Mr. Matt Creelman
Fifth Coast Guard District
431 Crawford Street
Portsmouth, VA 23704
By email: jerry.r.barnes@uscg.mil; matthew.k.creelman2@uscg.mil
Re:	Port Access Route Study; Seacoast of NJ and Approaches to DE Bay (NJ/DE PARS)
	USCG-2020-0172

Dear Mr. Barnes and Mr. Creelman:

I am writing on behalf of Garden State Seafood Association (GSSA) based in Trenton, New Jersey.  GSSA represents roughly 1,200 commercial fishermen operating within the State, as well as the land based processor, Seafood Co-Ops, distribution system and many seafood retailers.  In 2016, a NMFS technical paper ranked New Jersey's seafood industry sixth in the U.S with sales of $6.2 billion, income of $1.4 billion and value-added of $2.3 billion.  For the East Coast, New Jersey ranked second that year. The economic impacts of the NJ seafood industry, including imports, were 37,127 jobs, $6.2 billion in sales, $1.4 billion in income, and $2.3 billion in value- added impacts.  

New Jersey's commercial fishing industry is one of the largest year-round employers in many of our coastal communities and generates thousands of direct and indirect year-round jobs in our Coastal Communities. The Industry is concentrated at five major coastal ports, namely; Belford, Pt. Pleasant, Barnegat Light, Atlantic City, and Cape May/Wildwood.  In addition, another port is located on the Delaware Bay (Port Norris) in Cumberland County.  Each port has fishing vessels that harvest a myriad of finfish and shellfish such as Atlantic scallops, monkfish, shortfin and longfin squid, Atlantic mackerel, tunas, swordfish, black sea bass, summer flounder, Atlantic surfclams, and ocean quahogs. A total of 190,500,000 pounds of finfish and shellfish were landed by New Jersey's commercial fishermen in 2018 with a landed value of $170,261,000.  Four of the top six commercial fishing ports in the Mid-Atlantic are found in New Jersey.

Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on the Notice of Study (NOS) for the NJ/DE PARS.  We appreciate the USCG focusing, primarily, on the need for long-term fishing vessel access within and safe transit through planned or potential offshore wind energy development in this region.  Obviously with the size and scope of our association, transit through these areas from home ports in all weather conditions will be of the greatest concern.

Additionally note, some federal permits such as scallops run on a strict 24 hour clock for days at sea.  So any delay in transiting from base ports to fishing grounds and returning voyages represent a direct cost to our vessels and those businesses. Not only are current wind development projects of concern, but compounded with the proposed build out of all projects represent significant transit issues.  Also recognize the value of many fragile species such as squid will be negatively impacted by transit delays.    

We are concerned that after several requests were filed requesting a public hearing a month past per your requirements on this study, no hearing has been scheduled prior to the deadline for comments today.  

our comments are attached
Sincerely,

 
Scot Mackey
Garden State Seafood Association
Smackey@mbi-gs.com

Title: Comment Submitted by Kirk Larson, Jr.
Comment: I have been fishing my whole life off the coast of NY, NJ, Mass. and as south to Florida. East to the edge of the Canadian line. Mostly fishing for sea scallops on a limited access vessel. When the weather gets bad sometimes we head to the coastline to get away from brutal weather. In the winter this helps us not take much spray so we don't accumulate ice. It looks to me that these proposed lease areas would be in the location that we go to so we can get to safety. Fishing for sea scallops we tend to catch more on the windy days dealing with wind and waves, other fisherman towing in a different direction is enough. Now add a group of electric generating turbines with cables on the bottom would make that a nightmare. Not just fishing but transiting in these areas during dense fog like conditions and bad weather would be quite difficult and dangerous especially if the wind is not the same as the transit lane direction. Especially if there is a problem with the vessel. I have had to operate a vessel in the open ocean to help a crew member get air lifted. As I can remember the coast guard chopper asked me to get my 9 knot commercial scallop vessel remain at top speed for as long and steady as I could in rough seas to help land the basket. With the spacing of the turbines I don't see that being possible. If there was a rescue needed at sea would the coast guard be slower in reaction time cause they had to navigate differently or avoid a wind farm area? A man overboard situation would eliminate a Williamson turn in some cases. Wind seems like a great source of renewable energy but why put them in an area that would create fence where for generations fishermen have been working hard to supply the world with food?  It kinda feels like we have been targeted politically. Are you telling me that there is no wind anywhere else? I find that hard to believe. As a fisherman I feel like this is an unnecessary risk that can be avoided by locating turbines on land or inland waters. That way they can be maintained and seen by the public regularly. Because when people can see them they will be more likely to be maintained. My worst fear is abandonment. If these things ever get abandoned we will be stuck with a huge ecological disaster. I don't care what these things are made of they will constantly need maintenance. Would the turbines survive Sandy or perfect storm like conditions? What is the protocol if one or more of these turbines gets wiped out by a rouge wave or a cruise ship full of people or a tanker ship carrying oil accidentally loses maneuverability. My point...there are too many if's.

Title: Comment Submitted by James Junker
Comment:
I am writing to support re-certification of the Cook Inlet Regional Citizens Advisory Council (CIRCAC). Over the last 30 years CIRCAC has helped to protect the precious resources and biodiversity of Cook Inlet. CIRCAC's work has helped to ensure environmental safety while working closely and proactively with multiple stakeholders in Alaska. I have visited Alaska five times and have close friends who live in Anchorage and in the Kenai Peninsula. I look forward to hearing that CIRCAC has been recertified. 

Thank you for your time and concern.

Title: Comment Submitted by Robert Flint
Comment:
Matthew T. Bell, Jr.
Rear Admiral
United States Coast Guard
Commander 17th Coast Guard District

Admiral Bell:

I am writing in full support of recertification of the Cook Inlet Regional Citizens Advisory Council (CIRCAC). For 30 years, CIRCAC has been Cook Inlet's most effective organization for promoting programs to prevent spills, enhance safety in both marine transportation and oil facilities operations, and protect Cook Inlet's waters, shorelines, cultural, natural and wildlife resources. Over most of those 30 years I have worked with CIRCAC first as a regulator then a volunteer.

CIRCAC advocates for better regulatory oversight and safety measures, they contribute concrete solutions on how to achieve those goals by working with the regulated community and the citizens. This includes advocating risk assessments, sharing data, developing applicable tools and strategies, evaluating best available technology, engaging the public, and thoroughly reviewing contingency plans and regulations that prioritize prevention while promoting safety. No other organization has focused as much attention for as many years to identifying, assessing and mitigating risks in this region.

CIRCAC has been proactive in identifying risks and developing recommendations to address them; an example is the recently completed Cook Inlet Pipeline Integrity Assessment. Through this project, a full catalog of Cook Inlet's undersea pipeline system was documented allowing a panel of experts, operators and the public to recommend risk reduction measures before problems arise. 

Working with industry, CIRCAC has also been able to achieve the long-term goal of closing the Drift River Oil Terminal on the West side of Cook Inlet. Situated at the base of Mt. Redoubt, Drift River posed a significant safety hazard in the event of a natural disaster. Now, that oil is transported via pipeline, greatly reducing unnecessary risk.

CIRCAC's science program provides valuable data about coastal habitats, physical oceanography and oil behavior. Current research will generate new information about how biological debris interacts with oil as it moves through the water column.

CIRCAC continues to strengthen oil spill contingency plans and recommend substantive changes to ensure facilities are adequately staffed and that the plans are executable.

CIRCAC's accomplishments in the last three years include, but are certainly not limited to:
Completing multi-year near-shore habitat assessment
Launching groundbreaking study of marine snow as an oil transporter
Advocating for a strengthening of oil spill prevention and response regulations
Increasing public outreach efforts through new, local advertising, exhibits and expanding audiences for its newsletter, website, and social media
Expanding Geographic Response Information Database (GRID) in scope and accessibility
Working with regulators to maintain a robust Vessels of Opportunity program
Upgrading the Cook Inlet Ice Monitoring Camera Network with modern video technology

Since its inception, CIRCAC has maintained a balance approach to meeting it mandate under OPA90.  The CIRCAC Council fairly represents the diverse Cook Inlet community in directing the organization.  CIRCAC forms and strengthened partnerships and encouraged consensus decision-making. Through this process, CIRCAC brings a varied group of stakeholders together to create environmental monitoring and oil spill prevention programs to promote safe production and transportation of oil in Cook Inlet.

I strongly urge the U.S. Coast Guard to re-certify CIRCAC so that it can continue to build on its work and positively impact the future of Cook Inlet. 

Sincerely 


Robert C. Flint
8631 Muir Court 
Anchorage, Alaska 99504

Title: Comment Submitted by Robert Archibald
Comment:
Cook Inlet Regional Citizens Advisory Council Recertification Application

Docket Number: USCG-2020-0188 
Submit comments at: https://www.regulations.gov/docket?D=USCG-2020-0188 



Matthew T. Bell, Jr.
Rear Admiral
United States Coast Guard
Commander 17th Coast Guard District

Admiral Bell:

I am writing in full support of recertification of the Cook Inlet Regional Citizens Advisory Council (CIRCAC).

The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 created the Regional Citizens Advisory Councils. As explained by Congress, "many people believe that complacency on the part of the industry and government personnel responsible for monitoring the operation of the Valdez terminal and vessel traffic in Prince William Sound was one of the contributing factors to the EXXON VALDEZ oil spill"
 "One way to combat this complacency is to involve local citizens in the process of    preparing, adopting, and revising oil spill contingency plans".

I have seen the value of the Cook Inlet Regional Citizens Council and the valuable programs and studies they have completed are a definite safety and pollution prevention assets for the Cook Inlet Area. 

CIRCAC is a success story that came out of a belief in 1990. 

CIRCAC has been proactive in identifying risks and developing recommendations to address them; an example is the recently completed Cook Inlet Pipeline Integrity Assessment. Through this project, a full catalog of Cook Inlet's undersea pipeline system was documented allowing a panel of experts, operators and the public to recommend risk reduction measures before problems arise. 

Working with industry, CIRCAC has also been able to achieve the long-term goal of closing the Drift River Oil Terminal on the West side of Cook Inlet. Situated at the base of Mt. Redoubt, Drift River posed a significant safety hazard in the event of a natural disaster. Now, that oil is transported via pipeline, greatly reducing unnecessary risk.

CIRCAC's science program provides valuable data about coastal habitats, physical oceanography and oil behavior. Current research will generate new information about how biological debris interacts with oil as it moves through the water column.

CIRCAC continues to strengthen oil spill contingency plans and recommend substantive changes to ensure facilities are adequately staffed and that the plans are executable. 


CIRCAC's accomplishments in the last three years include, but are certainly not limited to:

	Completing multi-year near-shore habitat assessment
	Launching groundbreaking study of marine snow as an oil transporter
	Advocating for a strengthening of oil spill prevention and response regulations 
	Increasing public outreach efforts through new, local advertising, exhibits and expanding audiences for its newsletter, website, and social media
	Expanding Geographic Response Information Database (GRID) in scope and accessibility
	Working with regulators to maintain a robust Vessels of Opportunity program
	Upgrading the Cook Inlet Ice Monitoring Camera Network with modern video technology

Since its inception, CIRCAC has formed and strengthened partnerships and encouraged consensus decision-making. Through this process, CIRCAC brings a varied group of stakeholders together to create environmental monitoring and oil spill prevention programs to promote safe production and transportation of oil in Cook Inlet.

I strongly urge the U.S. Coast Guard to recertify CIRCAC so that it can continue to build on its work and positively impact the future of Cook Inlet. 


Respectfully
Robert E. Archibald
PO. Box 2460
Homer, AK. 99603
