Topics: Harbors,Marine Safety,Navigation (Water),Reporting and Recordkeeping Requirements,Security Measures,Waterways
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Alexis K.
Comment:
The title of my chosen regulation is Safety Zone; Lake of the Ozarks, Mile 1.5 on the Gravois Arm of the Lake of the Ozarks, Lake Ozark, MO. The agency that is proposing the regulation is the U.S. Coast Guard. 

This regulation is asking for a safety zone to be enforced on certain waters of the lake during a firework show on June 6, 2020. This rule would prohibit people and watercrafts from being in the safety zone unless otherwise authorized by the designated representative. 

I think the agency is asking something that is very well valid, and much needed to enforce during the time of the show. It is needed because the public safety will be put at risk if the area is compromised during the time of the show. Failure to implement will result in possible "accidents" within the public and or serious injury/deaths from explosives. Accidental "falling red embers" from firework debris within the safety zone is not acceptable to the public's safety.

Title: Comment Submitted by Danielle L.
Comment:
The title of my chosen regulation is Safety Zone; Lake of the Ozarks, Mile 1.5 on the Gravois Arm of the Lake of the Ozarks, Lake Ozark, MO. The agency that is proposing the regulation is the U.S. Coast Guard.
The need for this regulation to be put into place is to keep the public safe from the possible hazards from the fireworks display scheduled for June 6, 2020. Possible hazards that the agency discusses are "accidental discharge of fireworks, dangerous projectiles, and falling hot embers or other debris." The agency's argument and purpose for this regulation is well thought out and very valid. The possibility of a mishap occurring is one that the agency needs to be aware of and be ready to deal with anything happens. One of the agency's responsibilities is to enforce rules and regulations that keep the public safe, and by them enforcing a safety zone, in which only authorized personnel are allowed, the agency is within their specific job duty. The regulation should be passed and enforced for the firework display that is scheduled.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: This proposal seems reasonable and I believe that it is more beneficial to small businesses in the area to have a safe fireworks display. The closure is reasonable in time, and the distance from the barge which will be providing the display is reasonable. The trade of the 1.5 hour closure would be an attraction to many of the establishments in the area and many will be in attendance helping business in the area with a boost in sales most likely. I believe this proposed regulation should be adopted with little hesitation.

Title: Comment Submitted by Evan Stone
Comment: So long as this lockdown of that portion of the lake is only in effect for the minimum amount of time required to keep people safe from the fireworks display, then I see no harm in this rule.

Title: Comment Submitted by Megan T
Comment: I believe that this proposed rule has merit because the purpose is to serve as a protection for the public. The Coast Guard are proposing this rule because of the potential dangers that boaters would face during a firework show. Fireworks can be dangerous and can misfire and endanger those around therefore, this proposed rule would be a safety measure to minimize such occurrences. The proposed rule limits entrance to the safety zone during a specified time, therefore, the safety zone is not enacted during the whole day, but during the times there is significant danger to boaters. The proposed rule also allows for boaters with reason, to gain permission from the coast guard to gain entrance during the safety zone time.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jarrod W.
Comment: The proposed rule listed here is a reasonable suggestion, because it allows the lake to stay operational during the time talked about in the rule.  This rule has good intentions to support it because it is centered around people's safety.  Because the range is limited to 420 feet, it still allows people to travel around the lake in a safe manner, and those that need within the restricted area can apply for an allowance to be in the area from the Coast Guard if they have a reasonable reason. For those this rule may greatly affect, it is only during one day of the year so they would have the ability to plan around this occurrence.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Thank you for publishing this notice.

I feel that given the current situation of COVID-19 this event would not be appropriate to promote human safety and health.  Can this event be done next year instead?  

Is the city of Milwaukee aware of this event?

Title: Comment Submitted by L. Roberts
Comment:
This rule proposal is valid and necessary because it will allow participants in the swim portion of the triathlon to safely navigate the waters. With as many as 6,000 people participating in the swim portion of the triathlon, it is imperative that those in charge of the harbor put the safety of the participants first. Allowing kayaks, paddleboards, and small boats in the water during the triathlon would likely result in serious injury to a significant portion of the 6,000 participants. By passing this rule the Coast Guard could effectively mitigate the potential for injury to participants in the swim. Furthermore, this rule would only be in effect for three days and only in certain waters. This seems like a small sacrifice to make to insure the safety of the participants. 

Sincerely,

Title: Comment Submitted by Bailee [Last Name Unknown]
Comment: There will be 6,000 participants in the upcoming triathlon and I understand that may cause overcrowding but why would the priority be to protect the participants, vessels and water toys over the wildlife living in the lake? The lake is their home and these participants, vessels and water toys are just there for activity purposes. They are disturbing the home of the wildlife and scaring them into hiding. Wildlife should be the number one priority and all rules and regulations should be to protect them first. These humans and objects are invading their space so it seems backwards that they would be the ones to be protected. I understand this triathlon is just three days out of the year but the wildlife in the lake will be terrified and it may prevent them from coming out of hiding for a little while after the event is over. I ask of you to take the lives of the fish and plants in the lake serious and consider putting regulations in place to protect them as well.

Title: Unrelated Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Thanks to the movie Wayne's World (1992) I know that Milwaukee means "the good land." Not only that, it's the home of Shotz Beer from Laverne and Shirley. What better publicity could a triathlon have?

Meanwhile back in Covid-land the Trump administration keeps sinking lower and lower. The Justice Dept under Bill Barr acts as Trump's personal legal team, authorized to investigate his enemies (Biden) and let his friends (Flynn) off the hook. Meanwhile over at HHS when a top virologist decided to focus on science rather than Trump's quack medicine, he was demoted and smeared. Title: Comment Submitted by The Wilmington Cape Fear Pilots Association
Comment:
The Wilmington Cape Fear Pilots Association fully supports the proposed anchorage ground designation adjacent to the Cape Fear River Approaches and the subsequent removal of the designated explosives anchorage off Lockwood Folly inlet as outlined in Docket ID USCG-2020-0216.  

The size and scope outlined in the docket is satisfactory to accommodate expected continued growth of traffic servicing the port of Wilmington and MOTSU and will improve navigation safety  The geographic area being considered is currently where our Association recommends vessels awaiting transit to anchor.  The area is known for suitable bottom for safe anchorage and is located a safe distance from the charted pilot boarding area to accommodate adequate leeway for embarking/disembarking maneuvers.  Anchoring vessels routinely rely on our associations instructions on anchoring locations as no such location is designated on navigational charts.  Furthermore, the current designated explosives anchorage at Lockwood Folly Inlet is insufficient for larger explosives laden vessels with known deeper drafts and should be eliminated and relocated as described in Docket ID USCG-2020-0216.

Title: Unrelated Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
This is regarding the US Coast Guard's proposed rule to establish a temporary safety zone for certain waters of Apra Outer Harbor (docket USCG-2020-0248).

Since I have never been to Guam I needed to look this up in Wikipedia. Apra harbor has a fascinating history, from fishing and whaling to Japanese occupation to liberation and now to use by the Navy, recreation boaters and scuba divers exploring shipwrecks. And I'm sure that USCG knows even more about this harbor, so I fully approve the proposed rule.

By the way Wikipedia is a convenient resource for gathering some basic facts about a place, person or event. If President Trump spent a few minutes on Wikipedia he would learn that Covid-19 is not "going away" in the US -- quite the contrary. Of course since Trump is an illiterate moron he would need to be spoon fed this information by a trusted source like Sean Hannity or Rudy Giuliani.

Title: Comment Submitted by Wallace and Associates (W&A)
Comment:
Wallace & Associates

Wallace and Associates (W&A) is a consulting firm that represents commercial fishing interest.  Many of our clients operate large fishing vessels that deploy fishing gear that comes in contact with the ocean floor.  W&A is aware of that the United States Coast Guard ( USCG) agreed with the Vineyard Wind's proposed turbine spacing of one by one nautical mile (NM) between the turbines as adequate for safe transit through Vineyard Wind, wind farm off Martha's Vineyard.  Because there are no prescribed transit, lanes and the turbines are so close together that fisheries research, fishing and search and rescue within the array is at best difficult, dangerous and in some cases impossible.  The precedents set by the Vineyard Wind proposal and accepted by the Coast Guard is going to have destructive consequences for all of the other users of the open ocean.  Our clients disagree with your acceptance of the spacing.  Spreading out the turbines to two by two NM would make the situation more palatable to the other users of the ocean.   They are:
Opening Statement
	One by one, NM between each turbine will set a precedent for all of the other wind developers to do the same.  With thousands of these structures in the offshore waters in New England and the Mid Atlantic, the turbines spacing will cause expensive and safety problems for the other users of the open ocean.  The turbine spacing should be at a least two by two NM apart, and in straight lines in both directions.
Turbine Layout for all of The New England Leases 
	The seven lease holders South and East of Martha's Vineyard have agreed to space all of their turbines in straight rows east and west, and north, and south along with their turbines being one NM apart in the entire area.  It is possible that there could be more than 1,000 turbines in the seven leases.   
Transit Lanes
	The current American ocean users have reviewed your acceptance of the one by one NM turbine spacing, as a precedent it is bewildering.  When all leases are built out a, vessel coming out of Buzzards Bay and going to the scallop grounds south of seven leases, may have to go 80 NM outside of the leases area or steam 40 to 60 NM through the arrays.  No prudent vessel captain would risk his crew and ship to steam through the wind farms, especially if it is dark, foggy. bad weather and with their radar being blinded by the rotating blades, it is too dangerous.  Spreading the turbines out to two by two NM make it more palatable to the other users. 
Fishing Access
	The fishing industry has a number of suggestions including four NM transit lanes and two by two, NM turbine spacing, which would allow transit in any direction and would be enough space for large fishing vessels to fish in the arrays safely in good weather.  
	When the ocean wind developers bid for their leases each was based on about 800 MW of power using 8 MW turbines in the lease area.  Therefore, when the 12 MW turbines became available, they increased their income by up to fifty percent.  However, they are unwilling to help the fishing industry or the other ocean users out by spreading out their turbines out to two by two NM apart.  
Americans Hurt By European Wind Farm Developers 
Research Vessels will not be Able to Complete their Protected Species and Fishery Surveys
	If the spacing of the turbines is not increased, the NOAA fishery research vessels will not be able to sample the lease areas once the turbines are installed.  That means that NOAA's fish populations, protected species and habitat work cannot be performed within the arrays and the quotas of fish will be lowered because there are questions of what the holes in the data would be so the precautionary principle must be considered, meaning reducing the fisheries quotas.
	For surveys of protected species, which is done by aircraft in many cases, using low flying small aircraft.  During surveys, the aircraft normally fly at about 500 feet.   Once the turbines are installed, the aircraft will be required to fly above 2500 feet, which reduces the sightings and the details necessary for identifying the type of whale and markings of whales, dolphins and sea turtles.  This will not be acceptable because of the poor quality of the detailed data collection.
Search and Rescue Within the 1300 Square Miles Wind Arrays.
	If the turbine spacing is one by one NM apart aircraft will be useless in heavy weather.  If an aircraft were to attempting help a distressed vessel there would be little the aircraft crew could do to help from 2500 feet.   
	Therefore, a small boat would be necessary to find the vessel in distress and provide the necessary help.  The amount of extra time it would take to find and get to a vessel that is taking on water or being on fire is going to reduce the chance of a good outcome are much lower.
Conclusion
  
						David H. Wallace,
						Wallace & Associates

Title: Comment Submitted by Jim Barton
Comment: I live on smith cove, about a mile north of the coast guard academy and travel up and down the Thanes river at least once a week from mid April until mid October. During July and August it is much more frequent probably 2-4 times per week   Only on a rare occasion do I see a single boat anchored in the proposed area. I've never seen multiple boats anchored.   I don't see any issues reducing by half the area for anchorage as it Is seldom used.  It would be nice if the new building and pier would be constructed in a visually responsible way.  The only thing I'd like to know is how many jobs will it bring to the area and the average annual income it will provide for the workers.

Title: Comment Submitted by Content Brockett
Comment: It seems to me that looking at the maps that have been circulated these modifications will destroy some very productive shellfish beds. This modification is in anticipation of an entirely new and larger pier north of the Gold Star Bridge which will most likely then need massive dredging for the size boats that will also be coming up the river. This dredging process will also destroy productive shellfish beds.

Title: Comment Submitted by Priscilla Wells

Title: Comment Submitted by Emilee Harris
Comment: I support this proposed rule because it provides essential safety for the viewers of the firework show as well as the travelling vessels. Fireworks have the potential to cause severe damage to people and property so by having a 420-foot radius safety zone, it will allow vessels and other travelling boats a way to avoid this potential harm. By continuing this safety zone even once the show has concluded, it will provide ample time for proper cleanup for the safety of vessels and boats as well as safety of the cleanup crew. Fireworks can be seen from a distance, so moving viewers will allow them to still enjoy the show, while being a safe distance away from the accidental discharge of the fireworks.

Title: Comment Submitted by A. Scott Fulkerson
Comment: The problem I see with this is that the proposed rule covers what seems to be a rather expansive section of the river of about three miles. It would seem more pragmatic to the rights of all parties involved to require Newbergh to limit the fireworks display in such a manner that the safety zone only need be much smaller, say no more than two miles at most- in order to limit the potential unconstitutional effects on interstate commerce. I find that, despite the proper rule-making authority- it is still the agency's responsibility to limit the effects of state and local government actions to be as de minimus as possible in terms of effects on interstate commerce.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
There is a known flaw in the physical requirements for mariners. A completed physical with a physicians signature is normally all that is required to meet coast guard requirements.

There is currently no way for the coast guard to verify that a pilot/master who is obese meets the physical demonstrations requirements except for taking the doctors word for it. For example: bending over and touching your toes, climbing an almost vertical ladder and crawling through a 24" square hatch.

I see hundreds of captains and pilots every year and for many it is obvious that it is impossible for them to meet the standards of the Mariner Medical manual. Part of this problem is perpetuated by using family doctors whom the member has know for most of his life or company paid doctors who "may" have incentive to "sign off" on the physical. I'm not claiming any knowledge of illegalities but being in the industry for over 40 years does give me some credibility.

I understand the underlying problems of shortages of pilots and captains but if this is a mandatory requirement it should be verified by some means. For example: Full body profile picture, verified or a third party verification, etc.....

Dear President Tiny Hands,

People used to trust the NWS hurricane forecast maps. Then you altered a map with a Sharpie, lied about the path of hurricane Dorian, and got NOAA to back you up and chide the local weather station.

And you also got the FDA to laughably misstate the benefits of plasma therapy. These are just a few examples from a long list of institutions you've screwed up. Basically everything you touch turns to crap. I look forward to seeing you and your inept, corrupt family evicted from the White House.

Title: COAST GUARD NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT (NEPA) RECORD OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSIDERATION (REC) FOR CATEGORICALLY EXCLUDED ACTIONS
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Jada P
Comment:
I agree with this regulation because I think the U.S Coastguard (USCG) is well within their rights to issue this regulation, because the have the safety of others on the fore front of their mind. If they were just proposing this regulation for the fun of it, more than likely I would be opposed to it. The good thing is that it is only temporary so when the Ocean Cup Pacific Rum Run is over other vessels can enter and exit as they please. This regulation is put in to place so that the vessels who would like to enter the designated area will not interfere with the vessels participating in this event. So I agree, if the vessels are traveling at around 100 miles per hour there needs to be no other vessel traveling in that area because someone can get seriously hurt. The coast guard is here to protect our waters and everyone in our waters and they will be doing just that if this regulation is passed!

-Jada Anonymous

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I submit the action be excluded since the entire Proposed Action clearly fits within the category of excludable actions set forth as CATEX.

Title: Comment Submitted by Quinn Tran, Orange Coast College
Comment:
The objective of this proposed rule is to establish a one-time, temporary safety zone near Ship Rock, Catalina Island, in support of the Ocean Cup Pacific Rum Run. This rule is to protect the area near Ship Rock, Catalina Island, public vessels, and the high speed vessels participating in the event. This regulation would prohibit vessels from entering into, transiting through, or remaining within the designated area unless specifically authorized by the Captain of the Port, Los AngelesLong Beach, or her designated representative. The safety zone is scheduled to be enforced on the day of the Pacific Rum Run race, which is planned for October 10, 2020. 
After reading the proposed rule thoroughly, I think the proposed safety zone is a good idea to protect the safety of participating parties and the public as this race will involve a high concentration of racing vessels operating at high speed. Moreover, the proposed rule seems to have taken into consideration its impact on other entities, such as small businesses, Indian tribal governments, environment, and protest activities, and it seems like it will not have a significantly negative impact, if any, on those entities. Specifically, it will not have a significant economic impact on a substantial number of small entities because commercial vessel traffic will be able to safely transit through this safety zone with the Captain and her representatives guidance, and recreational traffic will also be allowed to travel around the safety zone. 
However, I do have a side comment, which is not directly related to the proposed rule itself. I believe the safety zone itself should not have any problem with negatively affecting the environment since it is just a safety zone, but the Pacific Rum race does affect the environment. I dont know anything about this race nor its purposes, but I do think racing vessels will emit a lot of oil and gas that will bring about air and water pollution to the area. Thus, I dont support the idea of having this kind of event. There should be a rule regulating events that could negatively affect the environment.

Title: Unrelated Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Donald Trump is a derogatory person. Which is a polite way of saying that he's a total jerk. He regularly attacks, insults and mocks individuals and groups.

Trump denies that he has mocked veterans, Christians, Mormons, taxpayers and the disabled. But he's a serial liar with zero credibility. Trump lies so often that his own staff can't keep up, which is why they have to keep correcting each other. So his denials mean nothing. Fer cryin' out loud, this is a guy that denies saying things that Bob Woodward has ON TAPE.

But hey, Trump supporters - you shouldn't feel bad that Trump is almost certainly laughing at you. Really, why should you care what he thinks? True he does have the the world's ear, but that's only because he's president. And that's something you can fix.

Vote. Him. Out.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Agency/Docket Number:re
    Docket Number USCG-2020-0511  
I do not own a boat, however, the information published in this Federal Register (FR) makes no sense.  What does a company which performs car "tricks" have to do which with the "safety of life" on navigable waters at Annapolis, MD?  Please explain.  Also, please explain the reason why there is only a 15-day comment period vice the normal 30 days.  A persuasive reason has not been provided for this short time frame other than a lack of tourism.  Tourism drop off covers more than the month of October.  I fail to see the urgency in a car company needing to use and cordon off our waterways.  It makes no sense.  Also, why does there need to be a "rule" and the involvement of Homeland Security?  Ordinarily filming in this area is simply published in the local newspapers and the proper arrangements made through the local authorities.  What is Hoonigan Industries filming?  Are they also filming around the Annapolis City Dock?  Are the "safety zones"  only on the water?  Seriously?  For Hoonigan car racing?  I believe there should be more definitive information published when using Federal Resources during a COVID19 crises.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jennifer Kaye
Comment:
We have a business, Schooner Woodwind Sailing Cruises that uses Annapolis Harbor and "Ego Alley" aka Market Slip and Spa Creek. We currently have an 11:00-1:00 sail planned on both of our sailing cruise vessels. I would like to continue to do our Sailing Cruise, as we are a business and need the $$. We have been hurt so much by COVID-19 and the changes to our USCG capacity because of physical distancing, we need to be able to get out and back to our dock at 80 Compromise Street at the Annapolis Waterfront Hotel. If there is a map available of the impacted area, can you please forward it to me.

Just opening up the harbor enough to let us out would be great. And of course to come back in. The revenue that we could lose is up to $3500.

Thanks-

Title: Comment Submitted by Peter Guth
Comment:
If this is to support a stupid motocycle stunt, it should not be done in our city with inconvenience to boaters and residents alike.  The proposal is very misleading in not getting very specific about what they are filming, apparently because they do not want the public to see what is happening (or know what is being requested).

Closing public access to support private movie making is an inconvenience we should not put up with.  The city of Annapolis already closes too much, but at least the reasons are clearly explained, and there is some public benefit, which is sorely lacking in this case.

It they do not pull the request now that the details are out, you should turn this down.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Expansion of safety zones is not needed or wanted in Spa Creek. 
Please . Do not restrict boating.
I have been in AACO for 55 years . There are too many Government restrictions appearing due to some minority.
Consider the rest of us before you give in to the wishes of a few who squeak loudly.

Title: Comment Submitted by Joseph Baressi
Comment:
I respectfully request that DHS and the Coast Guard decline to finalize this proposed rule.

Hoonigan Industries has no need to use this specific location for this proposed purpose. I own a house in the vicinity and I believe that Hoonigan can find another location for its desired stunt jump where costly and disruptive harm-prevention measures are not necessary.

Further, Hoonigan's proposed purpose for these costly and disruptive measures -- a motorcycle stunt jump -- is unnecessary, bordering on frivolous. It is also dangerous, both to the motorcycle rider himself and to others in the area.

Title: Comment Submitted by Rebecca Pioso
Comment: I fully agree that two safety zones need to be established as a film is being produced on Spa Creek because the "safety of life" should be a top priority. This rule is very respectable and reasonable because of the fact that vessels only need to leave the designated area during filming, which is only a minimal number of hours. Additionally, these enforcements are not during the main tourism season or weekends, causing as minimal economic harm as possible. The proposed rule acknowledges through The Regulatory Flexibility Act of 1980 that this act would not make a significant harmful economic impact on many small entities.This rule puts several considerations on the table, including Executive Order 13175 which shows that this rule would not impact one or more Indian tribes. Overall, this environmental law considers several crucial aspects such as the economy and social inequities, so there is no reason this should not be passed.

In response to this rule we at Gaelic Tugboat Company have a problem with this rule. Steve Carrothers

Gaelic Tugboat Company

Topics: Navigation (Water),Waterways

Title: Comment Submitted by Max Dunlavy
Comment: I see this NPRM as a good thing because it can be somewhat related to car traffic.  Another semi-truck, like a vessel, does not want to wait for another semi-truck to slow or stop traffic to wait for an open spot whether that be at a rest stop, or its final destination.  By allowing the movement to go around, it is mitigating the probable cause of creating a slow down of traffic or causing another vessel to miss its ETA or become off schedule.

Title: Comment Submitted by Bay H
Comment: Concerning the connecting waters from Lake Huron to Lake Erie, what are the precautions that are being taken when considering the chemical and biological contaminants? In Lake Erie, there are toxic contaminants that are being introduced into the Lake Erie. The toxic chemicals impact water quality, affecting drinking water, wildlife, and humans. There are biological contaminants such as Type E botulism bacterium. Therefore, when connecting Lake Huron into Lake Erie, it will result in the spread of contaminants into Lake Huron. Which then introduces those contaminants into Lake Huron and those contaminants in Lake Huron to spread into Lake Erie.

Title: Comment Submitted by Ryan Kluk
Comment: When people walk on the sidewalk or when cars are on the highway, people pass slower walkers or drivers. Boats should be allowed the same, especially if allowing boats to pass improves shipping times and trade efficiency.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: This proposed rule is a good thing, allowing vehicles to legally pass another in the case of the vehicle being passed is being towed or towing another vehicle or slowed down waiting for berth availability. This proposed rule will allow the passing vehicle to save some time by overtaking the slowed vehicle. Passing a slowed vehicle will bring benefits. The time taken to travel will decrease. If the vehicle in wait happened to be a ship holding cargo, the delivery time will decrease allowing for faster shipments. Being allowed to pass a slow vehicle will also prevent the helmsman's emotional state to worsen. No one likes to be forced to wait for someone else. This can be proven on street roads. If someone was forced to wait after a long day, the helmsman might get irritated and cause problems in social interactions later on that day.

Title: Comment Submitted by Carin Bess
Comment: I am currently working with an environmental engineer on a case study of the Minnesota River. This case study is looking at the changes that have occurred in the river over the past 60 years, which includes a change in tributaries, and a drastic increase in the amount of sediment present in the water. Based on this case study, I am in support of establishing an RNA to protect the cap on sediment in the Willamette River. If the sediment in the Willamette River increases, it could potentially start to mirror the Minnesota River which is having negative effects on the community living near the river as well as the agricultural services that use the river for transportation of goods. The Willamette River has the potential of flooding if sediment increases at all, which could affect the nearby floodplains and any houses or structures nearby. If the establishment of an RNA will ensure that the sediment in the river will remain at bay, then it is definitely worth the investment.

Title: Comment Submitted by Lauren Clagg
Comment: The regulated navigation area was originally created to restrict navigation through the channel for vessels with a draft of less than 34.5 feet, however, a recent survey places the sewer line at or below the permitted depth of 42 feet. The hazard is adequately marked on the water surface as well as on navigation charts. With the advancement of technology and mechanical innovations as well as the expertise of the pilots that guide vessels in and around Port Tampa Bay, the current restricted navigation area has become outdated. After reading the summary and information given, I see no existing reason why the rule cannot be passed. If the navigation does not pose a threat to wildlife or the underwater pipeline is no longer a concern, then by all means. The removal of the regulated navigation area may even assist seafarers in allowing for quicker travel.

Title: Comment Submitted by Melissa Berthier
Comment: Thanks so much for considering an opening schedule of "on the hour/half hour" (outside of rush hour) for the 63 Street bridge. I live on Collins Avenue and 57 Street and take that bridge often. It's a Godsend knowing it won't open during rush hour and this new schedule will allow me to plan my routes accordingly when I travel in the off peak hours and during the weekend. I applaud the Coast Guard for this effort!

Title: Comment Submitted by Mark B
Comment: As a north beach resident I use the 63rd street bridge, but for the past several months have opted to use 41st street even though it's further, just to avoid the unpredictability and extensive traffic backups related to the 63rd street bride openings. I appreciate the coast guard for evaluating and hopefully improving this situation. One thing not clear from reading the previous or current scheduling information is how late in the evening the bridge can open, is it 24x7?

Title: Comment Submitted by Richard Steinberg
Comment: The restrictions have been very helpful in reducing traffic in peak times and allowing for route planning.  Please extend to cover more time.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
I have become aware of the new weekend test schedule for the 63rd Street drawbridge openings that took effect on December 14, 2020 and that will continue for the next 6 months until June 11, 2021 which is designed to be a test to see if this new schedule (without the On-Demand openings on the weekends) will help to alleviate traffic congestion on the weekends.  

I want to let you know that I am ok with having the On-Demand schedule removed on the weekends.  I am ok with openings on the weekends to be only on the hour and the half-hour just like it is done on the weekdays from Monday to Friday. I also feel that because of the many large charter boats that go out of the Hotel marinas/docks all throughout every day of the week (especially on the weekends) that because of the On-Demand schedule that the bridge is opening too often during the weekdays and weekends and that it causes more traffic congestion than is necessary. It is my opinion that the charter boat captains and their guests that leave from the Hotel marinas/docks can schedule their boats to leave the docks and wait for the bridge to be opened on the hour and the half hour, and that this would reduce the number of bridge openings on the weekend reducing the traffic congestion. There will likely be more boats waiting to go through the 63rd Street bridge on Saturdays and Sundays at certain times of the day, and that the bridge will likely need to remain open a minute or two longer each time it opens up on the hour and the half hour versus the amount of time that the bridge was open in the past with the On-Demand openings. Nevertheless, I am confident that the data you are collecting from the 6 month test will allow you and your team to make the proper decision regarding this issue, but wanted to give my opinion on the matter as stated/offered in the notice that was published/broadcasted to all citizens (and boaters in this waterway) potentially affected by the proposed change. 

What I am not ok with and what I strongly object to is for the curfew that currently exists during the weekdays (from 7 am to 10 am and from 4 pm to 7 pm) to be applied to the weekend days also as was the case this past Sunday, December 20, 2020 in the morning and then again in the afternoon on the same day on Sunday, December 20, 2020.  It appears to have been a mistake on the part of the bridge operator and the acting supervisor of the bridge operator. I received a notice from the City of Miami Beach on December 12, 2020 and the notice never said anything about applying the weekday curfew to the weekend days (Saturdays and Sundays) also when no peak traffic periods exists on the weekends between the hours of 7 am and 10 am or from 4 pm to 7 pm or at any other time of the day. I asked the bridge operator to call her supervisor and she was told by her supervisor that the curfew was also being applied or in place on the weekends also during the 6 month trial period and that the curfew took place in the morning and that it would be also be in effect in the afternoon from 4 pm to 7 pm. I decided to call the Coast Guard at 1-855-406-8724 and an officer directed me to call the Coast Guard Miami Beach sector at 305-535-4472. I sent the Coast Guard information by text that I found on Google (a Federal Register document) that discussed the new test schedule for the 63rd Street bridge and that said the curfew only applies on the weekdays from Monday to Friday. It appears that the information was sent to the acting bridge supervisor and then passed on to the on-duty bridge operator who told me that a mistake had been made/admitted when they applied the curfew to the weekend. This information was provided to me by the bridge operator after I called her on my VHF radio in the late afternoon as I began to hear and see her granting requests to boats to open the 63rd Street bridge between 4 pm and 7 pm. Applying the weekday curfew to the weekend would be too restrictive, unreasonable and unfair to all of the boaters that live on the waterway south of the 63rd Street bridge that just want to go boating with their friends and families for a few hours in the morning or in the afternoon especially since there are no peak vehicular traffic periods on Saturdays and Sundays at any time in the morning or the afternoon. I wanted for you to be aware of what happened this past Sunday to me and many other boaters, and for you to have my opinion on the curfew matter in the event that this is something that is also proposed or requested by one or more private citizens in the future (i.e. applying the curfew that is in place during the weekdays to the weekend days also).  

Thank you very much for your time and attention to my comments above and to this matter.

There will likely be more boats waiting to go through the 63rd Street bridge on Saturdays and Sundays at certain times of the day, and that the bridge will likely need to remain open a minute or two longer each time it opens up on the hour and the half hour versus the amount of time that the bridge was open in the past with the On-Demand openings. Nevertheless, I am confident that the data you are collecting from the 6 month test will allow you and your team to make the proper decision regarding this issue, but wanted to give my opinion on the matter as stated/offered in the notice that was published/broadcasted to all citizens (and boaters in this waterway) potentially affected by the proposed change. What I am not ok with and what I strongly object to is for the curfew that currently exists during the weekdays (from 7 am to 10 am and from 4 pm to 7 pm) to be applied to the weekend days also as was the case this past Sunday, December 20, 2020 in the morning and then again in the afternoon on the same day on Sunday, December 20, 2020. It appears to have been a mistake on the part of the bridge operator and the acting supervisor of the bridge operator. I received a notice from the City of Miami Beach on December 12, 2020 and the notice never said anything about applying the weekday curfew to the weekend days (Saturdays and Sundays) also when no peak traffic periods exists on the weekends between the hours of 7 am and 10 am or from 4 pm to 7 pm or at any other time of the day. I asked the bridge operator to call her supervisor and she was told by her supervisor that the curfew was also being applied or in place on the weekends also during the 6 month trial period and that the curfew took place in the morning and that it would be also be in effect in the afternoon from 4 pm to 7 pm. I decided to call the Coast Guard at 1-855-406-8724 and an officer directed me to call the Coast Guard Miami Beach sector at 305-535-4472. I sent the Coast Guard information by text that I found on Google (a Federal Register document) that discussed the new test schedule for the 63rd Street bridge and that said the curfew only applies on the weekdays from Monday to Friday. It appears that the information was sent to the acting bridge supervisor and then passed on to the on-duty bridge operator who told me that a mistake had been made/admitted when they applied the curfew to the weekend. This information was provided to me by the bridge operator after I called her on my VHF radio in the late afternoon as I began to hear and see her granting requests to boats to open the 63rd Street bridge between 4 pm and 7 pm. I wanted for you to be aware of what happened this past Sunday to me and many other boaters, and for you to have my opinion on the curfew matter in the event that this is something that is also proposed or requested by one or more private citizens in the future (i.e. applying the curfew that is in place during the weekdays to the weekend days also). Thank you very much for your time and attention to my comments above and to this matter.

Title: Comment Submitted by Lizette Lopez
Comment: Good morning & Happy New Year, I would like to thank all involved, especially Commissioner Steinberg for always asking residents for their input & keeping us informed. I would like to express my support to the USCG proposed 63street Bridge weekend operating schedule. I believe it strikes a fair balance between the needs of the motorist and boaters. Thanks from a Beach Resident.

Title: Comment Submitted by Liz S
Comment: As a resident and boat owner living between 63rd street and 41st street on Collins, I am fine with a fixed schedule for weekends, however I believe there should NOT be a curfew at all on weekends or holidays. Further, while I understand the need for limited openings during the week, residents should be able to have access even if only once each hour. Otherwise it is too restrictive for folks living south of the bridge who truly have no other route they could take.

Title: Comment Submitted by
Comment: The situation with the 63 bridge has become unbearable. At times the bridge is up for 10+mins resulting in a massive inconvenience for 100s of cars, an increase in emissions and backed up traffic on Alton and Pine Tree that also further pollutes those homes atmospheres.  All this for one or two boats with 4-5 people in them (all likely wealthy due to size of boats that requiere the bridge to move). Presently I believe it opens once per half hour, how about hourly OR better yet a TOLL for the boats when it opens thereby Paying for maintenance which might make bridge run more efficiently or forcing boats to find alternative routes out to sea.  The situation needs to be addressed as it is a massive inconvenience to 100s of people for the pleasure of a few.  Thank you

Title: Comment Submitted by Milton Raijman
Comment:
As a property owner and boater in the affected area, I support the new test schedule which replaces on-demand weekend openings with bridge openings only on the hour and half hour.  I encourage the Coast Guard to permanently implement this schedule (or even a slightly expanded schedule) after the evaluation period, as it is already evident that these measures are effective, beneficial and necessary to improve traffic flow along Alton Road, Pinetree Drive and Indian Creek Drive. 

I would also like to take this opportunity to praise the Coast Guard for having previously implemented the Monday through Friday rush hour bridge lock-down schedule which has dramatically improved rush hour traffic flow along Alton Road, Pinetree Drive, and Indian Creek Drive.   That simple but important bridge schedule change has had an enormous positive effect on the quality of life of thousands of people daily, while at the same time greatly improving emergency response times for police,fire and life safety vehicles which were previously stuck in gridlock traffic jams every weekday morning and afternoon.

Title: Comment Submitted by Robert Schwartz
Comment:
As a homeowner on Allison road.  It would be best for all parties involved if all openings were on schedule.  
There is no reason for random openings.  
Scheduled openings are better for residents, boat captains ,and bridge operators.


 Scheduled openings allow residents to avoid spending 20 minutes waiting on bridges to run an errand a half a mile away.


Another bonus is  on weekdays business can run  more efficiently avoid wasting valuable time waiting for bridge.  A 10 minute errand often turns into an unpredictable 30 minutes .

Title: Comment Submitted by Eric Mendelson
Comment: Scheduled openings permit us to plan when we should travel by car, as continual openings are very disruptive.  Also, the Coast Guard should monitor the no wake situation in Indian Creek on the weekends, as the charter boats (over 100/day) ignore the no wake postings and create much wake.

Title: Comment Submitted by Michael Smith
Comment: Hello, I am a homeowner on Allison Road.  We have work schedules (both spouses) and 2 students in school and sometimes from home.  The scheduled openings have been great and allowed for planning and being on time when leaving and returning to home.  The challenge for on demand is that the timing is unknown and allows for large boats (many of them are now charters) picking up speed upon suddenly seeing the bridge open when rounding the northern tip of our island.  Scheduled has led to the private boats and charters planning their departures and return and a safer route and less damage to the seawalls.  When on demand, the bridge operators would open and close the bridge within minutes of each other for multiple openings.  There was no reasoning to it and we would have several openings, especially on weekends within 10 or 15 minutes of each other. The bridge operator would not require boats to sit.  Traffic was terrible.

Title: Comment Submitted by Ida Schwartz
Comment:
As a resident living on Allison Road  I would like to let you know that I favor the Scheduled Openings at all times.
I can plan my day without concern for catching the bridge which opens randomly.  The Traffic delays are frustrating and time consuming

Title: Comment Submitted by Rayna Mintz
Comment:
I am a resident of aqua and it is extremely important to me and my family for the coast guard to have scheduled opening hours of the 63rd St bridge so that I can plan accordingly as otherwise it is impossible to exit and enter Aqua because of the traffic back up . In addition, it causes me to be late or miss appoitments because of the traffic back ups when the bridge opens on demand. 

Thank you
Rayna Mintz

Title: Comment Submitted by Eric Kraftsow
Comment: Please keep the bridge openings on a schedule otherwise it makes living in the area a nightmare as you can't plan properly to be on time for work , school and appointments. Traffic backs up from bridge openings but atleast when on a schedule one can plan accordingly. Thank you for your help.

Title: Comment Submitted by Melissa Budin
Comment:
Please as a resident of aqua that it is extremely important to you and your family for the coast guard to have scheduled opening hours of the 63rd St bridge so that you can plan accordingly as otherwise it is impossible to exit and enter Aqua because of the traffic back up . In addition , it causes you to be late or miss appoitments because of the traffic back ups when the bridge opens on demand. 



Thank you

Title: Comment Submitted by Renata Vasconez
Comment: Hello! This is Renata Vasconez. I live in Aqua at Allison Island. As someone with a busy schedule, that comes in an out the Island several times a day, I find VERY IMPORTANT than the openings of the bridge are regulated by a ser schedule. Numerous times have been stuck at the bridge twice in less that 30 minutes. We NEED to address this matter.

Title: Comment Submitted by Diane Ovadia
Comment:
Hi ! I live at Aqua Ave and I am having an issue with the bridge that opens on 63rd street. I need to know what is the schedule of them opening the bridge. I'm always late because that bridge that opens all the time. Please let me know what is the schedule URGENTLY. 
Sincerely, 
Diane Ovadia.

Title: Comment Submitted by Juan Cruz
Comment:
As a resident of aqua located at 6103 Aqua Avenue, it is extremely important the coast guard have scheduled opening hours of the 63rd St bridge so that we can plan our lives accordingly as otherwise it is impossible to exit and enter Aqua because of the traffic back up . In addition, it causes me to be late or miss appoitments because of the traffic back ups when the bridge opens on demand. It has caused my daughters to be late to school. On the weekends it opens every 15-20 minutes.  Please help us! As a former resident of the venetian islands on Miami Beach I know you can make the change. 

Thank you!

Title: Comment Submitted by David Greenberg
Comment:
The on demand open of the 63rd street bridge has made living in Aqua at Allison Island extremely difficult.  There is no way to plan when to
Leave.  It seems the bridge in a given hour maybe raised more than it is lowered fir traffic.  The bridge is opening mostly for charters and putting the residence last.  A charter could easily schedule their trip around abridge opening.

Title: Comment Submitted by Pablo Chiozza
Comment:
The bridge opens on demand, it has no blackout times making the traffic insane. We need to rule this, no openings on week days from 7-9,30am and from 3:45-5,45 pm. Weekends the openings should be every hour on the hour.
Also the siren blowing so hard make our lives miserable, specially during the weekends when the bridge can open every ten minutes.
There is also no maximum time for the bridge to be open, it happened several times that the operator waits for boats that are further north of Alison island, making the wait longer building up traffic on both ends.

Title: Comment Submitted by Luisa Mannucci Pizzorni
Comment:
Dear coast guards, as a resident of Aqua Allison Island it is extremely important for me and my family, to have schedule opening hours of the 63rd street bridge, that can help me to plan accordingly, and avoid to be late to my appointments.
Thank you for your consideration 

Kind Regards,

Title: Comment Submitted by Langdon- Grace Coen
Comment:
as a resident of aqua that it is extremely important to me and my family for the coast guard to have scheduled opening hours of the 63rd St bridge so that i can plan accordingly as otherwise it is impossible to exit and enter Aqua because of the traffic back up . In addition , it causes me to be late or miss appoitments because of the traffic back ups when the bridge opens on demand. 


Thank you

Title: Comment Submitted by Alan Waserstein
Comment:
We live in Allison Island. The bridge currently opens on demand. This causes a lot of gridlock and traffic and many times 1 boat is holding up at least 80 cars and up to 200 people. Most of the people that are waiting for the bridge to close are working as opposed to 1-10 people that are going on a boat where waiting 30-45 is insignificant.

By have a schedule drivers in cars will know when they shouldn't cross the bridge and many boater will know the same thing.
I am a boater and have a boat and always check the bridge schedules to know when to travel.

I hope that is schedule for opening is done on the weekdays and weekends

Title: Comment Submitted by Babi Haykel
Comment: We would like a schedule for the bridge to open. I'm a resident of Aqua and the bridge situation is extremely annoying

Title: Comment Submitted by Jaclyn Miller
Comment:
We live at Aqua and Allison Island. The lack of drawbridge schedule over the last 15 years that we have lived here, has created a traffic nightmare. The traffic is increasingly more congested over the years, which has been compounded by the bridge opening and closing on demand for boats. In the last several years many boats have started docking at the fountain blue and Eden roc marinas, in addition to charter boats that come into the area to park and party. It would be increasingly helpful to have some sort of schedule so that traffic in the area is not so heavily impacted. The majority of the boats going by who need to go under the bridge when it is up, our charters that can wait the 15 to 20 minutes extra for an hour on the hour and half hour schedule.

Please consider this change to help alleviate traffic in the area.

Title: Comment Submitted by Brian Riemer
Comment: I feel strongly that the bridge should only be open at scheduled times.

Title: Comment Submitted by Traci Waserstein
Comment: We would like this bridge to be put on a fixed schedule please NOT on demand. It's terrible for the surrounding islands with traffic. Thank you.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jessica Waserstein
Comment: I strongly believe and am in favor of the drawbridge opening based on a schedule. If the drawbridge is to open on demand, this will create even worse car traffic and congestion surrounding the nearby neighborhoods. The bridge opening on demand also creates chaos and is inefficient. The residents who are living in the nearby neighborhoods who are traveling to and from their homes multiple times a day, should be given the opportunity to plan around these scheduled times and people traveling by boat should equally plan according to the schedule as well. Boats speed in the canals and pass by the surrounding homes numerous times per day with loud music and opening on demand will only make this situation worse.

Title: Comment Submitted by Brittany Riemer
Comment: I am in favor of scheduled time for bridge openings.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jill Meland
Comment: the bridge should be on a scheduled opening as its burdensome and random effect on drivers and pedestrians our weights the benefit to the boaters. There are a many more users vehicles and pedestrians hindered by randomly on demand openings which sometimes take more that 15 minutes and make people late. If it were schedule boaters and drivers could all schudleue accordingly and be on time. as a resident who lives on allison island near the bridge.....the back up of boats and noise from the boats is a nuisance that interferes with our enjoyment and privacy at our home. having the bridge on schedules will hopefully alleviate this problem

Title: Comment Submitted by

Title: Comment Submitted by William Crew
Comment: We are actively cruising waters off the east coast of the US and out of range of VHF communication towers.  We have an HF radio but do not have any satellite communications systems.  I have often felt that your monitoring HF emergency channels was an excellent safety net for us.

Title: Comment Submitted by Paul Eugenio
Comment:
This is a bad idea as many HF radios do not have DSC.  The activity on the HF emergency frequencies is limited because the type of sailors who utilize HF radios(marine&amateur) are more competent and less likely to waste USCG resources for the Yuppie 911 type needs. That is one on HF is not likely to call for a "come get me I'm sea sick".  BUT when emergency is call out over HF, it will likely be a bonafide emergency need.   

I strongly urge that maintaining HF monitoring continue.

Title: Comment Submitted by Kevin Bennett
Comment: Please continue to monitor HF frequency.  Sat phones are extremely expensive and cost prohibitive for small operations.  If they are required it would put small commercial fishing vessels in financial hardship.  If discontinuing please offer buy back program for existing HF equipment installed to comply in the amount equal to or greater than cost of sat phone or wave requirement for vessels under 20 ton or 40foot in length

Title: Special Local Regulation; Gasparilla Marine Parade; Hillsborough Bay; Tampa, FL
Topics: Marine Safety,Navigation (Water),Reporting and Recordkeeping Requirements,Waterways

Title: Comment Submitted by StraitsResearch
Comment:
It cannot be too strongly emphasized that even
charts based on modern surveys may not show all seabed obstructions or the shoalest depths, and actual tide
levels may be appreciably lower than those predicted.

Title: Comment Submitted by Alan Richard
Comment:
Paragraph (2) of subsection (b), "Special Local Regulations," is addressed to "Jet skis and vessels without mechanical propulsion."  Jet ski is a registered trademark of Kawasaki.  By specifying Jet skis, you fail to regulate WaveRunners (Yamaha), Sea-Doos (Bombardier Recreational Products), AquaTrax (Honda), and similar vessels.  All of these other brands could enter the parade route without violating the proposed regulation.

The appropriate term for these vessels is "personal watercraft" or PWCs.  Section 33 C.F.R.  173.3 provides this definition: "Personal watercraft means a vessel propelled by a water-jet pump or other machinery as its primary source of motive power and designed to be operated by a person sitting, standing, or kneeling on the vessel, rather than sitting or standing within the vessel's hull.  See also: 33 C.F.R.  174.3 (identical definition);  327.02(36), Fla. Stat. (2020) (similar definition).

I recommend that you revise paragraph (b)(2) to read: "Personal watercraft (Jet Skis, Sea-Doos, WaveRunners, etc.) and vessels without mechanical propulsion are prohibited from the parade route."

Title: Unrelated Comment Submitted by Ram Yadav
Comment: In consultation with public health officials and consistent with the January 21, 2021 Executive Order on Promoting COVID-19 Safety in Domestic and International Travel and the January 29, 2021 Order by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announcing a requirement for persons to wear masks while on conveyances and at transportation hubs, the Acting Secretary of Homeland Security on January 27, 2021, issued a Declaration of a National Emergency Requiring Actions to Protect the Safety of Americans Using and Employed by the Transportation System (``declaration''). The declaration finds that a national emergency exists and directs the Transportation Security Administration to take certain actions to promote safety in and to secure the transportation system and to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 through the transportation system.

Title: Safety Zone; Fincantieri Blasting Project; Menominee River, Menominee, MI and Marinette, WI
Topics: Harbors,Marine Safety,Navigation (Water),Reporting and Recordkeeping Requirements,Security Measures,Waterways
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Angela May
Comment: It is important to maintain the safety of individuals. By enforcing a safety zone of 1000 feet it should be sufficient for individuals to keep them safe from the blasts coming from the site.

Title: Comment Submitted by Bee Jeenkins
Comment: I completely agree with the precautions being taken with the safety zone proposed by the Coast Guard. The restricted usage of persons and vessels within the safety zone is a great precaution, especially with the prohibited usage during blasting periods for safety. Having this safety zone withing 1000ft  should be reasonable depending on the size of the blasts, but should be varied depending on the same. Overall great precautions being taken.
